life and letter
i do nt remember hear the phrase white guilt very much before the mid
grow up black in the s i never have the impression that white be much disturb by guilt when it come to black
when i would stray into the wrong restaurant in pursuit of a hamburger it do nt occur to me that the waitress be unduly trouble by guilt when she ask me to leave
i can see now that possibly she be but then all i see be her irritability at have to carry out so unpleasant a task
if there be guilt it be mine for have make a imposition of myself
i can remember feel a certain sympathy for such people as if i be victimize them by draw them out of a innocent anonymity into the unasked for role of racial policeman
occasionally they come right out and ask me to feel sorry for them
a caddymaster at a country club tell my brother and me that he be this white club and that we should try to understand his position put yourself in my shoe
our color have bring this man anguish and if a part of that anguish be guilt it be not as immediate to me as my own guilt
i smile at the man to let him know he should nt feel bad and then begin my long walk home
certainly i also judge him a coward but in that era his cowardice be something i have to absorb
in the s particularly the blackisbeautiful late s this absorption of another be cowardice be no long necessary
the line of moral power like plate in the earth have shift
white guilt become so palpable you could see it on people
at the time what it look like to my eye be a remarkable loss of authority
and what white lose in authority black gain
you can not feel guilty about anyone without give away power to them
suddenly this huge vulnerability have open have the power to step right into it
in fact black power all but demand that you do so
what shock me in the late s after the helplessness i have feel in the fifties be that guilt have change the nature of the white man s burden from the administration of inferior to the uplift of equal from the obligation of dominance to the urgency of repentance
i think what make the difference between the fifties and sixties at least as far as white guilt be concerned be that white undergo a archetypal fall
because of the immense turmoil of the civil right movement and later the blackpower movement white be confront for more than a decade with their willingness to participate in or comply with the oppression of black their indifference to human suffering and denigration their capacity to abide evil for their own benefit and in the defiance of their own sacred principle
the civil right bill that bestow equality under the law on black be also in have white society not be wrong there would have be no need for such a bill
in this bill the nation acknowledge its fallenness its lack of racial innocence and confront the incriminating selfknowledge that it have rationalize for many year a flagrant injustice
denial be a common way of handle guilt but in the s there be little will leave for denial except in the most recalcitrant white
with this defense lose there be really only one road back to innocence through action and policy that would bring redemption
in the s the need for white redemption from racial guilt become the most powerful yet unspoken element in america s socialpolicymaking process first give rise to the great society and then to a series of program policy and law that seek to make black equality and restitution a national mission
once america could no long deny its guilt it go after redemption or at least the look of redemption and do so with a vengeance
yet today some twenty many measure the gap between black and white be widen rather than narrow
a university of chicago study indicate that segregation be more entrenched in american city today than ever imagine
a national research council study note the status of black relative to white in housing and education have stagnate or regress since the early seventies
a followup to the famous kerner commission report warn that black be as much at risk today of become a nation within a nation as we be twenty year ago when the original report be make
i think the white need for redemption have contribute to this tragic situation by shape our policy regarding black in way that may deliver the look of innocence to society and its institution but that do very little actually to uplift black
the specific effect of this hidden need have be to bend social policy more toward reparation for black oppression than toward the much hard and more mundane work of black uplift and development
rather than facilitate the development of black to achieve parity be a good example have tend to give black special entitlement that in many case be of no use because black lack the development that would put us in a position to take advantage of them
i think the reason there have be more entitlement than development be along with black power the unacknowledged white need for redemption not true redemption which would have concentrate policy on black development but the appearance of redemption which require only that society in the name of development seem to be pay back its former victim with preference
one of the effect of entitlement i believe have be to encourage in black a dependency both on entitlement and on the white guilt that generate them
even when it serve ideal justice bounty from another man s guilt weaken
while this be not the only factor in black stagnation and regression i believe it be one very potent factor
it be easy enough to say that white guilt too often have the effect what exactly be this guilt and how do it work in american life
i think white guilt in its broad sense spring from a knowledge of illgotten advantage
more precisely it come from the juxtaposition of this knowledge with the inevitable gratitude one feel for be white rather than black in america
give the moral instinct of human being it be all but impossible to enjoy a illgotten advantage much less to feel at least secretly grateful for it without consciously or unconsciously experience guilt
if as kierkegaard write innocence be ignorance then guilt must always involve knowledge
white american know that their historical advantage come from the subjugation of a entire people
so even for white today for whom racism be anathema there be no escape from the knowledge that make for guilt
racial guilt simply accompany the condition of be white in america
i do not believe that this guilt be a crushing anguish for most white but i do believe it constitute a that be a thread in white life sometimes feel sometimes not but ever present as a potential feeling
in the late s almost any black could charge this vulnerability with enough current for a white person to feel it
i have a friend who have develop this activity into a sort of specialty
i do nt think he mean to be mean though certainly he be mean
i think he be in that hyperbolic era exhilarated by the discovery that his race which have long be a liability now give him a certain edge that white guilt be the true force behind black power
to feel this power he would sometimes set up what he call race experiment
once i watch him stop a white businessman in the man s room of a large hotel and convince him to increase his tip to the black attendant from one to twenty dollar
my friend s tactic be very simple even corny
out of the attendant s earshot he ask the man elderly and very dark man in a starched white smock that make the skin on his neck and face look as leathery as a turtle s
he sit listlessly pathetically on a straightbacked chair next to a small table on which sit a stack of hand towel and a silver plate for tip
since the attendant offer no service whatever beyond the hand out of towel one could only conclude the hotel management offer his lowly presence as flattery to their patron as a opportunity for that easy noblesse oblige that could reassure even the harried and weary traveling salesman of his superior station
my friend be quick to make this point to the businessman and to say that no white man would do in this job
but when the businessman put the single back in his wallet and take out a five my friend only sneer
do he understand the tragedy of a life spend this way of what it must be like to earn one s paltry living as a symbol of inferiority and do he ironically he have just spend the day try to sell a printing press to the black muslim for their newspaper mohammed speak be connect to the deprivation of this man and others like him
but then my friend make a mistake that end the game
in the heat of argument which until then have only be playfully challenging he inadvertently mention his father
this stop the victim cold and his eye turn inward
what about your father the businessman ask
my friend reply he have a hard life that be all
how do he have a hard life the businessman ask
now my friend be on the defensive
i know he do not get along with his father a bitter man who work night in a factory and demand that the house be dark and silent all day
my friend blame his father s bitterness on racism but i know he have not mean to exploit his own pain in this silly experiment
do nt know how to get out of the situation without lose face
now catch in his own trap he do what he least want to do
he give forth the rage he truly feel to a white stranger in a public man s room
my father never have a chance he say with the kind of anger that could easily turn to tear
he never have a freakin chance
your father have all the goddamn chance and you know he do
you sell print press to black people and make thousand and your father probably live down in fat city florida all because you be white
on and on he go in this vein use against all that be honorable in him his own profound racial pain to extract a flash of guilt from a white man he do nt even know
he get more than a flash
the businessman be touch
his eye become mournful and finally he simply say you he take a twenty dollar bill from his wallet and walk over and drop it in the old man s tip plate
when he be go my friend and i could not look at the old man nor could we look at each other
it be obvious that this be a rather shameful encounter for all concerned my friend and i as his silent accomplice trade on our racial pain tamper with a strange for no reason and the stranger then buy his way out of the situation for twenty dollar a sum that be generous by one count and cheap by another
it be not a encounter of people but of historical grudge and guilt
yet when i think about it now twenty year later i see that it have all the element of a paradigm that i believe have be very much at the heart of racial policymaking in america since the s
my friend do two thing that make this businessman vulnerable to his guilt that bring his guilt into man in touch with his own knowledge of his illgotten advantage as a white
the effect of this be to disallow the man any pretense of racial innocence to let him know that even if he be not the sort of white who use the word nigger around the dinner table he still have reason to feel racial guilt
but as disarming as this might have be it be too abstract to do much more than crack open this man s vulnerability to expose him to the logic of white guilt
this be the fivedollar intellectual sort of guilt
the twenty dollar required something more visceral
in achieve this the second thing my friend do be something he have not intend to do something that ultimately bring him as much shame as he be dole out he make a display of his own racial pain and anger
what bring him shame be not the pain and anger but his trading on them for what turn out to be a mere twenty buck
man s knowledge of illgotten advantage to give credibility and solidity to it by put a face on it
here be human testimony a young black beside himself at the thought of his father s racially constricted life
the pain of one man evidence the knowledge of the other
when the businessman listen to my friend s pain his racial guilt normally only one source of guilt lie dormant among others be call out like a neglected debt he would finally have to settle
a illgotten advantage be not hard to bear it can be mark up to fate until it touch the genuine human pain it have bring into the world
this be the pain that harden guilty knowledge
such knowledge be a powerful influence when it become conscious
what make it so powerful be the element of fear that guilt always carry the fear of what the guilty knowledge say about us
guilt make us afraid for ourselves and thus generate as much selfpreoccupation as concern for others
the nature the reestablishment of good feeling about oneself
in this sense the fear for the self that be bury in all guilt be a pressure toward selfishness
it can lead us to put our own need for innocence above our concern for the problem that make us feel guilt in the first place
but this fear for the self do not only inspire selfishness it also become a pressure to escape the guiltinducing situation
when selfishness and escapism be at work we be no long interested in the source of our guilt and therefore no long concerned with a authentic redemption from it
then we only want the look of redemption the gesture of concern that will give us the appearance of innocence and escape from the situation
obviously the businessman do not put twenty dollar in the tip plate because he think it would uplift black american
he do it selfishly for the appearance of concern and for the escape it afford him
this be not to say that guilt be never the right motive it be a very dangerous one because of its tendency to draw us into selfpreoccupation and escapism
guilt be a civilizing emotion when the fear for the self that it carry be contain a containment that allow guilt to be more selfless and that make genuine concern possible
i think this be the kind of guilt that along with the other force make the civil right bill possible
but since then i believe too many of our social policy relate to race have be shape by the fearful underside of guilt
black power evoke white guilt and make it a force in american institution very much in the same way as my friend bring it to life in the businessman
few people volunteer for guilt
usually others make us feel it
it be the expression of black anger and pain that harden the guilty knowledge of white illgotten advantage
and black power whether from militant fringe group the civil right establishment or big city political campaign know exactly the kind of white guilt of white guilt in which white fear for their own decency and innocence it want the guilt of white selfpreoccupation and escapism
always at the heart of black power in whatever form have be a profound anger at what be do to black and a equally profound feeling that there should be reparation
but a sober white guilt in which fear for the self be still contain seek a strict fairness the civil right bill that guaranteed equality under the law
it be of little value when one be after more than fairness
so black power make its mission to have white fear for their innocence to feel a visceral guilt from which they would have to seek a more profound redemption
in such redemption be the possibility of black reparation
black power up the ante on white guilt
with black power all of the element of the hidden paradigm that shape america s racerelated social policy be in place
knowledge of illgotten advantage could now be show and deepen by black power redeem themselves by offer more than fairness by offer form of reparation and compensation for past injustice
i believe this bend our policy toward racial entitlement at the expense of racial development
in one of the assurance senator hubert humphrey and others have to give congress to get the landmark civil right bill pass be that the bill would not in any way require employer to use racial preference to rectify racial imbalance
but this be before the explosion of black power in the late s before the hidden paradigm be set in motion
after black power racial preference become the order of the day
if this paradigm bring black entitlement it also bring the continuation of the most profound problem in american society the invisibility of black as a people
the white guilt that this paradigm elicit be the kind of guilt that preoccupy white with their own innocence and pressure them toward escapism twenty dollar in the plate and out the door
with this guilt as opposed to the contained guilt of need for quick redemption
black then become a mean to this redemption and as such they must be see as generally less than others
their need be special unique different
they be see exclusively along the dimension of their victimization so that they become different people with whom white can negotiate entitlement but never fully see as people like themselves
guilt that preoccupy people with their own innocence blind them to those who make them feel guilty
this of course be not racism and yet it have the same effect as racism since it make black something of a separate species for whom normal standard and value do not automatically apply
nowhere be this more evident today than in american university
at some of america s most elite university administrator have grant concession in response to black student demand black power that all but sanction racial separatism on campus black theme dorm black student union black yearbook believe administrator sincerely believe in these separatist concession
most of them be liberal who see racial separatism as wrong
but black student demand pull administrator into the paradigm of selfpreoccupied white guilt whereby they seek a quick redemption by offer special entitlement that go beyond fairness
as a result black student become all but invisible to them
though black have the low grade point average of any racial group in american university administrator never sit down with them and demand in kind that black student bring their grade up to par
the paradigm of white guilt make the real problem of black student secondary to the need for white redemption
it also cut administrator off from their own value which would most certainly discourage racial separatism and encourage high academic performance for black student
lastly it make for escapist policy
there be no difference between give black student a separate lounge and leave twenty dollar in the tip plate on the way out the door
what demonstrate more than anything else the degree to by this paradigm be their refusal to lead black student to tell them what they honestly think to insist that they perform at a high academic level and to ask them to integrate themselves fully into campus life
this mark the difference between selfpreoccupied guilt and the guilt of genuine concern where fear for one s innocence be contain
the former grant entitlement as a mean to easy innocence and escape from judgment the latter refuse the entanglement and blindness of selfconcerned guilt and out of honest concern demand black development
escapist racial policy policy where institution favor black entitlement over development because of a preoccupation with their own innocence have i believe a dispiriting effect on black
such policy have the effect of transform white from victimizer into patronizers and keep black where they have always be dependent on the largesse of white
this be make evident in a famous statement by president lyndon johnson at howard university in 
you do not take a person who for year bring him up to the starting line of a race and then say you be free to compete with others and justly believe that you have be fair
on its surface this seem to be the most reasonable of statement but on closer examination one can clearly see how it deflect the emphasis away from black responsibility and toward white responsibility
the actor in this statement you white do not take a person black be white black be the passive recipient of white action
the former victimizer be challenge now to be patron but where be the black challenge this be really a statement to and about white people their guilt their responsibility and their road to redemption
not only do it not enunciate a black mission but it see black only on the dimension of their victimization hobble by chain and cast them once again into the role of receiver of white beneficence
nowhere in this utterance do president johnson show black to run fast once they get to the starting line
this statement which launch johnson s great society have the two everpresent signpost of white guilt white selfpreoccupation and black invisibility
white guilt have influence many of america s racial policy toward a paternalism that make it difficult for black to find their true mettle or to develop a faith in their own capacity to run as fast as others
the most vivid example of this be the many form of preferential treatment that come under the heading of affirmative action a escapist racial policy i believe that offer entitlement rather than development to black
a preference be not a training program it teach no skill instill no value
it only make a color a passport
but the bad aspect of racial preference be that they encourage dependency on entitlement rather than on our own initiative a situation that have already lead many black to believe that we can not have fairness without entitlement
here one fall into orwellian doublespeak confusion i believe be a unspoken black doubt about our ability to compete that be cover over by a preoccupation with racial discrimination
since there be already law to protect us against discrimination preference only impute a certain helplessness to black that diminish our selfesteem
the selfpreoccupied form of white guilt that be behind racial preference always make us lower so that we can be lift up
recently pennsylvania state university launch a program that pay black student for improve their grade a c to c average bring and anything high bring 
here be the sort of guilty kindness that kill
what kind of selfrespect be a black student go to have as he or she reach out to take for c work when many white student would be embarrass by so average a performance what better way to drive home the nail of inferiority what more pavlovian system of conditioning black to dependency than shell out cash for grade here black student learn to hustle their victimization rather than overcome it while not all preferential treatment be this insidious but the same dynamics be always at work when skin color bring entitlement
i think effective racial policy can only come from the sort of white guilt where fear for the self be contain so that genuine concern can ultimately emerge
the test for this healthy guilt be simply a heartfelt feeling of concern without any compromise of one s high value and principle
but how can white reach this more selfless form of guilt i believe the only way be to slacken one s grip on innocence
guilt have always be the lazy man s way to innocence i feel guilt because i be innocent and guilt confirm my innocence
it be the compulsion to think always of ourselves as innocent that bind us to selfpreoccupied guilt
white in general and particularly those public and private insitutions not necessarily white that make racial policy must not be so preoccupied with their image of innocence or put another way their public relation of good intention
in racial matter where black be view simply as american citizen who deserve complete fairness and in some case developmental assistance but in no case special entitlement base on color
we need social policy that attack poverty rather than black poverty and that instill those value that make for selfreliance
the white message to black must be america hurt you badly and that be wrong but entitlement only prolong the hurt while development overcome it
selfish white guilt be really selfimportance
it have no humility and it ask for a unreasonable egotistical innocence
nothing diminish a black more than this sort of guilt in a white which to my mind amount to a sort of moral colonialism
we use to say in the s that at least in the south you know where you stand
i always think this be a little foolish since i do nt like where i stand there
but i think one of the thing we mean by this at the time be that the south have very liberating in a ironical sort of way
it mean there would be no entangling complication with white need
it give us back ourselves
the selfishly guilty white person be draw to what black least like in themselves their suffering victimization and dependency
this be no good for anyone black or white
by shelby steele
shelby steele be a associate professor of english at san jose state university
his book the content of our character a new vision of race in america will be publish this august by st martin s press
section life and letter
the prince of wales in his speech and book a vision for britain attack modernist architect for building they have put up in the postwar year in britain have arouse a uproar among architect
one writer in architectural review the leading british architectural journal even find the source of the prince s taste in the architecture of nazi germany
he reproduce some picture of new housing from a german publicity handout of and sure enough they show singlefamily home on their own little plot
because the nazi prefer singlefamily house to apartmenthome block he find a precedent for the prince
of course we find the same preference in pare lorentz s famous movie the city make for the new york world be fair in or in the book and article of the reformer clarence stein and lewis mumford advocate planned community of low density for family
and these be no nazi
but architect give the prince no take the prince to task for colonialism racism and imperialism because he like classical architecture and would prefer to see more classical element in contemporary building
in this storm of denunciation the prince can only find satisfaction in the fact that the ordinary people seem to agree with him and that his critic be hysterical
which raise a paradox how be it possible that modernist architecture which begin with deep social concern and one of whose theme be proper housing for worker to improve their lot now require a elitist defense argue that only properly qualify professionally train expert should discuss and criticize architecture how do a socially concerned architecture turn out to be condemn fifty year later as soulless bureaucratic and inhuman a critique that receive wide acceptance by ordinary folk who have enthusiastically and overwhelmingly applaud the prince s attack on contemporary architecture and by many architect and planner as well
it be in the thirties that modern idea in architecture first begin to filter back american return from europe begin to bring us news of the modern movement
some of them be mostly interested in the new strip down unornamented functional aesthetic form but others be more interested in house for worker
catherine bauer s modern housing have a great influence on concerned architect on planner and on the early public housing movement
she bring back picture of the new housing be build in europe by socialist or socially concerned government
we look at the picture with admiration
instead of the messy workingclass district we know in american city with their crowded building build right up in a wall against the street with their mixture of housing and store and pushcart and sign with their sidewalk crowd with pedestrian and horse there be not many car in poor area then we see simple block of building in modern style orient to catch the sun with ample space around each block
yet today these onceadmired building block for worker from germany and know when or under what regime they be build most people would prefer those individual home show in the nazi publicity pamphlet
and many architect would agree
moshe safdie in his book form and purpose show picture of israeli apartment complex on the hill around jerusalem build under a social democratic government
and he contrast them unfavorably with arab housing build without benefit of modernism or government concern for the poor or house law that guarantee subsidized and modern dwelling unit to the poor
in other word the product of architectural concern for the working class do nt evoke much admiration today
what seem in the s and early postworld war ii decade to be responsive to social need and indeed be responsive to social need as far as architect and planner and socially mind government could discern them at the time now seem to us inhumane soulless bureaucratic
it be a very upsetting development if we be concerned that architect take more account of social consideration when socially mind now appear to us pretty poor stuff
be we wrong then about what be good housing for the poor and be we right now and if our taste have change so radically be it possible that they will change again and that we be right then and be wrong now
consider a concrete example of how our taste and judgment about house for the poor have change since the thirties
there be a aerial photograph much reproduce in reformist book on housing and urbanism of one of our first housing project set in the midst of a sea of slum and tenement in brooklyn
we see from the air the endless grid of street line with unbroken housing
we can see in the middle of each block if we look closely something rather fuzzy the backyard behind the tenement of each block
in the middle of the photograph a dozen block have be clear away obliterate tenement and street and set on this white and empty site be line up the street grid as if to remind us that the original street grid be set down by soulless marketminded surveyor
these new house for the worker be site scientifically to catch the sun or for some other good reason that cause their designer to ignore the original street grid
around the building be a expanse of empty land which will be dedicate to playground and greenery
i recall as a socialminded and socialist youth look at this picture proud at what have be do worry about how long it would take to clear away the surrounding sea of slum
when that photograph be first publish the tenement represent the terrible past the housing project the future
we all know what housing project represent to us today
those old building if they have survive be now often more desirable not only to poor people but to middleclass people too
what explain this upsetting reversal of taste do we deal with simple designer idiosyncrasy a and brownstone of new york properly remodel of course to the housing that be build as part of a great social experiment that social experiment incorporate to the extent this could be do in the practical world of bureaucrat and financial limitation the thinking of socially concerned architect and planner
be it that we simply and irrationally love strong cornice stoop column heavy lintel strongly marked sill the occasional decoration that grace even the worker housing of the early twentieth century
if that explain the reversal of taste it would be irresponsible for us to prefer the old
but it turn out that many of the people for whom the subsidized public housing with plenty of open space be build also prefer the old
now we must avoid the mistake of explain people s preference for one kind of housing or another only because of difference in design
people with few choice do nt decide on the basis of design
if we be to ask them they might say the project delinquent family or that they can nt live near their mother or they would give some other reason that relate to the social composition of the project or the bureaucratic rule under which it operate
or if they prefer the project and many do we might find out that it be because it be comparatively so cheap because of its subsidy and not because of its design and more spacious surroundings
design be nt everything
but design do play a role not only in the distaste of presentday designer and architect and planner for the result of the socially concerned architect and planner of the past but in the preference of the people with limited choice who reject or accept them today
and so we have our problem why be it that the sophisticated intelligence of socially mind architect do nt produce satisfactory environment for those with the least choice even bad why be it as my example suggest that environment build by commercial builder try simply to make a buck as environment in their appeal to ordinary people now here be something one have to ponder
it be all too easy to understand why the environment create by anonymous architect on greek island in italian hill town in moroccan city be so much more attractive to architect and designer today than what either sophisticated modernist or postmodernists do
that problem be a familiar one and we have answer that be more or less satisfactory
the town grow organically over time in one traditional style with one major traditional building material it enclose a life define by a traditional culture
what result impress all architect and designer of whatever persuasion
in year of leaf through architectural book and magazine i have never yet see a picture of one of these mediterranean urban environment that be use to illustrate a bad environment
every architect or designer love them
it be only reformer who be unsophisticated as designer generally native who want to sweep them away because of crowd or dirt or limited air the building block that have become the uniform residence of people all over the world
so we understand well enough why these environment have become so attractive to us
we know why or can guess why even the modern displaced arab who do know about other way of building who can use a variety of material who have to build his housing fast rather than over century and who may want to accommodate car seem to build a better environment according to moshe safdie than the israeli government agency with their advanced westerntrained architect and designer modern standard uptodateness in all respect
for a architect to lose out to the arab or any other traditional builder of the vernacular housing of a traditional culture in the way of produce good housing be not so devastating after all we be up against all that traditional wisdom develop over the age
but to lose out to the commercial builder be another matter and one that can not make the commercial builder beat out the architectdesigner
the question be why and i suspect the answer will teach us more than we can learn from the mediterranean village or the other wonderful works of the vernacular builder
consider two far example of this competition between the commercial builder with no high ambition than to produce what will sell or rent and the sophisticated architectdesigner
the first come from england and it be the case of the town of sunderland a shipbuilding and coalmining town fall on hard time for some decade in which old housing have be clear away for new development in the decade since world war ii
england we should recall stand in the first few decade after the war at the forefront of plan internationally and at the forefront of europe in the provision of good housing for the working class
it be a mecca for anyone interested in good planning and in sensible replacement of house stock
the case of sunderland have be describe in a fascinating book by norman dennis of course go first and there seem to have be little opposition to clear it after all all those who lose their housing be guarantee new wellsubsidized modern housing
by the bad of the slum have be clear but central government money be still available for go far and planner select the area by their standard that should be level with the people rehouse in new modern flat
by this time the resistance be severe
why consider the house that be come down to be replace by modern flat
they be typical of the row house for worker of the dreary industrial town of england
these cottage as they be call in sunderland be build for the working class by unnamed builder one hundred year ago
many be rent but most be by this time own by their inhabitant
the house sit directly on the sidewalk
there be no tree on the street
there be no front yard
we floor and if there be a second as some have two more window
there be a tiny backyard with a brick outhouse
what could possess people to prefer these anonymous and styleless dwelling to new flat and one heavily subsidize to boot but if one look more closely one see that one facade have be stucco another leave in brick
one entry have a flat top another a arched one
some window have heavily mark lintel top and bottom
other have the lintel stucco over
at the end of one block in a unit identical to the others be the gardener s arm a pub
we can understand some of the reason why people prefer to stay and some of them have nothing to do with architect or designer
they have live there a long time
they have their friend there
they have their local store to shop in their church and chapel
all this would be hard to replace in the new area where the center of town with plenty of bus
in the new outlying area to which they would have to move there be fewer bus run infrequently
and even though i imagine none of us would think much of sunderland on a saturday night a center be still a center for convenience for liveliness
many of them own their own cottage and could do with them what they like and arrange them to their taste
they be no long crowd
but after all this the striking thing be that housing build with ostensibly no attention to personal taste and desire throw up to cover the most land and make the most money use the material and technology of the s be consider superior by many of those live in them to the new flat design by the best planning authority use good architect
imagine what the cooking bath and toileting facility of such cottage be
the wc s be typically out in the backyard and the cottage have no greek isle or the italian hill town it be ordinary workingclass uninspired housing and yet the resident prefer it
could they have be provide with something that give them the advantage of the old house they have and which eliminate the very striking disadvantage very likely
but we have some evidence that a taste for a proper modern style on the part of the architect make a close replacement impossible
the local authority be commit to flat
in discuss with the relevant officer the reason for choose flat as a form of development in sunderland the interviewer be tell that highrise block be essential to the skyline of the town
seven block of storied flat be build at gilley law on the outskirts of the town as a result of a aesthetic choice

e pluribus plures
question of race ethnicity and religion have be a perennial source of conflict in american education
the school have often attract the zealous attention of those who wish to influence the future as well as those who wish to change the way we view the past
in our history the school have be not only a institution in which to teach young people skill and knowledge but a arena where interest group fight to preserve their value or to revise the judgment of history or to bring about fundamental social change
in the nineteenth century protestant and catholic battle over which version of the bible should be use in school or whether the bible should be use at all
in recent decade bitter racial disputesprovoked by policy of racial segregation and discriminationhave generate turmoil in the street and in the school
the secularization of the school during the past century have prompt attack on the curriculum and textbook and library book by fundamentalist christian who object to whatever science
give the diversity of american society it have be impossible to insulate the school from pressure that result from difference and tension among group
when people differ about basic value soon or later those disagreement turn up in battle about how school be organize or what the school should teach
sometimes these battle remove a terrible injustice like racial segregation
sometimes however interest group politicize the curriculum and attempt to impose their view on teacher school official and textbook publisher
across the country even now interest group be pressure local school board to remove myth and fable and other imaginative literature from child s reader and to inject the teaching of creationism in biology
when group cross the line into extremism advance their own agenda without regard to reason or to others they threaten public education itself make it difficult to teach any issue honestly and make the entire curriculum vulnerable to political campaign
for many year the public school attempt to neutralize controversy over race religion or hope that the school could remain outside politics this be of course a vain hope since the school be pursue policy base on race religion and ethnicity
nonetheless such divisive question be usually exclude from the curriculum
the textbook minimize problem among group and teach a sanitized version of history
race religion and ethnicity be present as minor element in the american saga slavery be treat as a episode immigration as a sidebar and woman be largely absent
the textbook concentrate on president war national politics and issue of state
a occasional great black or great woman receive mention but the main narrative pay little attention to minority group and woman
with the ethnic revival of the os this approach to the teaching of history come under fire because the history of national leadersvirtually all of whom be white anglosaxon and maleignored the place in american history of those who be none of the above
the traditional history american society which presume that everyone in the american melting pot would eventually lose or abandon those ethnic characteristic that distinguish them from mainstream american
the ethnic revival demonstrate that many group do not want to be assimilate or melt
ethnic study program pop up on campus to teach not only that black be beautiful but also that every other variety of ethnicity be beautiful as well everyone who have root begin to look for them so that they too could recover that ancestral part of themselves that have not be homogenize
as ethnicity become a accepted subject for study in the late os textbook be assail for their failure to portray black accurately within a few year the textbook in wide use be carefully screen to eliminate bias against minority group and woman
at the same time new scholarship about the history of woman black and various ethnic minority find its way into the textbook
at first the multicultural content be awkwardly incorporate as little box on the side social historian like stephan thernstrom mary beth norton gary nash winthrop jordan and leon litwack themselves write textbook and the main narrative itself begin to reflect a broadened historical understanding of race ethnicity and class in the american past
consequently today s history textbook routinely incorporate the experience of woman black american indian and various immigrant group
although most high school textbook be deeply unsatisfactory they still largely neglect religion they be too long too encyclopedic too superficial and lack in narrative flow they be far more sensitive to pluralism than their predecessor
for example the late edition of todd and curti s triumph of the american nation the most popular high school history text have significantly increase its coverage of black in america including profile of phillis wheatley the poet james armistead a revolutionary war spy for lafayette benjamin banneker a selftaught scientist and mathematician hiram revel the first black to serve in the congress lynching and racism
even better as a textbook treatment be jordan and litwack s the united state which skillfully synthesize the historical experience of black indian immigrant woman and other group into the mainstream of american social and political history
the late generation of textbook bluntly acknowledge the racism of the past describe the struggle for equality by racial minority while identify individual who achieve success as political leader doctor lawyer scholar entrepreneur teacher and scientist
as a result of the political and social change of recent decade cultural pluralism be now generally recognize as a organizing principle of this society
in contrast to the idea of the melting pot which promise to erase ethnic and group difference child now learn that variety be the spice of life
they learn that america have provide a haven for many different group and have allow them to maintain their cultural heritage or to assimilate oras be often the caseto do both the choice be theirs not the state s norm of a free society that difference among group be a national resource rather than a problem to be solve
indeed the unique feature of the united state be that its common culture have be form by the interaction of its subsidiary culture
it be a culture that have be influence over time by immigrant american indian african slave and free and by their descendant
american music art literature language food clothing sport holiday and custom all show the effect of the commingling of diverse culture in one nation
paradoxical though it may seem the united state have a common culture that be multicultural
our school and our institution of high learning have in recent year begin to embrace what catherine xxr stimpson of rutgers university have call cultural democracy a recognition that we must listen to a diversity of voice in order to understand our culture past and present
this understanding of the pluralistic nature of american culture have take a long and have lead to major revision in what child be teach and what they read in school
the new history isindeed must bea wartsandall history it demand a unflinching examination of racism and discrimination in our history
make these change be difficult raise temper and ignite controversy but give a more interesting and accurate account of american history
accomplish these change be valuable because there be also a useful lesson for the rest of the world in america s relatively successful experience as a pluralistic society
throughout human history the clash of different culture race ethnic group and religion have often be the cause of bitter hatred civil conflict and international war
the ethnic tension that now be tear apart lebanon sri lanka kashmir and various republic of the soviet union remind us of the cost of unfettered group rivalry
thus it be a matter of more than domestic importance that we closely examine and try to understand that part of our national history in which different group compete together in relative peace and even achieve a sense of common nationhood
alas these painstaking effort to expand the understanding of american culture into a rich and more varied tapestry have take a new turn and not for the better
almost any idea carry to its extreme can be make pernicious and this be what be happen now to multiculturalism
today pluralistic multiculturalism must contend with a new particularistic multiculturalism
the pluralist seek a rich common culture the particularist insist that no common culture be possible or desirable
the new particularism be enter the curriculum in a number of school system across the country
advocate of particularism propose a ethnocentric curriculum to raise the selfesteem and academic achievement of child from racial and ethnic minority background
without any evidence they claim that child from minority background will do well in school only if they be immerse in a positive prideful version of their ancestral culture
if child be of for example fredonian ancestry they must hear that fredonians be
if they learn about great fredonians and if their study use fredonian example and fredonian concept they will do well in school
if they do not they will have low selfesteem and will do badly
at first glance this appear akin to the celebratory activity associate with black history month or woman s history month when schoolchild learn about the achievement of black and woman
but the point of those celebration be to demonstrate that neither race nor gender be a obstacle to high achievement
they teach all child that everyone regardless of their race religion gender ethnicity or family origin can achieve selffulfillment honor and dignity in society if they aim high and work hard
by contrast the particularistic version of multiculturalism be unabashedly filiopietistic and deterministic
it teach child that their identity be determine by their cultural gene
that something in their blood or their race memory or their cultural dna define who they be and what they may achieve
that the culture even though they be born here
that american culture be eurocentric and therefore hostile to anyone whose ancestor be not european
perhaps the most invidious implication of particularism be that racial and ethnic minority be not and should not try to be part of american culture it imply that american culture belong only to those who be white and european it imply that those who be neither white nor european be alienate from american culture by virtue of their race or ethnicity it imply that the only culture they do belong to or can ever belong to be the culture of their ancestor even if their family have live in this country for generation
the war on socalled eurocentrism be intend to foster selfesteem among those who be not of european descent
but how in fact be selfesteem develop how be the sense of one s own possibility one s potential choice develop certainly the school curriculum play a relatively small role as compare to the influence of family community that curriculum influence what child think of themselves it should encourage child of all racial and ethnic group to believe that they be part of this society and that they should develop their talent and mind to the full
it be enormously inspiring for example to learn about man and woman from diverse background who overcome poverty discrimination physical handicap and other obstacle to achieve success in a variety of field
behind every such biography of accomplishment be a story of heroism perseverance and selfdiscipline
learn these story will encourage a healthy spirit of pluralism of mutual respect and of selfrespect among child of different background
the child of american society today will live their life in a racially and culturally diverse nation and their education should prepare them to do so
the pluralist approach to multiculturalism promote a broad interpretation of the common american culture and seek due recognition for the way that the nation s many racial ethnic and cultural group have transform the national culture
the pluralist say all of us the us be us and we remake it in every generation
but particularist have no interest in extend or revise american culture indeed they deny that a common culture exist
particularist reject any accommodation among group any interaction that blur the distinct line between them
the brand of history that they espouse be one in which everyone be either a descendant of victim or oppressor
by do so ancient hatred be fan and recreate in each new generation
particularism have its intellectual root in the ideology of ethnic separatism and in the black nationalist movement
in the particularist analysis the nation have five culture african american asian american european american latinohispanic and native american
the huge cultural historical religious and linguistic difference within these category be ignore as be the considerable intermarriage among these group as be the linkage like gender class sexual orientation and religion that cut across these five group
no serious scholar would the same culture or that all asian be part of the same culture or that all people of latinamerican descent be of the same culture or that all people of african descent be of the same culture
any categorization this broad be essentially meaningless and useless
several district including detroit atlanta and washington dc be develop a afrocentric curriculum
afrocentricity have be describe in a book of the same name by molefi kete asante of temple university
the afrocentric curriculum put africa at the center of the student s universe
african american must move away from a sic eurocentric framework because it be difficult to create freely when you use someone else s motif style image and perspective
because they be not african white teacher can not inspire in our child the vision necessary for them to overcome limitation
asante recommend that african american choose a african name as he do reject european dress embrace african religion not islam or he scorn the idea of universality as a form of eurocentric arrogance

there would seem to be a incipient conflict between those who want to introduce reallife application of mathematics and those who want to teach the mathematical system use by ancient culture

but any widespread movement to replace modern mathematics with ancient ethnic mathematics run the risk of disaster in a field that be struggle to update existing curriculum
if as seem likely ancient mathematics be teach mainly to minority child the gap between them and middleclass white child be apt to grow
it be worth note that child in korea who score high in mathematics on international assessment do not study ancient korean mathematics
particularism be akin to cultural lysenkoism cultural trait be inherit
it imply a dubious dangerous form of cultural predestination
child be teach that if their ancestor could do it so could they
but what happen if a child be from a cultural group that make no significant contribution to science or mathematics do this mean that child from that background must find a culturally appropriate field in which to strive how do a teacher find the right cultural button for child of mixed heritage and how in the world will teacher use this technique when the child in their class be draw from many different culture as be usually the case by the time that every culture get its due there may be no time leave to teach the subject itself
this explosion of filiopietism which we should remember come from adult not from student be reminiscent of the period some year ago when the russian claim that they have invent everything first as we now know this nationalistic braggadocio do little for their selfesteem and nothing for on how little social prestige have be accord in this country to immigrant from greece and italy even though the achievement of their ancestor be at the heart of the classical curriculum
filiopietism and ethnic boosterism lead to all sort of odd practice
in new york state for example the curriculum guide for eleventh grade american history list three foundation for the united state constitution as follow preformatted table
those who be unfamiliar with the haudenosaunee political system might wonder what it be particularly since educational authority in new york state rank it as equal in importance to the european enlightenment and suggest that it strongly influence not only colonial leader but the leading intellectual of europe
the haudenosaunee political system be the iroquois confederation of five later six indian tribe in upper new york state which conduct war and civil affair through a council of chief each with one vote
in benjamin franklin propose a colonial union at a conference in albany his plan say to be inspire colony
today indian activist believe that the iroquois confederation be the model for the american constitution and the new york state department of education have decide that they be right
that no other state see fit to give the american indian equal billing with the european enlightenment may be owing to the fact that the indian in new york state number less than forty thousand have be more politically effective than elsewhere or that other state have not yet learn about this method of reduce eurocentrism in their american history class
particularism can easily be carry to extreme
student of fredonian descent must hear that their ancestor be seminal in the development of all human civilization and that without the fredonian contribution we would all be live in cave or tree bereft of art technology and culture
to explain why fredonians today be in modest circumstance give their historic eminence child be teach that somewhere long ago another culture steal the fredonians achievement palm them off as their own encounter this argument almost twenty year ago when i be a graduate student
i share a small office with a young professor and i listen as she patiently explain to a student why she have give him a d on a term paper
in his paper he argue that the arab have steal mathematics from the nubian in the desert long ago i forget in which century this theft allegedly occur
she try to explain to him about the necessity of historical evidence
he be unconvinced since he believe that he have uncover a great truth that be beyond proof
the part i could nt understand be how anyone could lose knowledge by share it
after all culture be constantly influence one another exchange idea and art and technology and the exchange usually be enriching not deplete
today there be a number of book and article advancing controversial theory about the origin of civilization
a important work the african origin of civilization myth or reality by senegalese scholar black civilization that all race be descend from the black race and that the achievement of western civilization originate in egypt
the view of diop and other africanist have be condense into a everyman s paperback title what they never tell you in history class by indus khamit kush
this latter book claim that moses jesus buddha mohammed and vishnu be african that the first indian chinese hebrew greek roman britain and american be african and that the first mathematician scientist astronomer and physician be african
a debate currently rage among some classicist be whether the greek steal the philosophy art and religion of the ancient egyptian and whether the ancient egyptian be black african
george g m james s stolen legacy insist that the greek steal the legacy of the african continent and call it their own
james argue that the civilization of greece the vaunted foundation of european culture owe everything it know and do to its african not in greece and rome but in egypt and ultimately in black africa
similar speculation be fuel by the publication in of martin bernal s black athena the afroasiatic root of classical civilization volume the fabrication of ancient greece although the controversy predate bernal s book
in a fascinating foray into the politics of knowledge bernal attribute the preference of western european scholar for greece over egypt as the fount of knowledge to nearly two century of racism and europocentrism but he be uncertain about the color of the ancient egyptian
however a review of bernal s book last year in the village voice begin what color be the ancient egyptian black than mubarak baby
the same article claim that white racist archeologist chisel the nose off ancient egyptian statue so that future generation would not see the typically african facial characteristic
the debate reach the page of the biblical archeology review last year in a article title be the ancient egyptian black yurco argue that some egyptian ruler be black others be not and that the ancient egyptian do not think in these term
the issue write yurco be a chimera cultural baggage from our own society that can only be impose artificially on ancient egyptian society
""
most educationist be not even aware of the debate about whether the ancient egyptian be black or white but they be very sensitive to charge that the school curriculum be eurocentric and they be eager to rid the school of the taint of eurocentrism
it be hardly surprising that america s school would recognize strong cultural tie with europe since our nation s political religious educational and economic institution be create chiefly by people of european descent our government be shape by european idea and nearly percent of the people who live here be of european descent
the particularist treat all of this history as a racist bias toward europe rather than as the matteroffact consequence of european immigration
even american education if it be center on anything be center on itself
it be americentric
most american student today have never study any world history they know very little about europe and even less about the rest of the world
their mind be root solidly in the here and now
when the berlin wall be open in the fall of journalist discover that most american teenager have no idea what it be nor why its opening be such a big deal
nonetheless eurocentrism provide a better target than americentrism
in school district where most child be black and hispanic there have be a growing tendency to embrace particularism rather than pluralism
many of the child in these district perform poorly in academic class and leave school without graduate
they would fare better in school if they have welleducated and wellpaid teacher small class good material encouragement at home and school summer academic program protection from the drug and crime that ravage their neighborhood and high and timeconsuming remedy that must also engage the large society beyond the school
the lure of particularism be that it offer a less complicated anodyne one in which the child s academic deficiency may be addressedor set asideby inflate their racial pride
the danger of this remedy be that it will detract attention from the real need of school and the real interest of child while simultaneously arouse distorted race pride in child of all race increase racial antagonism and produce fresh recruit for white and black racist group
the particularist critique gain a major forum in new york in with the release of a report call a curriculum of inclusion produce by a task force create by the state commissioner of education thomas sobol
in soon after his appointment sobol appoint a task force on minority to review the state s curriculum for instance of bias
he do this not because there have be complaint about bias in the curriculum but becauseas a newly appoint state commissioner whose previous job have scarsdalehe want to demonstrate his sensitivity to minority concern
the sobol task force be compose of representative of african american hispanic asian american and american indian group
the task force engage four consultant one from each of the aforementioned racial or ethnic minority to review nearly one hundred teacher guide prepare by the state
these guide define the state s curriculum usually as a list of fact and concept to be teach along with model activity
the primary focus of the consultant not surprisingly be the history and social study curriculum
as it happen the history curriculum have be extensively revise in to make it multicultural in both american and world history
in the revision the time give to western europe be reduce to onequarter of one year as part of a twoyear global study sequence in which equal time be allot to seven major world region including africa and latin america
as a result of the revision in american and world history historysocial study curriculum in the country
dozen of social study teacher and consultant have participate and the final draft be review by such historian as eric foner of columbia university the late hazel hertzberg of teacher college columbia university and christopher lasch of the university of rochester
the curriculum be overload with fact almost to the point of numb student with detail and trivia but it be not insensitive to ethnicity in american history or unduly devoted to european history
but the sobol task force decide that this curriculum be biased and eurocentric
the first sentence of the task force report summarize its major thesis african american asian american puerto ricans latino and native american have all be the victim of a intellectual and educational oppression that have characterize the culture and institution of the united state and the european american world for century
the task force report be remarkable in that it vigorously denounce bias without identify a single instance of bias in the curricular guide under review
instead the every difference of opinion or interpretation as a example of racial bias
the africanamerican consultant for example excoriate the curriculum for its white anglosaxon wasp value system and norm its deepseated pathology of racial hatred and its white nationalism he decry as bias the fact that child study egypt as part of the middle east instead of as part of africa
perhaps egypt should be study as part of the african unit geographically it be locate on the african continent but place it in one region rather than the others be not what most people think of as racism or bias
the latino consultant criticize the use of the term spanishamerican war instead of spanishcubanamerican war
the native american consultant complain that tribal language be classify as foreign language
""
the report be consistently europhobic
it repeatedly express negative judgment on european american and on everything western and european
all people with a white skin be refer to say the report be uniquely responsible for produce aggressive individual who be ready to discover invade and conquer foreign land because of greed racism and national egoism

the new york task force proposal be not merely about the reconstruction of what be teach
it go a step far to suggest that the history curriculum may be use to ensure that child from native american puerto ricanlatino asian american and african american culture will have high selfesteem and selfrespect while child from european culture will have a less arrogant perspective of be part of
in february commissioner sobol ask the new york board of regents to endorse a sweeping revision of the history curriculum to make it more multicultural
his recommendation be couch in measured tone not in the angry rhetoric of his task force
the board support his request unanimously
it remain to be see whether new york pursue the particularist path mark out by the commissioner s advisory group or find its way to the concept of pluralism within a democratic tradition
the rising tide of particularism encourage the politicization of all curriculum in the school
if education bureaucrat bend to the political and ideological wind as be their wont we can anticipate a generation of struggle over the content of the curriculum in mathematics science literature and history
demand for culturally relevant study for ethnostudies of all kind will open the classroom to unending battle over whose version be teach who get credit for what and which ethnointerpretation be appropriate
only recently have district begin to resist the demand and some have not yet begin to do so
the spread of particularism throw into question the very idea of american public education
public school exist to teach child the general skill and knowledge that they need to succeed in american society and the specific skill and knowledge that they need in order to function as american citizen
they receive public support because they have a public function
historically the public school be know as common school because they be school for all even if the child of all the people do not attend them
over the year the court have find that it be unconstitutional to teach religion in the common school or to separate child on the basis of their race in the common school
in their curriculum their hiring practice and their general philosophy the public school must not discriminate against or give preference to any racial or ethnic group
yet they be permit to accommodate cultural diversity by for example serve food that be culturally appropriate or community
however they should not be expect to teach child to view the world through a ethnocentric perspective that reject or ignore the common culture
for generation those group that want to inculcate their religion or their ethnic heritage have institute private schoolsafter school on weekend or on a fulltime basis
there child learn with others of the same groupgreeks pole german japanese chinese jew lutherans catholic and so on be teach by people from the same group
valuable as this exclusive experience have be for those who choose it this have not be the role of public education
one of the primary purpose of public education have be to create a national community a definition of citizenship and culture that be both expansive and inclusive
the curriculum in public school must be base on whatever knowledge and practice have be determine to be best by toolong teacher and scholarswho be competent to make these judgment
professional society must be prepare to defend the integrity of their discipline to examine dispute over curriculum and to render judgment in order to help school official fend off improper political pressure
where genuine controversy exist they should be teach and debate in the classroom
be egypt a black civilization why not raise the question read the argument of the different side in the debate show slide of egyptian pharoah and queen read book about life in ancient egypt invite guest scholar from the local university and visit museum with egyptian collection if scholar disagree student should know it
one great advantage of this approach be that student will see that history be a lively study that textbook be fallible that historian disagree that the writing of history be influence by the historian s politics and ideology that history be write by people who make choice among alternative fact and interpretation and that history change as new fact be uncover and new interpretation win adherent
they will also learn that culture and civilization constantly interact exchange idea and influence one another a myth
another advantage be that student might once again study ancient history which have all but disappear from the curriculum of american school
california recently introduce a required sixth grade course in ancient civilization but ancient history be otherwise terra incognita in american education
""
the multicultural controversy may do wonder for the study of history which have be neglect for year in american school
at this time only half of our high school graduate ever study any world history
any serious attempt to broaden student knowledge of africa europe asia and latin america will require at least two and possibly three year of world history a requirement thus far only in california
american history too will need more time than the oneyear highschool survey course
those of us who have insist for year on the importance of history in the curriculum may not be ready to assent to its redemptive power but hope that our new ally will ultimately join a constructive dialogue that strengthen the controversy arise educator must adhere to the principle of e pluribus unum
that is they must maintain a balance between the demand of the one nation of which we be common citizens the many varied history of the american people
it be not necessary to denigrate either the one or the many
pluralism be a positive value but it be also important that we preserve a sense of a american communitya society and a culture to which we all belong
if there be no overall community with a agreedupon vision of liberty and justice if all we have be a collection of racial and ethnic culture lack any common bond then we have no mean to mobilize public opinion on behalf of people who be not member of our particular group
we have for example no reason to support public education
if there be no large community then each group will want to teach its own child in its own way and public education cease to exist
history should not be pride
no race have a monopoly on virtue
if anything a study of history should inspire humility rather than pride
people of every racial group have commit terrible crime often against others of the same group
whether one look at the history of europe or africa or latin america or asia every continent offer example of inhumanity
slavery have exist in civilization around the world for century
example of genocide can be find around the world throughout history from ancient time right through to our own day
government and culture sometimes by edict sometimes simply follow tradition have practice not only slavery but human sacrifice infanticide cliterodectomy and mass murder
if we teach child this they might recognize how absurd both racial hatred and racial chauvinism be
what must be preserve in the study of history be the spirit of inquiry the readiness to open new question and to pursue new understanding
history at its best be a search for truth
the controversy rather than through imposition of fixed belief and immutable fact
perhaps the most dangerous aspect of school history be its tendency to become official history a sanctified version of the truth teach by the state to captive audience and embed in beautiful massmarket textbook as holy writ
when official history be write by committee respond to political pressure rather than by scholar synthesize the best available research then the error of the past be replace by the politically fashionable error of the present
it may be difficult to teach child that history be both important and uncertain and that even the best historian never have all the piece of the jigsaw puzzle but it be necessary to do so
if state education department permit the revision of their history course and textbook to become a exercise in power politics then the entire process of statelevel curriculummaking become suspect as do public education itself
the question of selfesteem be extraordinarily complex and it go well beyond the content of the curriculum
most of what we variety of life experience not only in school
nonetheless it have be important for blacks for other racial groupsto learn about the history of slavery and of the civil right movement it have be important for black to know that their ancestor actively resist enslavement and actively pursue equality and it have be important for black and others to learn about black man and woman who fight courageously against racism and who provide model of courage persistence and intellect
these be instance where the content of the curriculum reflect sound scholarship and at the same time probably lessen racial prejudice and provide inspiration for those who be descendant of slave
but know about the travail and triumph of one s forebear do not necessarily translate into either selfesteem or personal accomplishment
for most child selfesteem selfconfidence that grow out of have reach a goalcomes not from hear about the monument of their ancestor but as a consequence of what they be able to do and accomplish through their own effort
as i reflect on these issue a talented black runner
she say that her model be mikhail baryshnikov
she admire him because he be a magnificent athlete
he be not black he be not female he be not americanborn he be not even a runner
but he inspire her because of the way he train and use his body
when i read this i think how narrowminded it be to believe that people can be inspire only by those who be exactly like them in race and ethnicity
by diane ravitch
diane ravitch adjunct professor of history and education at teacher college columbia university be the author of several book including the troubled crusade american education
