""
principle which be set in absolute term can not be uphold in the presence of a policy where percent of the freshman class be to be select through a process of secondary review where within each secondary review category roughly half the target would be meet by accept those applicant with the high academic index score and where one of the factor for the other half would be contribution to the overall diversity of the class
of course as we might have expect one of these secondary review category remain affirmative action student black hispanic american indian
give all this it be not at all surprising to note that we find the statement the flexible admission target for each group would be set primarily on the basis of recent practice and we therefore anticipate that there will be no drastic fluctuation in the number from each of these group to represent some sort of advance quota by any other name be still quota and we as a faculty by our approval of the report be endorse the continued destruction of any sense of community on the berkeley campus
there have also be remarkably little if any overt public outcry over these policy though by the same token there be little or no evidence of public approval

there be in addition of course a good deal of white guilt around and a welljustified fear of be tag with a racist label if one question policy that have acquire affirmative action status
well if this effort it
that begin to get us into pragmatic matter
it be unfortunate another aspect of our time that one should have to get into pragmatic matter at all when the policy at issue be prima facie unconstitutional

thus much of the justification and defense of berkeley admission policy have be pragmatic in appearance though the reality as will be see have be a good deal less

concerned white black asian hispanic it turn out that only asian be be admit to berkeley in proportion that do not differ significantly from their representation in the pool of academically eligible high school graduate see table above and this have be true for a great many year

in other word asian have be and be be treat fairly with respect to their academic achievement
the problem then be not with them they be be treat just as they always have be it lie instead in the fact that no one else be treat fairly in the chance of white student be admit be reduce by more than percent just by the defect of their whiteness and the chance of hispanic and black be correspondingly increase by percent and percent respectively compare row three and five in table again simply on the basis of their race and ethnicity
this be racism pure and simple and easily reminiscent of the infamous negative quota limit jewish enrollment in many of our most prestigious university which survive well into the s
it be difficult to conceive of ground on which so racially bind a policy could be defend in court
now it have be argue in particular by chancellor heyman and vicechancellor rod park that to quote the former these achievement be not at the expense of quality as some have claim san francisco chronicle january 
another common claim to quote administration official be that everyone admit to insight october

about the only actual datum ever refer to in this context be the fact that the mean scholastic aptitude test sit score of incoming student have be steadily rise
given that for all its fault the sit score be the only objective standin for quality that can be apply to all student it be the only academic experience they share let us look into what have actually be go on see table 
asian and white admit to berkeley in and almost always on academic ground alone have a average sit score of about black and hispanic for the vast majority of whom raceethnicity about for the former note that this be also just about the mean for all white high school senior who take the test for the latter
ten year previously in the corresponding figure be about for asian and white and about for black and hispanic
thus the gap between the two mean have increase by more than point in the past decade from to lead to a situation of minimal overlap percent or less between the two distribution
this current difference be equivalent to a fouryear gap in academic preparationachievement in other word the difference between a college junior and a high school junior
this enormous and growing disparity tell us that on the average minority group student be not go to be competitive with asian and white at berkeley
and whatever the fault of the sit or any standardized achievement test truth be see crudely in dropout figure but be much more apparent to those of us who spend much of our time teach undergraduate in relative performance in the same class and in the lack of minority representation in our more demanding course and major
all this be depressing and most unfortunate but nonetheless true as you get more and more selective among asian and white the competitive gap necessarily increase
this be simple statistics and nothing anyone here at berkeley can do short of admit only those asian and white who score below say could change it
this fact have be obscure by avoid any mention of the actual number involve
sometimes this avoidance be blatant as in the information digest of the university of california admission and outreach service where on page we be give in one table the sit score of university of california freshman as a whole as compare to national mean and in but not of course sit data by raceethnicity
indeed to the best of my knowledge raceethnicity sit data for berkeley student have never be publish
what we have get be statement of the type quote above from chancellor heyman and endorse in many place include unfortunately the karabel report the great accomplishment of the overall admission policy have in our view be its capacity to continue the process of diversification of berkeley s student body at the same time it have maintain and even raise the academic level of the freshman class 
there be in fact as just note no positive accomplishment at all
the gap between asianswhites and blackshispanics to repeat have increase
the administration have simply trade off large gain among asian and white large because one be select them from far out along the curve for small one among black and hispanic
their great accomplishment academic level that is the mean sit score of the freshman class while continue the process of diversification of berkeley s student body result from this tradeoff
and the claim blithely ignore the fact that the admission policy have also produce two student population percent and percent respectively of the freshman enrollee whose academic level barely overlap
so while the overall quality that is mean sit score of undergraduate may not have decline the relationship between quality and race or ethnicity have become much more strongly marked and the overall quality have certainly decline relative to where it would be if admission policy be as blind to raceethnicity as they be seven year ago
the problem with the concept of the quality of a performance with respect to reward in a world of limited good ie the number of place at berkeley be fix be that it can not be apply in other than if and only if one be willing and able to perform academically at a level commensurate with the demand of the institution and the overall response of the student body to those demand
therefore once one become at all selective that is once something pass from be a right for example the right to compete for a position in a band play or on a athletic team to a privilege a actual position then qualify have to become to a appreciable extent a performancebased term
no one would suggest to lou campanelli that he should recruit with a eye to increasing diversity on our basketball team
nor would anyone look for racialethnic diversity and balance on our olympic squad
there we choose on the basis of performance
why because presumably we want to do the best that we can do
why should it be any different for our faculty and student body the university of california at berkeley have be three best institution of high learning public or private in this country and probably in the world and be the best mean among other thing be selective and challenging
we do not achieve that eminence by concern ourselves with anything other than direct evidence of achievement
that eminence obviously can not be maintain if race sex ethnicity or any other factor be allow to substitute for achievement
there can not possibly be if we wish to maintain that eminence a performanceindependent right to membership in the university community and to repeat performance whether academic athletic or artistic can not be judge against absolute standard
any such judgment must be make in a comparative context
you get performance by rewarding performance you ensure nonperformance by rewarding nonperformance
intellectual performance be no exception
not to challenge our best student mind and we certainly can nt challenge them if they be not here nor can the strength of our challenge be as great now our society and the world later and to fail in our mission
to remain the best we must do our intellectual best but when we do that best we raise the required level of performance and degree of competition to the point where less qualified less prepared or less motivated student simply become noncompetitive
and unfortunately the level of qualification preparation or motivation be not randomly distribute with respect to race and ethnicity
it would be much more realistic to recognize the accomplishment of the berkeley administration as consist of the alienation of white by not admit them and of minority by admit them into a environment where they will tend to do poorly relative to others of course and therefore come to feel quite rightly cheat
such policy also and this be perhaps the sad result of all devalue the accomplishment of those minority student who be make it on their own without the benefit at least in theory provide some benefit but diversity in current practice here at berkeley be something else again
those potential benefit do not accrue automatically in the presence of increased diversity and there be alltooreal cost as well
but where do we see any attempt even to consider the cost never mind measure them against the potential benefit the cost be obvious and large the benefit if any difficult to perceive and certainly undocumented
we do need to understand better the difference and similarity among culture their strength as well as weakness and to appreciate that there be much we can learn from one another
but we must also be aware that belief and practice where they differ from culture to culture can not in general be neutral that is be equally effective in any particular situation
the academic environment at berkeley be a very particular situation and clearly performance within it be not neutral with respect to race and ethnicity nor obviously though attention be it neutral with respect to individual variation within group
that be the reality
it be of course all to easy to ignore unpalatable reality
unfortunately do so tend to produce even more unpalatable result
the berkeley administration have in its admission policy especially over the past five year or so ignore certain unpalatable reality and give us a even more unpalatable set of result
they have give us a situation where the association between raceethnicity and performance be real obvious and of everincreasing strength
what we be get at berkeley be two community separable on racialethnic ground and increasingly divergent from one another academically socially and in ethos a result desire presumably by no rational soul
it be frankly difficult to imagine policy more deliberately craft or better calculate to exacerbate racial and ethnic tension discourage individual performance among all group and contribute to the decay of a magnificent educational institution
postscript
my early comment be of course incomplete be all too easy to complain it be sometimes a good deal hard to suggest something better
i do nt see that as the case here
it seem to me quite easy to define a range of policy that would be constitutional be see as fair and be more or less compatible with the mission of this university
at one end we could have a purely meritocratic system that is we could simply define a set of performance criteria and select in order from those who fulfill them make certain that nothing be add to or subtract from student score because of what they be rather than what they have do
at the other we could simply admit the top x percent by performance where x be the same for all group of each defined group
it would be difficult to justify representation in number great than those merit by performance when that performance be above average by the same token it would be difficult relevant population here all high school graduate when the performance be below average
in other word the final total for each defined group would be somewhere between the figure in the last two row of table 
i leave unargued the question of whether the whole notion of defined group in this context be relevant moral fair or productive

report issue by the carnegie foundation for the advancement of teach be a mean by which the educational establishment build public support for the policy it favor
its report exhibit highmindedness expose genuine problem and propose solution that require ever great quantity of administration

the erosion of learning and civility
college student spend on the average much less time study than even the gloomy of us have think
the carnegie foundation report the following conclusion from a unpublished study of fulltime student in fouryear college in percent spend less than six hour a week study outside of class and no more than percent spend sixteen or more hour study by percent be spend less than six hour a week study and only percent spend more than percent of fulltime student at fouryear college be spend sixteen or fewer hour on their course work outside of class
since the standard number of class hour be ten to twelve and a half per week twelve to fifteen fiftyminute hour this mean that in more than three quarter of our student be engage in academic work less than twentyeight and a half hour a week even if they never skip a class while almost a third work less than eighteen and a half hour per week
the decline in hour spend study have to be consider against the background fact that student come to college much less well prepare than in the past
the carnegie report contain no data on this matter but it do mention a survey of professor in which twothirds said they be teach undergraduate basic skill they should have learn in school
particular professor at different type of institution be quote as say that student ability even to do simple arithmetic have define that they and so on
in short just when they should be work hard to make up for the deficiency of their past education american student be work fewer hour than ever
and during those hour they study less well than they once do
the quality of student life outside of academic work only add to one s wish that student would spend more time study
the carnegie report be base in part on a survey of college and university president
seventyfive percent of the president of liberal art college say that alcohol abuse be a moderate to major problem on their campus
eightytwo percent of the president of university research and doctorategranting institution say the same
one dean of student estimate that between and percent of the undergraduate at his school a prestigious southern university be alcoholic while another to percent be serious weekend drinker
the grim news about university doubtless pertain to their large undergraduate population rather than to their president complain of sexual harassment on their campus as opposed to percent of college president probably reflect the fact that opportunity and temptation be great within graduate program and for male graduate student who serve as teach assistant in undergraduate course
in any case university be clearly tough place to be and not just for woman
thirtyeight percent of college president believe theft to be a moderate to major problem while the figure for university president be percent
this document place a major emphasis on racial tension though the statistics shocking and depressing as they be do not indicate that race be the greatest problem on campus
twentyeight percent of college president and percent of university president say that racial tension be a moderate to major problem on their campus and percent and percent respectively say that racial intimidationharassment be
however whereas percent of college president and percent of university president cite interracial intercultural relation as a issue of greatest concern substance abuse primarily alcohol as be of greatest concern
all institution together which include twoyear college and comprehensive institution ie those not primarily liberal art rank substance abuse student apathy campus security and crime and inadequate facility ahead of toolong relation as area of concern
the carnegie report be also base on a survey of chief student affair officer
whereas percent of those personnel at liberal art college and percent at university believe that racial tensionshostilities have become a great problem over the past five year percent and percent respectively believe that alcohol abuse have become a great problem over the same period
considering the importance of word within a academic community one sentence in this report be particularly strike on too many campus incivility be a problem and all too frequently word be use not as the key to understanding but as weapon of assault
the author go on to cite disturbing
the carnegie foundation s proposed solution
there be in campus life surprisingly litre analysis of the deterioration report and almost no consideration of its cause
no thought be give to the possibility that drunkenness be a function of excessive leisure time and that racial incident might be promote by drunkenness
racial tension be highlight as a especially severe problem just as if those tension be root in racism pure and simple
then the report leap from these unconnected particulars to a single allembracing solution that is if not unrelated to the problem to be solve at least inadequate to their solution
the carnegie foundation call upon each school administration to form a new compact for community with its student body
the six principle of that compact be elaborate in the six chapter that form the body of this report
those chapter be seriatim a purposeful community wherein it be admit and rarely thereafter remember that a college or university be a place a open community wherein a delicate adjustment be achieve between protect freedom of expression and affirm civility a just community which urge the affirmative action and multicultural education package already so popular among college and university administrator a disciplined community which review the many way in which existing rule be be violate and offer little to rectify matter a caring community which tilt against fraternity and toward more support service for student to be provide by expanded student affair staff and a celebrative community which recommend traditional ceremony and ceremonial tradition
a epilogue follow these six chapter give the gist of what be propose we be convinced that all part of campus life can relate to one another and contribute to a sense of wholeness
it be of special significance we believe that high learning institution continue to use the familiar rhetoric of community to describe campus life
that ideal and rhetoric be the mean propose for achieve it
at least that be what at one level seem to be propose
however it would be a great mistake to dismiss this compact for community as nothing more than a empty exercise in communitarian rhetoric
for the compact once make can be put to some interesting use
the epilogue suggest begin with a campuswide forum to discuss a compact for community proceed to the compact s ratification by the board of trustee and then use it as a framework within which to evaluate policy and to make decision on such matter as the appropriateness of new student organization or the worthiness of existing one
in short while the compact itself will make little difference administrator can use a compact once ratify to justify action that might otherwise be resist by faculty student alumnus and parent
the epilogue ask and could student faculty and ado from inviting speaker or entertainment group to plan course to academic evaluation and even hire personnel yes they could
it behoove us therefore to examine the specific tendency that the carnegie foundation s proposal encourage
civility and academic freedom
chapter a open community address one of the most difficult and most discussed issue on campus today namely the need to combat the decline of civility while not infringe on academic freedom and freedom of speech
on the one hand there be a alarming increase in vulgar and abusive speech direct against other person often employ the most foul language of sexual racial and ethnic disparagement
on the other hand there be attempt by many college and university to curb such speech but in way that censor the expression of view run counter to the prevailing orthodoxy of the civil right establishment feminism and the gay right movement
the carnegie foundation take the position that academic freedom must be uncompromisingly protect but that the latter nevertheless can and should be condemn in the strong possible term
""
as strong feeling be always arouse by violation of substantive value than by violation of procedural value the carnegie foundation deserve credit for support procedural over substantive value in this case
nevertheless there be two problem with the carnegie foundation s recommendation
the first be that it extend the protection of academic freedom to purely abusive speech personal insult obscene language and racial slur even if they be entirely unconnected with any expression of opinion
pure abuse could be subject to institutional sanction even as the expression of idea opinion and theory no matter how offensive some of these may be to particular group be protect

this be a matter of some moment as university and college authority in the past few year often have be guilty of condemn as insensitive or as racist sexist or homophobic speech that at bad take misguided issue with prevailing view and often present entirely plausible criticism of those view

by thomas short
thomas short be associate professor of philosophy at kenyon college gambier oh 
alisdair macintyre entitle a recent book on ethics and political theory whose justice which rationality those question ought to be ask of teach in contemporary philosophy course
course on ethics and contemporary moral problem be popular throughout the country focus on among other thing justice
logic course if not quite so popular be also perennially full of student
whose conception of justice and which conception of rationality do these course teach
we have undertake a study of recent textbook on contemporary moral problem and on logic
we have find that overwhelmingly these book adopt a liberal to leftwing political stance
the ethics book imply that liberal or leftist have the strong argument on topic range from abortion to capital punishment to affirmative action
the logic book suggest that conservative reasoning be routinely fallacious
these finding be disturbing because while for most student one or another of these course be their first exposure to philosophy for many it be their last
at stake therefore generation will understand not only justice and rationality but philosophy itself
will student think of philosophy as a open search for truth wherever it lie or as a process of partisan debunking whose goal be to ratify contemporary ideological preference the case of logic textbook
logic seem like a paradigm of a objective apolitical discipline
despite recent trend in other area there be no such thing as specifically feminist or deconstructionist logic
there be no leftright dispute concerning logical theory
nevertheless many logic textbook reveal a bias against specific thinker and position mostly conservative one
we first begin to suspect that the teaching of logic be not immune from politics when a referee criticize a manuscript by one of us for a logic textbook not only for include too few quotation from nonwestern thinker but also for present as a example of fallacious reasoning the following quotation from m y latsis chief of lenin s secret police the cheka
we be not look for evidence or the first question we ask be to what class do he belong what be his origin upbringing education or profession these question define the fate of the accused
this be the essence of the red terror 
in just two and a half year the cheka condemn to death over fifty thousand people not because of any crime but because of their parentage education or occupation characteristic that be surely accidental to the issue of whether they deserve to die
the referee s defense of the cheka s reasoning shock us and suggest that politics may permeate logic textbook more than we have imagine
the focus of our study of logic textbook be the section most contain on informal fallacy beg the question argument ad hominem appeal to force pity emotion and the like
gerald massey and others have criticize these section for their obsession with taxonomy their lack of theory and their shoddy reasoning
certainly many treatment of fallacy do exhibit them they amount to little more than list of unrelated mistake
here however we want to focus on a different though perhaps relate shortcoming
these section to explain the general kind of fallacy and to offer student exercise give example of supposedly fallacious reasoning
we examine ten of the most commonly used introductory logic textbook contain take together almost fifteen hundred example of fallacious reasoning the book vary widely in their use of example draw from politics
in one book in our sample only percent of the example be in any way political and only percent could be construe as partisan
in another percent be political and percent be partisan
we consider a example partisan if it involve a political position often associate with a definite overall political stance
most political but nonideological example in our study involve fictional or littleknown local politician argue about each other s qualification ethics and other nonideological matter
""
the degree to which the on average percent of the example be nonpolitical and a additional percent be political but nonpartisan percent be partisan
these number be skew slightly by the highly political nature of several book
the median figure be percent percent and percent respectively
typically then about one example in four of fallacious reasoning be in some way partisan
ideological example be thus numerous enough to convey a political agenda if they display a systematic bias
be conservative reasoning fallacious reasoning
the main methodological problem in test for such bias be distinguish liberal from conservative thinker and position which if one be search for a universally applicable test be difficult
fortunately we find relatively few example in the surveyed text hard to categorize
in classify individual speaker we count richard nixon as a conservative
he be criticize in these book for many thing but never for imposing wage and price control issue a executive order authorize affirmative action or be tricky we count him as a liberal even though he be charge with fallacy almost solely because of his support for american involvement in vietnam
these two politician represent the only thinker whose position on the ideological spectrum be at all ambiguous
thus if anything we overstate the extent to which liberal thinker receive any critique at all in certain book
the number tell a discouraging tale
only one text in our sample offer a politically balanced treatment of fallacy
that be the market leader among introductory logic text copi s introduction to logic which offer a fully balanced approach criticize argument for conservative and liberal conclusion equally often
in every other text criticism of argument for conservative position outnumber those for liberal position by at least three to two and on average by three to one
the political orientation of the partisan example vary significantly but no textbook indict liberal more often than conservative
overwhelmingly the book suggest to student that fallacious reasoning be characteristic of conservative in general book in our sample indict conservative or conservative position for logical failing three time as often as they indict liberal or liberal position
it be interesting to compare the frequent criticism of conservative thinker with the treatment accord representative of extremist political position who lie outside the conventional conservativetoliberal spectrum such as hitler stalin other totalitarian and overt racist
rarely be such extremist charge with fallacy
only percent of the partisan example and just percent of the example overall be of extremist reasoning
fully half the book survey have at most one example of this kind no book have more than six
in no text have more than the median proportion of political example do those assail such extreme position comprise more than percent of the ideological example
give the continuing power of totalitarian ideology to shape world politics and the emergence of racist sentiment on campus the lack of criticism of these mode of thought be unfortunate
perhaps those responsible for these text feel it be more important expose the pseudoreasoning of racist and dictator
ungrounded criticism
these number alone however do not tell the whole story
other author have point out how some example of supposedly fallacious reasoning in logic textbook be in fact perfectly legitimate
massey for example have discuss text in which example draw from philosopher be unfairly charge with fallacy
we find that some author also evaluate argument for conservative position unfairly
some putative example of fallacious argument by conservative or for conservative position be ambiguous others be not fallacious at all
often the author seem to forget that in a textbook on logic the point at issue be not the substance of the speaker s position but the quality of his reasoning
many example of these fault be contain in howard kahane s two muchused logic textbook from which the following example be draw
example 
what persuade one person may be fallacious for another because people in different place time or circumstance have different sort of information and theory court system in the united state dispense justice equally to all on the basis of what teacher and textbook tell them may not reason fallaciously but any practicing lawyer who be nt blind who believe this have commit a horrendous error 
kahane s general principle that whether a argument be good or fallacious depend on context be surely correct
but be the example he offer to the point keep in mind that the point at issue be not whether the court system really be always just but whether particular argument for that claim be logical or not
kahane s remark come in the context of his definition of cogent and fallacious argument
have the tenyearold really be persuade by argument it seem unlikely but if so what argument without know how can we judge whether it be fallacious for either the tenyearold or the practicing lawyer a experienced lawyer who believe that the court system never make mistake be naive but have such a person commit a horrendous logical error tell what argument have convince the lawyer in sum kahane s example illustrate his point so poorly that it seem a gratuitous attack on the american legal system

what be fallacious be to apply principle unselectively
a common example be plato s question in the republic should you return a borrowed weapon to its owner even if he or she request it in a fit of rage and plan to use it to commit a murder although we should in general keep our promise it be fallacious to argue from that principle alone to the conclusion that we should return the weapon

on january rushton have read a twentyminute paper at the aaas meet in san francisco during a symposium entitle evolutionary theory economics and political science
in this talk and in several other paper he examine data on some sixty variable report in the group negroids caucasoids and oriental
the data examine include such trait as average brain size performance on standardized test evaluation of personality and temperament social behavior speed of maturation sexual habit and fertility
he reach the conclusion that the data cluster in such a way that the racial group could be order according to average variation in these trait
negroids be on average more fertile fast maturing more sexually active and less accomplish in standardized test than oriental who tend to the opposite in each trait
caucasoids regularly fall between the two other racial group
rushton then hypothesize that the ordering correspond to what be familiar to population biologist as the rk scale of reproductive strategy
at one end of this scale be rstrategies which emphasize high reproductive rate and at the other kstrategies which emphasize high level of parental investment nurturing
the scale be generally use to compare what be often widely disparate species but the human species
the more k the family the great should be the spacing between birth the fewer the number of offspring the low the rate of infant mortality the more stable the family system and the better develop the parental care
the more k the person the long should be the period of gestation the high the birthweight the more delay the onset of sexual activity the old the age at first reproduction the long the life the more psychologically efficient the use of energy the high the intelligence the more social rulefollowing the behavior and the great the altruism
thus diverse organismic characteristic not otherwise relatable be presume to covary along a single dimension
because the race differ on many of the k characteristic rushton hypothesize that oriental be more k selected than caucasoids who in turn be more k selected than negroids
thus he argue the posited racial difference in behavior may belong in a broad evolutionary context than have rk scale of reproductive strategy on to human evolution
base on work by e o wilson and john bonner among others as well as on study of genetic distancing draw from the analysis of dna sequencing by stringer and andrews he suggest that group that be more kselected in their reproduction strategy emerge later in the evolutionary process than group that be less kselected
rushton hypothesize that archaic version of the three population we call race emerge from the ancestral hominid line in the following order negroids about year ago caucasoids about year ago and oriental about year ago
such a ordering rushton argue fit with and explain the way in which the variable he study be find to cluster among human negroids the early to emerge be least kselected caucasoids emerge later be next least kselected and oriental emerging late be the most kselected
of course rushton do not claim to have establish his contentious hypothesis
they may never be them be eventually confirm they would provide a very powerful explanation of why on average the measured trait distribute themselves among racial group as they do
the resulting theory would provide a evolutionary explanation of many gross behavioral trait thus achieve two fundamental goal of any science to provide causal explanation of phenomenon and to unify separate field
these be powerful incentive for theory make and have historically drive the work of the best scientist
the issue of racism
the dilemma rushton s case seem to pose for anyone with a decent regard for both racial justice and free intellectual inquiry be manifold
even assume that rushton have a absolute right to academic freedom many question need to be ask about him his theory and his critic
one may inquire for example whether such seemingly odd speculation can possibly be the product of competent scholarship or whether if so they be morally defensible
so far almost all the criticism have be level on normative and political ground attempt hope to demonstrate here that they be neither and more generally that academic case of what seem to be genuinely racist theorizing be best deal with by subject them to rigorous scientific debate and review rather than through the application of political or legal pressure
i believe that the fact will also show that while the validity of rushton s conjecture be very far from have be demonstrate his work constitute a legitimate exercise by a competent scholar and do not deserve the abusive treatment it have receive
but before we consider rushton s work on scholarly ground we have to confront headon whether it be racist on its face
the essence of racism lie in the belief that people of a certain racial group should be accord less respect or fewer right than be give others solely because of their race
by this clear test nothing rushton say be racist
to begin with rushton go out of his way to emphasize that since there will be great difference among individual in each population group impossible to draw soundly even in principle
here he part company entirely with those theorist who argue that race be the best available predictor of a individual s intelligence or character
rushton be perfectly clear that his be not a theory of individual variation
it must be emphasize that there be enormous variability within each population
since the distribution overlap it be always problematic to generalize from a group average to any particular individual recall that only of the variance be genetic on his hypothesis and that be due to the environment
even the genetic effect be necessarily mediate by neuroendocrine and psychosocial mechanism 
at the level of the individual it must be recognize that almost all will have a mixture of xxr and k characteristic 
it be also crucial that rushton do not claim his hypothesis generate any social legal or political policy
indeed he say nothing about policy or politics at all
if rushton argue that on the basis of his hypothesis black should be discriminate against of racism
but he say no such thing
this bring us to the question of the validity of rushton s thesis and his scholarly competence regarding the validity of the hypothesis the fact be that no one neither rushton nor his critic know for certain whether it be true or not but and this be a crucial point a scholar need not establish the truth of his theory before he have a right to express and disseminate them
the point ought to be obvious for several reason
first of all even truth now universally accepted such as heliocentrism be uncertain and sometimes highly controversial when new
thus if academic freedom be reserve only for the propagation of unquestioned or even likely truth scientific and scholarly inquiry would come to a halt
in fact as everyone with experience in the academy well know scholar work on subject less controversial than race may propagate opinion that be not only obviously untrue but positively ludicrous without have their academic freedom to be of this type he have as much right to express them and as much a claim to civil treatment as do provocative eccentric or merely unorthodox scholar work in other field
the proper intellectual standard to apply in case such as this where the issue be whether academic freedom and civility be due ought not to be be this work absolutely true but rather be this work the product of competent scholarship just as physician and lawyer be properly censure or even deprive of their professional status not when wrong but only when clearly inept so too censure of rushton would be merit only if his theory be the product of incompetent scholarship
moreover the dismissal of a respected and tenured researcher could only be justify upon a showing of failure of competence in many line of his work 
rushton and others have discuss many of the objection to his theory including the following the correlation between many of the variable old and poorly ascertain at least some of the correlation may be explain by environmental factor there be mammalian species that do not fit the projected pattern both human sexual more and achieve fertility be notably variable feature fertility itself be not know to be heritable and the data on dna sequencing upon which rushton rely may be incorrect
naturally rushton believe he have sufficient answer to the objection
whether this be true or not however can not be our concern
that have to be leave to a scientific consensus that will emerge from the research publish in refereed journal
the question rather be whether rushton be honestly try to respond to such objection and be display adequate scholarly competence in do so
in this connection it be only fair to mention that all of rushton s work have be find convincing enough not merely to merit publication in refereed journal but to gain for him those distinction mention above
what be more he have develop his theory and respond to scientific criticism in a manner befit the scholar he be
however controversial or incorrect his idea may turn out to be they be simply not the product of a intellectual incompetent or a racist
despite this rushton s competence continue to be the target of many attack none of them convincing
in the january issue of the toronto star under the subhead race superiority theory pure hokum scientist say reporter lynda hurst challenge rushton s scholarship on the ground that his assumption about the relative dating of the emergence of the race be base on a article reporting dna sequence finding publish in a supposedly popular unscholarly journal science
hurst record a university of western ontario geneticist joseph cummins as say that contrary data would be forthcoming in the january issue of a professional publication the american journal of human genetics
unwary reader might be expect to miss the fact that this data would appear after rushton s talk and well they conflict with the science artide it would have be impossible for rushton to have take them into account
moreover science the official weekly of the aaas be in fact a highly regard and fully referee journal
the implication that data publish in this journal be less reliable than data publish elsewhere be false
some commentator have brand rushton a incompetent because many of the scientist whose data he use disagree with his interpretation of their work but scientist who gather data be not the final arbitrator on the interpretation of those data
rushton take his data as he find it in the literature
copernicus who do not make his own observation do the same when he take his data from his ancient predecessor ptolemy which he then use to overturn ptolemy s geocentric theory of the solar system
rushton be simply in disagreement with many of his datagathering scientific colleague and such disagreement be not a sign of intellectual failure
write in mill put the case for liberty
we can never be sure the opinion we be endeavor to stifle be a false opinion and if we be sure stifle it would be a evil still those who desire to suppress it of course deny its truth but they be not infallible
they have no authority to decide the question for all mankind to refuse a hearing to a opinion because they be sure it be false be to assume that their certainty be the same as absolute certainty
all silencing of discussion be a assumption of infallibility

by fred baumann
fred baumann be associate professor of political science at kenyon college gambier oh 
just a few week ago at my own college at a meeting on the curriculum a colleague of mine in anthropology remark that whatever else we may prescribe in a curriculum for the college he would argue for one requirement that our student come to understand a culture other than their own
this earnest man have be quite far from appreciate the irony of his proposal for these child the child of the american regime there be nothing so alien and unfamiliar as the doctrine of natural right that shape the understanding of the american founder
most of them have be raise in family that have identify themselves as christian or jewish and yet their conviction be quite at odds with the logic of that monotheism in which they have be raise
not too long ago i see a commentary on that story in the first book of king when elijah have lodge himself on mount horeb and he be instruct by god to journey to damascus point out that this story have be think to date from the first half of the ninth century bc and it show just how early the jew have absorb the notion of monotheism
the god who could order a local prophet to cross the border install a new king or cashier a old one be not one of those local god so familiar to antiquity
his authority be not confine to the land of israel his authority be the same in all place his jurisdiction be understand to be universal
and of course the god who be the author of the universal law of physics be also the author of moral law that be not confine to damascus or jersey city
most of our student at the most selective college and university have be raise in church and synagogue and yet they seem quite remote from this rudimentary point which be part of the logic of monotheism
anyone who know college student know that they be grip by the secular religion of cultural relativism absolute truth that there be no moral truth that preserve their truth in all place and time that notion of fight and wrong must always be relative to the country in which they be hold
the student seem quite distant too from the understanding of the nineteenyearold alexander hamilton when he remark on the root fallacy in hobbes namely that hobbes disbelieve in the existence of a intelligent superintending principle who be the governor and will be the final judge of the universe and that god have constitute a eternal and immutable law which be obligatory upon all mankind prior to any human institution whatever which be to say even before the advent of a government
that be not a idle observation it be bind up with the understanding of natural right hold by hamilton and others among the founder
and year later hamilton would draw upon this same understanding as he point out the serious problem of coherence that afflict the argument for engage in a serious study of the bible or theology or the understanding of the american founder would be for most of them a exercise in grasp a understanding quite at odds with what they be pleased to call at this moment their own culture
when we begin with these student at amherst we have often begin in the study of politics by take something near to them something familiar then we try to show how strange it may be
at time we have start for example with professor robert dahl and his account of politics in new haven
professor dahl find a diffusion of power in the politics of his city with different set of people be dominant in make policy say in the domain of education or real estate or public works
a certain political elite command a presence in all of these field but the dominance of this elite be supposed to be offset by the fact that the leader turn out to be the most committed to more than any other citizen the leader be commit to the rule of the game and the convention of democracy
but be those rule or norm like the rule of baseball or chess be they like the rule that establish that we get a base on ball after four pitch wide of the strike zone the rule on ball and strike or the number of man in the lineup be merely convention we could readily change them without do anything of moral significance and that may prompt us to ask just why political rule be good and just why the political elite respect them
after all the political elite may support these rule because they be the rule under which they have be successful
and they may continue to support them only as those rule continue to supply them with far success
there be a notable difference between a willingness to uphold the socalled rule of the game for that reason a willingness to respect the principle both good and true that those rule describe a political regime that be morally superior to a despotism
and yet that be not the understanding of professor dahl
dahl think that the principle of democracy be in the end too nebulous to claim much meaning let alone truth
they be part rather of a creed or a belief
that the most educated people seem to support a democratic regime more fully be explicable to him because education be the source of their indoctrination into these belief
at this point we be often move to ask the student whether they learn in school the pythagorean theorem ie the square of the hypotenuse of a right triangle be equal to the sum of the square of its two adjacent side
and if they do would they be incline later to say that they be indoctrinate in the pythagorean theorem student find that a curious expression
they be more disposed to say that they learn the pythagorean theorem that when they come to understand the premise and the reasoning from which it have be draw
would it be possible then that the american founder understand in the same way the moral truth express in the declaration of independence the truth on which the american republic be found
but my colleague at amherst be quick to insist that no such analogy can be draw that political and moral truth can not rest on the same kind of axiom that underlie the truth of mathematics
in this respect of course they differ radically from plato locke and the american founder they purport to explain
there can be no more dramatic example on this point than the passage alexander hamilton be content to strike off as the opening paragraph for federalist 
the subject of that paper be taxation and in the course of that essay hamilton would not say anything about taxation that could not be say today by bob dole
but any literate observer would be bind to notice something strikingly different in the furnishings of mind hamilton choose to introduce his subject in this way
in disquisition of every kind there be certain primary truth or first principle upon which all subsequent reasoning must depend
they contain a internal evidence which antecedent to all reflection or combination command the assent of the mind
where it produce not this effect it must proceed either from some disorder in the organ of perception or from the influence of some strong interest or passion or prejudice
of this nature be the maxim in geometry that the whole be great than its part that thing equal to the same be equal to one another that two straight line can not enclose a space that all right angle be equal to each other
of the same nature be these other maxim in ethics and politics that there can not be a effect without a cause that the mean ought to be proportion to the end that every power ought to be commensurate with its object that there ought to purpose which be itself incapable of limitation
people tutor in philosophy could see in this passage a mind attentive to the teaching of thomas reid and what have since be call the scottish school
one of the fine character among the founder james wilson be himself a immigrant from scotland and when he take his place as part of the first supreme court he invoke the authority of thomas reid in the first case that actually elicit a set of opinion from the judge
that be chisholm xxv georgia decide in 
wilson would explain in a elegant opinion that there be no case build up as precedent under this new constitution
it become ever more necessary then for the court to speak about the principle of general jurisprudence before it would speak about the principle that mark the peculiar character of the american constitution
wilson take care to remind the audience of the court that the principle of legal judgment be merely a part of the law of reason and the authority of any case at law or any writer on matter legal he would invoke the authority of a original and profound writer in the philosophy of mind
he would appeal to dr reid in his excellent enquiry into the human mind on the principle of common sense speak of the skeptical and illiberal philosophy which under bold but false pretension to liberality prevail in many part of europe before he write
""
in other word the court would ascend to the task of judgment only after it insist in the first instance that it be indeed possible to judge the court would reject that skepticism in philosophy which deny the possibility of know moral truth just as it deny the possibility of know almost anything else
wilson would move from the principle of general jurisprudence to the principle that define the distinct character of the american constitution
but the principle of lawfulness and the canon of reason do the american republic could claim to rest on truth that do not depend for their truth on the opinion dominant in america
as wilson move through this train of reason to produce his conclusion he advance through the force of what he describe as fair and conclusive deduction
 seventeen year later chief justice john marshall would offer a striking example of how a mind tutor in the same way could derive certain constitutional right through deduction
the case be fletcher xxv peck and it be the occasion for strike down a act of the legislature in georgia
the case involve a grant of public land the buying of legislator and a attempt finally to strike at the corruption by rescind the original grant of land to the speculator
marshall and his colleague see in this act of rescind the grant the subverting or undoing of the obligation of a contract
the impaired contract be the contract that convey the land to the current buyer who be the case in this way marshall could have rest his judgment on a specific provision in the constitution the contract clause the clause that forbid the state from impair the obligation of contract
but he choose to argue in a notably different way
he try to show that the wrong engaged in this case could be deduce from the principle on ex post facto law
marshall explain that a ex post facto law be one which render a act punishable in a manner in which it be not punishable when it be commit
but what be mean by punishment many jurist have seek to solve a tricky problem by identify ex post facto law with those retrospective law that impose criminal penalty
but marshall recognize that the problem could not be settle in such a facile way
i will nt review here the subtle and search challenge he raise on this point let us simply say that marshall recognize that socalled civil penalty with large award of damage the seizure of property as emphatic and astound as penalty mete out through the criminal law
and so marshall be move to write
this rescinding act in georgia would have the effect of a ex post facto law
it forfeit the estate of the buyer for a crime not commit by himself but by those from whom he purchase
this can not be effect in the form of a ex post facto law or bill of attainder why then be it allowable in the form of a law annul the original grant 
marshall evidently share the assumption hold by many of the founder that the principle on expost facto law be indeed a principle of law that be not only true but true of necessity
if marshall could show then that the statute in georgia be really a species of ex post facto law he have every reason to be confident that the conclusion he draw about the wrongness of the statute be not merely defensible but compellingly true
his conclusion would flow with the logic of a syllogism
and in that event the wrongness of the statute would not hinge in any way on the question of whether contract or grant or rescind law have be mention in the text of the constitution
marshall draw out the import of this point with a far and novel recognition
he remark that georgia be part of a large empire she be a member of the american union and the union have a constitution that be supreme over its separate part
but as a result of the argument that marshall make in this case he could point out that the rescinding act pass by the legislature of georgia might well be doubt be georgia a single sovereign power
 that is even if georgia have not come under the constitution and the restriction of the contract clause the action of the legislature would still have be wrong
for the legislature have violate a principle that do not depend for its validity on the explicit provision of the constitution union
to put it another way marshall do not rest his judgment on the authority of the constitution
what he seek to show instead be that the contract clause in the constitution derive its authority from a deep principle of law that do not depend for its validity on the text of the constitution
and in make that transition he apparently think he be explain far more decisively why the passage in the constitution deserve to be treat with the solemn authority of a fundamental law
the section in the constitution do not mark off merely a convention or understanding establish in this country a understanding of what we in this particular tribe of american regard as a wrong
but rather marshall amplify the text and in his hand the provision on the obligation of contract be make to alert us to the use of law that be in principle wrong in all place
i have the occasion recently to recall a conversation with a friend who have military service
his student be all seasoned veteran in their forties they have all see military action but they be still twenty year later the people who have be college student in the s and they have absorb much of the secular religion that affect other young people at the time
they be on the whole skeptical of moral truth that hold across culture
they be willing to risk their life for their country but they be notably uncertain about the ground on which their country could claim to have the merit that justified such a risk
they would not claim that the political regime in america be morally superior to that of the soviet union say or vietnam
they would settle for the far more modest claim that our political way of life be at least ours
""
now i do nt deride this prejudice in favor of the thing that be ours
but at a certain point the passion for what be ours can not provide a justification principle of a free regime be the equivalent merely of the convention of baseball then it should be as plausible to change the principle of law as to change the rule on ball and strike or the convention on designated hitter
and yet be we really free in the same way to alter these axiom of the law that people should not be hold blameworthy or responsible for act they be powerless to affect that like case should be treat in like fashion according to the same rule that being who be capable of understanding reason deserve to be rule through the rendering of reason through a regime of consent even the dim of us may suspect that these proposition be not merely conventional
they be not ours because we have choose to adopt them rather we have adopt themwe have make them ours for the sovereign reason that they be compellingly true
marshall shape his argument in a rather elegant way but i would suggest that the man on the the kind of understand that marshall have touch
people continue to care about question of equity and fairness about question of reverse discrimination the burden of taxation the tilt in the court between criminal and victim
people persistently care about these question which involve nothing less than the term of principle on which we live together the term on which we constitute ourselves as a political community
and when people do show their concern for these question i would suggest that they show a awareness of that part of their life that be not merely local a part that touch on something of a more enduring and universal significance
for something local we go to zabar s for the cheesecake but for the condition of justice we be all athenian
section point of view
very often we hear protest against what be call the politicization of liberal education but before we can discuss that issue intelligently we must answer a more fundamental question whether or not all education be intrinsically political
to those myself include who object to use educational curriculum to advance a certain political agenda or who object to indoctrination in the classroom whether it be indoctrination in feminism pacifism leftism conservatism or whatever the response be always the same all education be a type of indoctrination for all education be inherently political
the argument go as follow education fill the student with some set of value either society s value or other value
what value get advanced be a function of what be teach of whether for example we read my shakespeare or your alice walker
educational choice be therefore political act both in deny the promotion of one set of view and in substitute one person s agenda for another s by what we teach and what we do not teach but in any event we always indoctrinate
there be i think three different response to this argument all of which have partisan if not reason on their side
the first accept the political nature of education the second dogmatically deny it
both fail to recognize the awkward consequence their argument entail
the third involve a critical acceptance of the politics inherent in education but still insist on the possibility of a education that transcend its purely political root
the first position try mildly to ask what all the commotion be about
it rather plausibly argue as follow while there may be some knowledge and some principle that be properly transcultural and transhistorical most education grow out of a particular way of life out of a particular culture
how a democratic man raise his child be necessarily different from the way in which aristocratic or oligarchic man raise their child
the education of a person in child will learn by grow up in new jersey
not only be this the way education work we want it that way we want our future adult citizen to know something about and even to respect the principle of our democratic way of life
if we do nt transmit our principle through education we would be do something stupid and suicidal
such be the mild version of the first position which as far as it go seem incontrovertible
the problem be that it be easily and often radicalize with indefensible result
the radical version run as follow yes education be the handmaiden of politics as we have just see
so what in principle be the argument against education in support of the new politics of the advanced professoriate no doubt it be political to teach in class that for example the united state be commit genocide in latin america or that property be theft but all teaching be political as you have mind when school teach the ideal of jeffersonian democracy but object when i say that america be a corrupt society that should be overthrow it be not that i be more political than you it be just that you do nt share my politics
once it be admit that education be not value neutral but rather the supporter of particular belief or a particular way of life it be also admit that all education be political and serve political end
now it be only a question of whose political end
consider for example the following all stance in scholarly research imply a prior commitment to some basic belief system
furthermore at its best contemporary humanistic thinking do not peddle ideology but rather attempt to sensitize us to the presence of ideology in our work and to its capacity to delude us into promote as universal value that in fact belong to one nation one social class one sect thus speak scholarship imply a prior commitment to a basic belief system what exactly be the objection to teacher who peddle ideology have radicalize the mild view that education be ultimately ground in a given set of value the council easily slide into the view that all know be ideologized and finally have nothing to say against indoctrination except that rabid ideologue might not be to their taste
the second response to the claim that all education be political be the answer do nt be silly
if you think that when i teach calculus or chemistry or which way the mississippi river flow or when eisenhower be elect president or who write volpone i be being political then you be just wrong
indeed common sense rebel at the broadness of the brush use by those who see education and indoctrination as necessarily intertwine
that a course in biology or mathematical logic could be political be implausible on its face and this despite or philosophy as if these discipline have their ground in a particular set of political regime
however this position though commonsensical have its limit mostly because it focus entirely on content and not at all on selection
why biology and not eastern herbalism why pick mathematical logic and not the study of the vedas and of course the politics of selection become much clear in the humanities and social science
what be so neutral about pick shakespeare instead of native american oral literature hardheadedness simply do nt respond to the argument at hand we make choice choice reflect value value stem from cultural social and political opinion
ergo teach the time table be a political act
common sense may rebel but be have not yet provide a coherent response
the third and perhaps most satisfying position would respond along these line yes all education do involve a kind of acculturation and acculturation be a kind of politicization in the sense of be and foundation of a particular society
but to equate teaching logic or science or even political theory on the one hand and ideological indoctrination on the others be madness
be there not a difference as even marx observe between try to understand the world and try to change it or to put it differently be there not a difference between a teacher try to possess a student s mind and have a student possess his mind for himself
i think this be where we must begin and i do it with much trepidation
yes education be political in the sense that it grow out of the culture of a people which culture be shape in greatest measure by a nation s political principle
but there must be a way of distinguish between the liberation of the mind through liberal education and the attempt to capture and coerce the mind through indoctrination
if we can nt do that we should give up the defense of liberal education as impossible and try something more useful the proponent of oldfashioned liberal education have long argue that reading text nonpolitically by that i mean look for transtemporal and universal truth or principle be the one good road to wisdom
the argument rest on the fact that some question and some answer transcend the particular political situation in which each person be place
it rest on the view that universal be possible
what for example do shakespeare teach about love or envy or loyalty or art yet the radical politicization of liberal education perforce deny the existence of universal truth universal insight or transtemporal wisdom once you have subtract from the accident of class race gender and political circumstance mr stanley fish of duke university write what be it that you have leave well if you have nothing leave if everything be culture race class and gender bind then there be no possibility of liberal education
you can not be liberate
at best even then you probably only make the switch because of the dictate of class race gender or politics
you can nt have make the choice rationally since that be just a prejudice
of course it be conceivable that people who say that all education be the propagandizing of mere value be try to deceive us for why would they spend their life push their value if they do not think them true but we should refuse to take the low road and accuse them of try to deceive us
we should give them the benefit of the doubt and assume they be only deceive themselves
but more
sometimes the partisan of the politicization of the curriculum admit to the fact that not only be all education political but moreover that all politics be struggle
all politics be a matter of get your way over others
thus feminist reading of literary text be sometimes portray as scholarly breakthrough imaginative and inventive and sometimes candidly portray as vehicle for the elimination in the global fight
or as jonathan culler of cornell once put it we can not have a canon of literary text since the concept support the fundamental misogyny of the reagan administration and would eliminate course in woman s writing
 hey hey ho ho western culture be get to go be equally a curricular slogan and a slogan for struggle in the street
sometimes the argument for curricular change in the direction of open proselytizing be so shabby as to merit giggle as well as tear
when stanford for example say it would far liberate student mind by give them book by contemporary ideologist woman and people of color to cover contemporary issue they do virtually nothing to shake the prejudice of their student or especially their teacher
rather they do everything to ratify opinion current in the wind
that this affirmative action program for already rife contemporary opinion could be describe by columnist ellen goodman as open some people get fooled if they really want to transcend contemporary opinion and liberate the mind they would surely read homer and dante and augustine rather than frantz fanon
but then again homer and dante and augustine might not support the various orthodoxy many in the professoriate would like to see promote
or to put it differently truly to open up your mind you have to read book that disagree with today s unexamined prejudice in such area as equality liberty democracy and right
such be the sin commit under the banner all education be political
understand in those term liberal education be impossible
where however do we begin especially since we have partly admit the truth that education and politics be not unconnected first i think we have to say that on one level acculturation be a necessary and legitimate part of education
many i think would find it sad for indigenous culture to reject their past and refuse to pass their skeptical of the worth of willful cultural suicide
in the same way we should be skeptical of the attempt make in our own midst to denigrate the study of this culture or of western civilization
know thyself to cite a impeccably western authority apply universally to japanese and papuans and nigerian as well as to american
if our student leave school with the most cutting of advanced opinion and do not know the foundation of this civilization and its work in its breadth and depth and detail they have be cheat
that say we must admit that mere acculturation or know our own proper as it be do not rise to the level of liberal education
it be however the firm ground upon which liberal education can later start
what be we liberate from if not in part from the possibly wrong but formative opinion of our parent professor and priest
if student do nt know who plato be or who write king lear we will have no reason to respect their more progressive thought
the vaunted pluralism of american society change this not one whit it seem clearly more necessary for recent asian immigrant to know who martin luther king be than for american black to know the cultural contradiction of cambodian society
acculturation be the way in which we take marginal group and stranger and make them fellow citizen and friend
nonetheless on the high level liberal education have to deny the argument that all education be political
it have to maintain the possibility of the liberation from the political opinion and prejudice of our friend and fellow citizen
liberal education rise and fall on the possibility of transtemporal transhistorical transcultural truth
it live on the prospect that there can be knowledge over opinion
some of those who wish to indoctrinate rather than educate do recognize this
if american capitalism be true or if marxism be true or if any other ism be true and it may be of course then liberal ideology
that would indeed be liberation of a sort
but liberal education have to be forgive if it begin with skepticism of this matter if it say let us read as widely as possible among those who might be the best author and most powerful mind let us learn something about the heaven and the rock and the atom and human nature and human convention
let us have the tool to judge for ourselves the truth of opinion others offer us
there be then two hallmark of a truly liberal education first it concern itself with the greatest of human issue issue such as the nature of love hate know truth loyalty justice god beauty number mean and death
that is it concern itself with object of the mind and heart that can be transpolitical
and second it give us a variety of the strong best and most penetrating argument and view of these topic
it have no hesitation even when they batter and shake our deepest sensibility
to do anything less be to do the opposite of liberation it be to say we professor do not wish to liberate our student mind but only to possess them
or bad that we be afraid to liberate our own mind from the numbing or giddy joy of ideology
