by james applewhite
in a variety of book from philosophy and the mirror of nature to contingency irony and solidarity and a spate of influential article richard rorty have mount a farreaching critique of what might be call our contemporary intellectual pseudodoxia
that term francis bacon s be employ to refer to various notion in the human mind that stand in the way of the advancement of human knowledge
these notion or idol be he say of four kind and they need to be overcome in the furtherance of knowledge idol of the tribe be inherent in human nature seduce us into believe that sensory perception can give us direct knowledge of reality rather than knowledge relative to the standpoint and coloration of the sense and refract through the mind s own desire for coherence and regularity idol of the den reflect the particular and singular disposition of individual perceiver and the fact that their interpretation be dependent upon what be reflect in the cave of their to the symbolic form of human commerce and exchange and their susceptibility to debasement whenever their inherent plurisignificance in philip wheelright s coinage be discount or word be take for thing language confuse with actual entity and idol of the theater which bacon associate with the purely inventive dogma of various philosophical system that sow the seed of error in human mind operate not as lens through which to see the universe as it actually be but as stage play design to produce particular effect on a audience
for our purpose it matter scarcely at all that bacon prescribe as the antidote to these toxin what many intellectual would now describe as but another poison
by insist that human being could regain mastery over the natural world only through the application of the scientific method for gather data classify material conduct experiment interpret result and generalize inductively bacon be merely displace one of the idol of the theater with what rorty would describe as another whose blandishment no long need
what be more remarkable be that despite the foundationalist pretension of bacon s great instauration his diagnosis of modern idolatry carry within itself the clue to what many modern intellectual rorty among them would now accept as effective vaccine for these disorder
to counter the influence of the idol of the tribe bacon recommend a epistemological skepticism toward all that be seemingly mirror by our faculty of perception
to resist the temptation of the idol of the den he counsel suspicion of whatever the mind seize and dwell upon with peculiar satisfaction
as a prosthetic for the idol of the marketplace he urge a new respect for the difference between language and its referent and a new appreciation of the equivocality of word
and finally as a preventive against the idol of the theater he advise the cultivation of a studied disbelief hold that the nostrum of philosophy and particularly that kind of philosophy which confuse itself with the mixture of matter divine and human as heretical religion
""
bacon s prescience in these matter be by no means a sign of rorty s belatedness
it be rather a way of underscore the scope and more importantly the essential significance of rorty s philosophical project
rorty be deeply oppose to put science or reason in the place where religious faith or belief once be and he view all attempt to defend theory in what stanley fish call the strong sense by develop a general model of hermeneutics that would be free of contingency contextual circumstance and interested judgment as beside the point
and yet he be as committed as bacon ever be to challenge the way we currently think about thought or rather the way we think about the relation between thought and experience
he want to delineate what deserve to be call a new model of the constituent of this process and a different not to say more useful way of relate morally and socially
so conceive rorty s project be part of the ongoing revision of american philosophical and cultural pragmatism
as we can now appreciate the project amount to the most important critical and political attempt since john dewey to resituate the tradition of american pragmatism within the broad framework of modern western liberalism
it deserve to be describe as at least a modest instauration to replace bacon s great one because rorty s project assume that this resituating will require a fundamental alteration of the goal of liberal society itself and the creation of a new set of intellectual technique for pursue the mastery it afford
the word resituate be no accident here
in much recent literary criticism no small amount of it influence by the position rorty take so powerfully in consequence of pragmatism pragmatism or neopragmatism as it be sometimes call have come to be associate with cultural current that be think to be postliberal if not antiliberal in some very specific way
it align itself as a kind of writing and nineteenthcentury idealism and twentiethcentury textualism with the postmodernist and poststructuralist repudiation of culture as a expression of individual consciousness weave into pattern of consensus and dissent of conformity and conflict and it prefer to view culture as a intertextual system of sign that can be infinitely redescribe
it have thus position the critical recovery of pragmatist discourse essentially beyond the kind of dispute that use to vex liberal criticism theoretically
the old dispute concerning the relation between the universal and the particular the absolute and the relative the political and the personal the necessary and the contingent the selfcreative and the socially reconstructive the ethical and the artistic be deem by the neopragmatist either false or irrelevant
whichever the case there immediately follow a rejection of the first term in each pair in favor of a embrace of the second and a subsequent assertion that pragmatic thinking be antifoundationalist antiessentialist antiintentionalist and antirepresentational
it be a pragmatism commit ultimately and exclusively to the effectual contingency of value as the local figuringworking out as well as we heterogeneously can of what seem to work better rather than bad
it may therefore be describe in smith s version as the most ideologically unillusioned and politically unmotivated of critical theory or as in the version propose by walter benn michaels and steven knapp in their celebrated essay against theory as no theory at all
rather it be a name for that kind of practice which be critical of all other practice that resort to theory for the sake of try to govern practice from a position mistakenly assume to exist outside of it
rorty s relation to this postmodernist pragmatist revisioning have become increasingly complex
while support and as we shall see in certain way further the ironizing of discourse to which this have lead he have at the same time distance himself from the wholesale critique of democratic individualism or what c b mcpherson call possessive individualism that go along with foucault in nietzsche or heidegger
side with those who accentuate the historicity and relativism of all cultural practice rorty nonetheless insist that some practice like art and ethnography and one would suppose certain kind of investigative journalism be much more humanlybeneficial than others such as theology or let us say advertising
even as he dismiss all talk of history as a evolutionary process he still believe that intellectual and moral progress can be measure by the history of increasingly useful metaphor
insist that conscience as freud teach us be a product of no more than the accident of upbringing he yet write a prose that be recurrently hortatory and determinedly edify
these paradox would be more disconcerting if they be nt manage with such disarming candor and panache
rorty remind me a bit of kenneth burke s injunction to use all there be to use but here there be nothing eclectic about the all
by put his all to selective as well as effective as wallace stevens once note in a helpful distinction be intent on make sure of every foot of the way than like the poet whose attention be always divert because the sense of the certainty of the presence about him be as nothing to the presence themselves
rorty s version of pragmatism be clearly less interested than some of the other new variant in repudiate its tie with the history of western liberalism
he want to recuperate albeit cautiously what may have be gloss in this process of postmodernist revisioning
this have recently entail a change or at least a sharpening of focus in his own thinking about the pragmatic legacy itself at any rate it have lead to a important extension and development of some of his early idea particularly as they bear upon his interest in the culture of democracy
in its rortian postmodernist form pragmatism be premise on the contingency as rorty describe them successively in the first three chapter of his new book of language be large with complexity but rorty be masterful at thread his way through them
pair each term with a major thinker who serve less as a guide rorty have assume this virgilian role for himself than as a kind of benchmark davidson with language freud with self and a combination of isaiah berlin joseph schumpeter michael oakeshott john rawls and in the immediate background john dewey with community rorty proceed to delineate the main element of his proposal for the reconstitution of intellectual method
the contingency of language commit rorty to the idea that truth be no long out there in a reality beyond language but in here so to speak in the relation among our sentence
truth be something we make with metaphor it be not already there wait to be find with word
just as nothing possess a intrinsic nature neither word self nor the world rorty think of this as the residue of the notion that reality be the us no closer to the way thing truly be
it only move us into a more useful figurative or tropological relation with them
in this conception language be a medium neither exactly of representation nor of expression
it be rather a instrument of redescription
davidson let us think of the history of language and thus of culture as darwin teach us to think of the history of a coral reef
old metaphor be constantly die off into literalness and then serve as a platform and foil for new metaphor
to accept this analogy be for rorty to believe that a recognition of the contingency of language be tie inextricably to the dedivinization of the self and the world
this be the point make by intellectual historian like han blumenberg who narrativize these connection by argue that they be the product of a sequence of transformation
where once upon a time we feel a need to worship something which lay beyond the visible world as rorty summarize the story blumenberg tell in the legitimacy of to worship something that lay within the world and thus decide to substitute the love of truth for the love of god
by the end of the eighteenth century however the love of truth be compel to give way to the love of self as human being transfer their worship from the quasi divinity of the world describe by science to the quasi divinity of their own spiritual nature
but by the end of the nineteenth century and the beginning of the twentieth the idealistic or romantic worship of the self be to be displace by the realization variously phrase by nietzsche freud and wittgenstein that we do nt in fact need to worship anything as divine once we recognize that everything our language our conscience our community be a product of time and chance
""
this be a narrative that lend considerable credence to the assumption that the self be linguistically construct and that reality be largely unaffected by the language we attach to it
it also support the with alteration in language than with revolution in belief
as kuhn argue in the copernican revolution we do not decide on the basis of some telescopic observation or on the basis of anything else that the earth be not the center of the universe that macroscopic behavior could be explain on the basis of microstructural motion and that prediction and control should be the principle aim of scientific theorizing
rather after a hundred year of inconclusive muddle the european find themselves speak in a way which take these interlocked thesis for grant
language in this view be more like a set of tool for perform a task than a medium for get something straight
but as rorty point out the creator of new language the inventor of new vocabulary unlike the master of various craft may not know what it be that they want to do before they have create a language with which to do it
thus the problem of adequation still remain but it be now solve or long how to secure agreement between one s language and something that stand beyond it such as fact truth or reality the world offer no criteria for compare alternative metaphor but how to get over one way of talk and acquire the habit of another
this be pragmatism with a vengeance and rorty be nothing if not consistent in practice it
since the key to changing mind be not better argument but alternative vocabulary his chief discursive tactic be to make the position he oppose look bad by show how limited and brittle they be and to cast his own position in the most favorable light by reveal how many different issue it can illumine
either way the oftnoted frustration of rorty s prose frustration it should be remark that have nothing to do with the lucidity of his sentence the deftness of his move or the elegance of his example begin to make sense
his occasional simplification of opposing argument his constant tacking in the face of stretch his agile but also disconcerting transition from one analogy to another his incisive almost aphoristic synopsis of supporting position his constant and always slightly altered redescription of central point all find their justification in a emersonian conviction that deference to the language of one s ancestor or at least to the inherited description of their contingency amount to a kind of mortuary practice what rorty describe in another arresting figure as worship of the corpse of their metaphor
""
this emersonian iconoclasm thinking of rorty no less than of emerson it could as easily be describe as a antinomian intransigence be nowhere more vividly exemplify than in the practice of the socalled strong poet
rorty apply this term more broadly than do harold bloom to the originator of any new word the founder of any new language but like bloom and emerson before him he conceive this figure a little hyperbolically as the vanguard of the species
all strong poet be ironist anything can be make to look good or bad by be redescribe and their renunciation of the attempt to formulate criteria of choice between final vocabulary
they be to be distinguish from the rest of us ironist by their ability to recreate what nietzsche call the all it be into a thus i will it
""
the strong poet be thus the kind of self who refuse to be a copy who be horrify at the thought of be in bloom s wording a replica
the question be whether a self terrorize by the thought of live off the capital of other people creativity be more prepared than any other self to accept the fact of its own contingency
indeed by couch the term of his or her selfinvention in language usually reserve for the deity rorty s strong poet seem in danger of the opposite of hypostatizing its own sense of be rather than provisionalizing it
to put this more directly if the portentous capacity to will oneself and direction to something as benign as a emersonian or better a franklinesque experiment in selfcreation can it not lead in another direction toward a zarathustrean exercise in selfdeification
despite the fact that we be all by now alert to the significance of this kind of terminological instability rorty can be occasionally obtuse about the referential equivocality it imply
to rorty such verbal ambiguity be more often than not the sign of a epistemological playfulness that derive from the conviction that the self and the world have be empty of intrinsic significance have become dedivinized so to speak leave the field to those whose aim be to develop not the one right description but a expanding repertoire of alternative description
here the exemplary text be the first part of derridats the post card entitle envois whose whimsical fantasizing strike rorty as the end product of ironist theorizing
but to the careful reader of some of rorty s own equivocation about heidegger and nabokov such verbal escapade rorty call them certain moral insensibility about the way in which play can become simply frivolous and possibly banal redescription evasive reweaving narcissistic
to rorty such reservation as these almost fail to matter
the importance culture hero possess for us derrida be one of his be more often associate with the name of their book and the style of selfperfection those book represent for us than with how well they live up to their own selfimage
but this beg several question
one be whether there be always consensus about what those selfimage actually consist of
in the celebrated case of heidegger and say paul de man there seem to be a good deal of confusion on the part of their defender and detractor alike as to what it be they mean to represent in the first place
another have to do with whether our caring or not caring about the integrity of our culture hero remain the same no matter what they represent
again it would seem that the de man and heidegger affair all party to all side of the current debate about these figure seem to care about nothing other than the relation between the image of self project by their work and the actual life they lead
not that rorty find all strong poet admirable any more than he believe all redescribers be invincible
if the world and the self have be deprive of their divinity this neither mean that the world and the self have lose their power over us nor that the expert in human redescription will always invent selfimage we will want to emulate
rorty be acutely sensitive to the fact that the world can overcome us that other self can betray and destroy us that our own vulnerability to despair grief and rage can engulf us
but in add that the only remedy to such hazard lie as so many strong poet have attest over the century in our ability to acknowledge contingency pain and otherness for what they be he may be slight the other half of their testimony the invention of the self and the abjection of the self
in other word their realism whether comic or tragic have not stop short of acknowledge that the self in its very desire to achieve autonomy and redefinition be often the author of its own embarrassment the creator of its own pain the parent of its own misery
nor be this insight lose on the figure most central to rorty s discussion of the self
freud s theory of human nature acquire its immense modern authority not simply because it verify the fairly recent discovery that human being be product of the contingency of their upbringing what set it apart from all other contemporary theory equally historicist and positivist be that it also confirm the more traditional and tragic view that in their desire to escape or overcome these contingency human being simultaneously become the muse of their own unmaking
this lacuna in rorty s understanding of freud and by extension in his appreciation of the legacy of strong poet do not deter him from might be call secondary redescribers such as literary and cultural critic
comparers rather than explainers or inventor contextualizers more than evaluator or creator the arnold and trilling and sontags and spivaks of this world be expert in place book in relation to other book
hence their range of acquaintance be more important than their deep reading
by constantly enlarge the sphere of the cultural conversation they help us resist the seduction of any one final vocabulary
it be worth observe that rorty extend the notion of literature to include any works that critic discuss any works that might conceivably have moral relevance might conceivably alter one s sense of what be possible and important
literary criticism thus become regrafted on the branch of what be once call moral philosophy
but in critical term moral philosophy then become to a discouraging extent largely academicized
the critic be no long oblige to determine the literary merit or the moral worth of any work but can content him or herself with encouraging ethical reflection advisor and suggest way in which the tension within this canon may be ease or where necessary sharpen
""
if strong poet like hegel nietzsche heidegger derrida and foucault afford us model of selfperfection of individual salvation rorty find their usefulness in social reconstruction very much more limited
while they be of enormous assistance in free the self for redescription and thus in help liberal society exchange the dream of rationalize for that of poetizing itself they be pretty much useless when it come to politics
their central social task be restrict to further the dedivinization of liberal culture by show how the language of moral responsibility and social purpose be always contingent
but they have little to contribute to the actual restructuring of society
for that we must turn to a entirely different line of thinker to author such as marx mill dewey and habermas who have make the public sphere and not the private the subject of their reflection
interestingly enough rorty no need of conceptual redescription
though he take many of his cue from modern social thinker like michael oakeshott and john rawls philosopher who have retain enlightenment liberalism while drop enlightenment rationalism he write that xxj s mill s suggestion that government devote themselves to optimize the balance between leave people s private life alone and prevent suffering seem to me pretty much the last word
the ideal citizen of this new world of revisionary american liberalism will therefore be a ironist who combine a acceptance of the contingency of all political perspective with a belief that whatever be mean by the good and the true in liberal society will always be a function of free discussion
rorty have read too much of the frankfurt school and marxist theory generally to believe that freedom be ever innocent of ideological coloring
all he ask for or think we need be the standard bourgeois kind of freedom that be possible when the press the judiciary the election and the university be free social high education be common and peace and wealth have make possible the leisure necessary to listen to lots of different people and think about what they say
while such freedom may have nothing more to recommend them than the kind of support history show they have furnish for private agenda of selfrecreation rorty think that they can and do generate distinctive public debate about two issue central to the creation and maintenance of a democratic society
the first be how to balance the private need for individual selffulfillment with the public need to leave people alone to use or abuse such personal opportunity as they will
the second be how the desire democracy typically create for wealth freedom and peace can be adjust to the fact that those desire can not be equally accommodate economically socially and politically
rorty s liberal be thus not without conviction
draw on judith shklar s definition of a liberal as a person who think that cruelty be the bad thing we do he add to this a thing we do
as a liberal rorty account these conviction socially and ethically salutary as a ironist he know that this can not be prove
the liberal be therefore place in the paradoxical situation of have to grant as isaiah berlin once quote joseph schumpeter to say the relative validity of his or her own conviction and yet stand for them unflinchingly
schumpeter conceive of this paradox as the difference between barbarism and civilization
berlin himself be more circumspect
while he be prepare to admit the deep metaphysical need for great ontological certainty he be equally convinced that to allow this need to determine one s life be symptomatic of a equally deep and more dangerous moral and political immaturity

rorty understand this admonition to mean or at any rate to give him license to say that the aim of liberal society should be to cure us of the dependence on metaphysics by which he also mean metaphysical theory altogether
berlin merely say us

such a person be willing to live with the tension of believe with the nietzschean foucauldian line that most of our social ill derive from turn private provisional vocabulary the tradition from mill and dewey to habermas that the social goal of reduce pain and humiliation may be more commanding than any necessity for individual redefinition

in the language of weintentions the bourgeois liberal be simply someone whose special sense of we from the late eighteenth century to the present have be predicate at least partially on what nathaniel hawthorne speak of his own art once describe as a series of attempt and very imperfectly successful one to open a intercourse with the world

introduction property and freedom
although perhaps not terribly informative maurice cranston be nevertheless correct by definition a liberal be a man who believe in liberty at the core of every liberal theory be some case for individual liberty liberal may disagree about the nature of this case but there be little doubt that liberal theory be freedomcentered liberal have characteristically understand private property as complement and safeguard freedom insofar as personal holding define a sphere within which their holder enjoy the protected liberty to act as he may see fit
view from a different perspective however the complementarity of property right and liberty be problematic
in a wellknown essay alan gibbard observe
if a person own a thing his ownership enhance his liberty but it do so at the expense of the liberty of others
ownership of a thing give a person the fight to exclude others from its use and that right though it add to the freedom of the owner gibbard thereby point to a possible tension in the liberal case for private property
once my right to x be establish then i enjoy option with respect to the use or disposition of x that i previously lack
you however be now burden by a correlative obligation to defer to my decision concerning x as l t hobhouse remark the property that confer freedom on the owner may at the same time limit or destroy the freedom of another
 from the perspective of liberty then it would seem that the creation of the property right be at best a wash the apparent implication be that a advocate of freedom will have a difficult time justify property right on the ground that they be freedomenhancing
the very devotion to liberty that define liberalism may it would seem motivate abandonment or substantial qualification of a regime of robustly private property
in this essay we consider in just what way right to freedom relate to a right to property
gibbard and mort s property right to x do indeed restrict millie s liberty with respect to x such restriction be precisely the point of a recognition of right
however we claim this be not a special feature of property right as distinguish from other right nor do it somehow imply that freedom and property be in special conflict
the argument of the first three section of the paper support the judgment that property right be no more problematic within the context of liberal theory than other quintessentially liberal right such as freedom of speech
many theorist have however believe that the justification of title to private property diverge significantly from other strand of liberal justificatory theory
in the fourth section we offer a assessment of why these theorist take property to be different
""
right to freedom
""
hobbesian liberty and morality
in one respect all right indeed all morality limit liberty
we can imagine a liberty that preexists the moral boundary constitute by right including right to property
indeed hobbes have clone the imagine for us in his depiction of the state of nature
the fundamental law of nature he maintain be that naturally every man have a right to everything
 by right he understand simply the liberty to do or to forbear elsewhere hobbes describe this as our blameless liberty of use our own natural power and ability
 each then have a blameless liberty to do anything he must in order to promote his overriding concern namely his selfpreservation
since it be rational for each to act to preserve himself and since each have a blameless liberty to do whatever he must no one can be say to be blameworthy or irrational when his selfpreserving action impose harm on others
it be therefore neither absurd nor reprehensible neither against the dictate of true reason for a man to use all his endeavor to preserve and defend his body and the member thereof from death and reason that all man account to be do justly and with right
""
this condition of absolute premoral liberty lack two important feature of the liberty that obtain within a moralized sociality
first it do not ensure to individual the ability to live as pursuer of value and project
if each may exercise a blameless liberty to encroach on others in whatever way may seem requisite for improve one s survival chance the ability of each to pursue his project and value be gravely impugn
mort s bestlaid plan may and often will come a cropper to millie s conflicting design
life in such circumstance will not often afford to individual the opportunity to devote themselves in coherent fashion to longterm design
rather it will be a thoroughly grim affair memorably characterize by hobbes as solitary poor nasty brutish and short
 conversely general recognition of moral obligation not to encroach on the protected sphere of others ground the possibility of a freedom to pursue those this be a freedom that each agent typically have reason to prize there be a crucial sense in which those liberty consequent on the establishment of moral protection render individual significantly more free than they would be in their absence right so understand do augment freedom
second premoral liberty conflict with individual virtually inescapable conviction that they stand in a unique normative relation to their own action
to see this consider the situation of a hardy soul who despite hobbes s dour imprecation be inclined to give the regime of complete amoral liberty a try
hobbes of course insist that this would be foolhardy but he be a notorious pessimist concerning such matter
other of sunny mien may be more optimistic concerning their prospect in the state of nature
suppose then that mort decline the invitation to enter into a social contract with others
he thereby maintain his primordial liberty to pursue his end in whichsoever way he judge suitable and others possess a like liberty with regard to mort
direct his activity either by sheer force or threat he have no ground for complaint
mort may find himself enslave or imprisoned and yet he must admit that he have no basis for resentment or indignation to be sure he may be angry that they enslave him or surprised that they manage to do so
but what he can not do be claim that he occupy a privileged position visavis his own activity that they have wrongfully fail to respect
rather mort be oblige to acknowledge that they have as much entitlement to control mort s activity as he himself do
where only liberty obtain everything and everyone be fair game
it seem doubtful though that we can think of ourselves in this way
we take ourselves to be intimately relate to our own activity as something intrinsic to who and what we be rather than as some external thing in which both we and others might take a interest
nor do it seem sufficient to conceive of this special relation in purely descriptive but normatively neutral fact that it just so happen that your determination concerning how your arm and leg shall move typically correlate more closely with their subsequently observe motion than do my wish concerning the deportment of your limb
rather we maintain a special authority to direct our own activity a claim against others that all else equal they not undertake to subvert this control
if mort really want to give the hobbesian state of nature a try he not only must be prepare for others continually to frustrate his activity but he also must bring himself to concede that his own effort to determine the course of his activity be morally on a par with the attempt of others to control mott s doings
it be far from clear that this be something that he can simply will to do
to the extent that person be irremediably indisposed to adopt a detached stance toward their own activity they be rationally bar from espouse hobbesian amoralism
""
claim right to freedom
mott s difficulty point us who populate hobbes s state of nature
what can rightfully be describe as the liberal conception of a free person involve not only the bare power of a agent to act according to his own determination but also a claim against others that they not interfere
that is rather than assert a mere liberty to act the liberal person assert a claim right to act as he see fit 
claim right unlike the liberty of the state of nature restrict the freedom of others
if mort be at liberty to theta he be under no duty to refrain from thetaing it be not wrong for him to theta
but if all that mort enjoy be a liberty it be not wrong for millie to interfere with his thetaing
should he however assert a claim right to theta he maintain that millie be under a duty not to interfere
claim right unlike mere liberty attempt to demarcate a region of moral space against which others may not encroach
now acknowledge it she be from one perspective at least a loser from the transaction
to be restrict be all else equal to be render bad off and it be specifically to be bad off with respect to one s liberty
that be the sense in which all claim right be intrinsically libertydiminishing
but of course all else need not be equal
restriction on liberty can render available good other than liberty and thus from the perspective of the individual be judge a good bargain
yet more significantly they can generate a class of liberty unknown in the state of nature morally protected liberty
therefore even from the perspective of liberty alone the acceptance of restriction can be rationally advisable although theory of liberal right differ among themselves in many important way each affirm that some restriction of premoral liberty be warrant
more precisely each maintain that wouldbe right claimant be able to justify those restriction to the individual call on to forbear right to theta be himself better off than he be in the hobbesian state of nature
he retain his liberty to theta and join to it a assurance that others will not obstruct his action
from his perspective the claim right be freedomenhancing
but from millie s perspective mort s claim right be freedomrestricting if mort have a claim right to theta then she must not interfere with his thetaing
why should she accede to this restriction
mott s justificatory task be to provide millie with some good reason for give up her hobbesian liberty to interfere
and of course the traditional liberal answer be that millie too benefit from a moral regime although she lose her liberty to interfere with mort s thetaing she gain claim right of her own which in turn restrict mott s liberty in some area
that is they stand symmetrically with respect to what be gain and what be forgone
if the justificatory engine run smoothly it will turn out that each civil society be justifiable to each from the person s own perspective

property right and other freedom
it be important to stress that the foregoing consideration apply with full generality to all putative claim right not simply those that involve holding in property
to see that that be so consider the right to freedom of speech
it be apparent that what gibbard say about entitlement to property equally apply to freedom of speech if a person have a right to speak as he see fit that will enhance his freedom but it will correspondingly restrict the freedom of others
mott s rightful liberty to utter and publish and promulgate blasphemous thesis entail a absence of liberty on the part of the disapproving cleric to censor mort or cast him in prison as punishment for the offense he cause
that be not to say anything noteworthy about the nature of speech but it be to characterize the logical structure of a right
if right be a normative resource they enhance the opportunity in this regard freedom of speech be no different from any other right it restrict the freedom of others to act
we maintain then that what hold for right in general apply without additional qualification to property right they enhance the freedom of the possesor to act as he see fit
but if so then it would seem that the observation that mort s property right restrict millie s freedom do not indicate something uniquely awkward or exceptional about property right that require a justificatory strategy over and above that which generate other liberal right
if we be correct then those commentator who hold property right to be especially problematic have misconceive their status
because this misconception be widespread however its source merit closer attention

common property and private property
gibbard suggest that property holding may be problematic insofar as they disturb a initial moral order in which everything be open to common use
he write
everyone let can lose a natural fight only by a voluntary act such as agree to give that right up or forfeit it through violate the right of someone else now what be one s natural right with respect to thing for my purpose i shall need only a vague answer to this question i shall suppose that everyone have equal right to the use of all things 
the implication seem to be this if everyone have equal right to the use of all thing then mort s claim of a exclusive right to the use of some particular thing stand in violation of the natural right of everyone else
gibbard s supposition be questionable in several respect
first it be unclear what gibbard mean by a natural right
one thing he might mean be that natural right be justifiable to agent in virtue of their interest or belief or desire but foundational of other conventional or subsidiary right derivative therefrom
so understand however there do not even the vague characterization that gibbard supply
before we can understand which right might be foundational in this sense we need to understand the avenue of justification through which they be elicit and gibbard quite deliberately aim to evade that requirement
second the scope of thing be unclear
presumably the term be mean to exclude agent themselves as well as their action and undetached bodily part and to include tangible entity external to them such as land and chattel
unless some such distinction be implicit the supposition that everyone have equal right to the use of all thing be thoroughly implausible
as be argue in section mort be not likely to accept the suggestion that everyone have equal right to the use of mort s spleen or to decide whether mort will offer a deconstructionist analysis of leviathan at the philosophy department picnic
these be matter concerning which he will take himself to possess some distinctive unequal authority
but once one concede the absence of equal right over person with respect to all else become dubious
if mort believe that he have reason to claim special authority with respect to his own body he be unlikely to accede to a decision procedure in which everyone have a equal say concerning the disposition of the food that mort have forage or raise for the sustenance of the body that be his
similarly a agent who believe himself entitle to press a claim for privileged status with respect to his own action have reason to extend that claim to his use of those external thing requisite for action minimally the ground on which he stand while act
these fact about the tight relation between control thing and one s enablement as a agent be not obscure and their normative thrust seem to be quite different than that which gibbard imply
the egalitarianism that suggest itself be not one of equal right to the use of all thing but rather a equal propriety on the part of each agent to demand unequal title to some thing
third and most serious there
do he intend claim right right with concomitant restriction on the liberty of others or do he have in mind something like a purely hobbesian liberty that carry no restriction the former be thoroughly implausible
locke can assume a initial position of some sort of common ownership because he postulate that god have give the earth to all man in common
absent that theological premise or one of equivalent power there be no basis for posit a moral order of delicately equalize claim right and concomitant restriction
rather the only equality that might be take as antedate any particular system of parcel out morally protected claim be the equality of norestraint that vex hobbes and for which he understand political order to be the solution
in other word in the absence of what for locke be literally a deu ex machina no ground exist for commence with a universal socialism from which all subsequent movement toward other pattern of property in thing originate
the problem for those not encumber or favor get from one relatively inefficient system of ownership to another that be its paretosuperior but rather of demonstrate that where previously there be no restraint all have good reason to accept a system of restraint

consent and the creation of new obligation
if it be implausible to suppose a moral starting point of everyone possess equal fractional claim right to all thing we might consider instead whether gibbard have in mind the sort of negative communism describe by jeremy waldron
perhaps the original community of good do not actually involve any claim
right at all which might stand in the way of private appropriation but only and at most hohfeldian privilege such as the privilege of make use of the resource god have provide
on this account each individual would be at liberty to use any resource in the sense that he would have no duty not to do so but nobody at least initially would be conceive to have any right capable of generating duty on others be interested 
prima facie it be hard to see how gibbard s consent requirement can be base on mere liberty
if both mort and millie have a liberty to use x neither be morally beholden to the other
millie s liberty in no way restrict the range of mort s permissible action and so he do not need millie s consent to use x in whatever way he choose
gibbard explicitly insist however that mort s acquisition reqires millie s consent and he also seem to understand the natural right to the equal use of all thing as a liberty
within limit i shall suppose a person have a right to consume thing and to transform one thing into another
such act change the position of others by change the world physically and thereby deny other people opportunity they would otherwise have
my right to do such thing may well be limit
i do not though invariably need another person s consent to change the physical world do need his consent to bring him under new moral constraint to make it cease to be morally permissible for him to do certain thing that he can do or to make it morally permissible to coerce him in certain ways 
the point seem to be this
mort do not need millie s consent to exercise his liberty to use x even if as a matter of fact his exercise of that liberty mean that x be not available for millie to use
her opportunity be physically limit but her moral status have not be alter
but if mort claim a property right to x he not only claim that he be at liberty to use it but also that millie be under a new moral duty not to use it
that be where the need for millie s consent seem to enter
one may unilaterally transform thing but not the moral status of other person
three feature of gibbard s argument merit comment
 his conclusion be sound only by consent
if the only way to justify a duty be through the consent of the person bind by the duty then mort must get millie s consent if he be to justify his claim that she have a duty to refrain from use x but that be highly controversial
most of us will acknowledge that we be bind by duty that do not stem from some initial act of consent on our part to that duty
only by awkwardly slice the concept of consent into various hypothetical and tacit mode can one render even remotely plausible the proposition that all justification be to be construe as issue from consent
 but even if gibbard be right even if consent alone justify the imposition of duty he still have not demonstrate that there be anything especially problematic about duty to respect property
all moral duty would turn out to be contingent on obtain the ongoing consent of people
mort s liberty to speak his mind free of millie s censorship require her acquiescence as fully with a item of property in his possession
 a consent requirement for the existence of duty engender anomaly in intergenerational transaction
gibbard himself point out that one problematic aspect of his account of property right be that new adult enter the moral community will enjoy disproportionate bargaining advantage
people live through different though overlap period of time
now if anyone who have not agree otherwise have a right to use thing on the same basis as everyone else agreement make by others before a person be born to which he be not a party can not remove that right
when a child reach adulthood when that is he first become competent to make agreement he have the same right to equal use of all thing as he would have if everyone be in a state of nature
he can lose that fight only by agree to give it up
what happen then when a child first grow competent to make agreement if others have produce a very strong bargaining position
for abjure his natural right to equal use of scarce good such as cleared land stored food and housing the new adult can exact a high price 
once again the talk of equal right be confusing suggest as it do that one agree to give up a claim fight
but on the only plausible interpretation one give up a liberty ie one accept a duty
if the justification of moral duty require that each new adult must consent to the entire moral code then a system of claim right to property yield counterintuitive implication
however the implication concerning all other claim right be similarly unpalatable new adult can exact a high price for their compliance
their elder presumably have develop a settled way of life and expectation base on this code and would incur a considerable cost rather than give it up
so mort jr
can with good prospect of success put the following proposition to mort sr your property holding in return for of same and if you throw in a additional i will accept a obligation not to censor your speech or stone you for blasphemy
this we think stand as something of a reductio ad absurdum of the assumption that only the actual consent to a set of duty by each new moral citizen can justify such duty

convention and consequentialism
there exist a persistent strand of the liberal tradition that ascribe to property right a conventional status not share by other liberal fight and conclude trax a justification of property right will be inform by consequentialist consideration to a extent not true of other right
thus larry alexander write
right to pursue one s project can be no more than negative liberty to be free from have one s body labor and talent appropriate by others in pursuit of their project
the right to do not guarantee any resource outside of one s person
any right to act in and on the world in any way that compete with how others wish to act in and on the world must be right derive from some impersonal consequentialist consideration 
alexander maintain then that property right be distinguish from other liberal right in that the former but not the latter must pass the bar of consequentialist scrutiny
society may establish at its discretion whatever rule and institution of control over property that it deem conductive to overall value maximization it be restrain only at the periphory of person body
we have already argue that it be implausible that individual who maintain a special authority over their own person and action will have reason to cede all such authority concerning those external resource that constitute for them the requisite of action
the consideration of personal value that underlie one s normative authority over one s body labor and talent do not lose their salience when attention be shift to item point however may be different
he may be take as maintain that there be a variety of societal form through which recognition could be give to individual interest in exercise control over external thing
no one of these stand out as obviously correct ie natural in yet another sense of the term
therefore it be reasonable that society adopt conventional norm of justice in holding that promise to conduce to overall wellbeing understand as consequentialistic maximization
no doubt alexander be correct in maintain that property right be conventional
one need only glance at a text on comparative property law or us statute concerning patent and copyright to be make aware of the fact that socially acknowledged system of right to property be permeate through and through with artifice
however a equally brief glance at a compendium of supreme court decision concerning the scope of the first amendment guarantee of freedom of speech reveal something very similar
one can not simply read off the page of the great book of nature that a flag or dance nude in front of discriminating patron of the art be each protected speech over which the individual be properly sovereign but televised paean to the marlboro man be prohibitable for the sake of the great good
nor be there anything obviously natural in the fact that freedom of speech extend to soundtrucks at political rally in the park but not to those truck when they appraoch a hospital
right all right not just property right be ground in central human interest but take on the various particular form in which we observe them as a matter of convention
that be not to maintain that these conventional form be arbitrary that one determination about the proper bound of the exercise of speech or acquire use and convey property be as good as any other
convention themselves stand in need of justification in terms of how well or ill they conduce to the value they be intend to serve
however alexander have provide no reason to suppose that this justification take question be property right or other liberal freedom
rather we maintain that property right be to be understand as responsive to individual interest in lead their life according to their own light amidst a world of other people who similarly have a fundamental interest in direct their life in accord with their own value and project
this be to adopt a essentially anticonsequentialistic view of justification with respect to all liberal right
it may nonetheless seem that the convention define property right be uniquely contestable in a way that other right be not
vast political movement arise and contend with one another over question of how wealth be to be control moral philosopher who otherwise share a common commitment to liberal principle divide over whether property holding be to be distribute in accordance with a equality criteria a difference principle or laissezfaire allowance of unrestricted acquisition
in the face of such diversity one be tempt to conclude that there be something up for grab with respect to property right that do not similarly characterize other liberal right not as a entailment of the pure theory of right but rather as a commentary on the history of liberalism
many matter that move people in previous generation to take up arm no long sharply engage the passion and interest it be simply not a open question any long northern ireland aside whether papist be entitle to moral space within which they can give effect to their particular allegiance
within at least the democratic west and in recent month within nascently democratic central and eastern europe a substantial degree of consensus have be achieve concerning which activity fall within the protected sphere
it be important however that we overstate neither the extent nor the stability of such a consensus
liberal toleration be not without enemy who contend against it both in mass political movement and in the scholarly literature
nor be there anything in the logic of liberalism that generate the result say that one may permissibly elect to play golf on the sabbath but not to ing opiate
if might be both accidental and temporary
no conclusion should be draw that property right be either uniquely conventional or especially suit to toolong parcel out

a nonhistorical reinterpretation of the originalacquisition argument
here be one possibility

but suppose that someone deny

so understand a original acquisition account of property need be no more historical than a political theory base on the concept of the state of nature or the social contract

rather all three ie original acquisition the state of nature and the social contract be think experiment that induce us to view justificatory
to be sure this probably be not locke s intent

conclusion
do property right pose a special justificatory problem we have argue in this paper that for the most part they do not
most of the socalled special problem of property be simply particular case of the general requirement that claim right be justify to those on whom they impose obligation
we have show that critic of liberal property right typically hold these right to be dubious because they stand in need of justification though these same critic elsewhere in relation say to free speech accept a equivalent justificatory requirement as unproblematic

the problem
property typically come to us by transfer from previous owner
all property however eventually trace its existence as property to appropriation of previously unowned good

so the way to remove resource from the common stock be to mix one s labor with them thereby annex them to one s person

this qualification upon what one can originally extract from the commons be now know as the lockean proviso
virtually no one to my knowledge believe that any particular act of initial appropriation in a world of scarcity stand much chance of satisfy the lockean proviso judith jarvis thomson once put it this way
i suspect that there be no plausible construal of what locke have in mind by enough and as good under which anyone be take land for himself would leave enough and as good for all the other owner
for one thing locke do not realize how large the class of owner be go to be
i therefore suspect that if we take leave enough and as good as a necessary condition for property acquisition then it will follow that there can be no private ownership of land 
jeremy waldron concur
if the enough and as good clause be a necessary condition on appropriation it would follow that in these circumstance by starvation and exposure of them all distribution by consent be rule out practically and ex hypothesi since no appropriation would leave enough and as good in common for others

likewise reserve a campsite in a crowded national park also fail to leave enough and as good for others as do the use of public property in general when such property be subject to rationing or crowd

appropriate acquire etc good from the commons by establish control over them in particular establish the power to exclude others from consume those good

indeed sanders have a powerful argument that ignore it be exactly what we should do 
against the idea that we should ignore the proviso consider that in propose the proviso locke be already retreat from the usual criteria of legitimate property transfer which require that transaction be consensual

nor do anyone have the kind of claim to the resource that prior owner would have so there be no reason to suppose that anything as strong as prior consent be normatively require to legitimize original appropriation
yet locke be right to think something must be do to justify original appropriation for such appropriation seize exclusive control over that to which others previously have unrestricted access

 the problem with the proviso be that contrary than the requirement that one obtain the prior consent of others

moreover i do not think it become hard for original appropriation to satisfy the proviso as good become more scarce

nevertheless i beleive the proviso should be read this way for this reading capture a crucial truth about the condition under which property be legitimate

apple
a group of us find ourselves instantiate in a valley full of various kind of apple tree some already bear ripe fruit
find ourselves hungry we commence pick and eat so as other tree begin to ripen a few of us jump the gun and pick the best apple before they be quite ripe and the rest of us rush in fear that we will otherwise lose out entirely
thing get bad and eventually we find ourselves pick fruit before it be really edible
if we do not someone else will snatch it first and by the small of margin we would rather have little green apple tha none at all
tired of this degrading affair and of be underfed one of us build a fence around a single blossoming tree
none of the rest of us pay much attention to her until the day approach when her tree be the only tree we have yet to prematurely ravage will bear the only ripe apple in the valley
there be those of us who think about kill her in her sleep
but there be others who decide that her idea be a good one and follow suit while there be still time of us in group claim plot jointly adopt various way of share the cost and benefit of joint management
the detail of our arrangement be not important here for the task at hand be to justify original appropriation in general rather than to justify any particular kind of property institution
""
then group ii come along
they find some tree fence off bear lots of ripe fruit
the rest of the tree have be destroy
we tear them down try to eat the bark
group ii approach the fencedoff tree and
ask us where group ii s tree be
we say there be no tree for group ii
group ii say but we be hungry
we say no problem
grab those old dead tree over there and make fencepost
we will trade apple for them
group i say all right but there be many group yet to come
there be nt enough apple to feed them all
famine be like we begin to tremble a bit
well except for the original fence builder that be
she be think about the new fencepost industry and how it will facilitate the reclamation and rehabilitation of land for agricultural use
the end of our story find her busy collecting apple seed
the moral of the story be this
as latecomer arrive and natural resource become scarce anything leave in the commons will be level
this much be not news at least not to reader of garrett hardin what really be news be this leave good in the commons fail to satisfy the proviso
in fact leave good in the commons practically ensure their ruin
the essence of the tragedy of the commons what make it tragic be precisely that not enough and as good be leave for others
as a necessary condition for satisfy the proviso good must be remove from the commons
moreover the more severe the scarcity the faster resource will be destroy in will require that resource be remove from the commons
needless to say there be more than one institutional framework that can effectively remove good from the commons range from private property to public property to national border
for present purpose this make no difference
we be not try to decide which institution be most effective or even which be justify but only that the establishment of exclusive control which they all presume can be justify
at any rate there be no incentive to nurture apple tree in the commons
in the commons the fruit of production so to speak belong to others as much as to oneself
if one do not want to starve one be better off spend one s time eating while one can rather than produce
if only we have the power to decide how everyone will act
there might not be any point in remove resource from the commons
we could satisfy the proviso by choose for everyone to abide by principle ourselves not for everyone
and what people should choose for themselves differ from what would be right and from what the proviso would require if they be choose for everyone
what do this general point imply about the commons the commons might never be level if we could choose for everyone to leave enough and as good for others but the fact that people choose for themselves make a difference to what count as leave enough and as good for others
to decide that everyone will leave a piece of land alone would be to protect it to decide to leave it alone oneself be merely to leave it unprotected
in the commons we could naively restrain ourselves wait our turn and then eat only our share
but it would nt help
those who do otherwise will still precipitate the tragedy of the commons
our only choice in this unfolding tragedy would be these join in the mad rush to mutual starvation refuse to join the rush and be the first rhetorically and otherwise
only if some people successfully implement the latter choice be there any chance of the proviso be satisfy
be those who initially catalyze this mad rush do something wrong of course in particular they be violate the proviso
but whether their action be right or wrong be not really the point
the point be that until access to the land be restrict people will have the opportunity and the incentive to overuse it and some of them as a matter of fact will overuse it thereby not leave enough and as good for others
a moral agent have to take this into account when decide how to go about ensure that there will be something leave for her child
and simply allow the commons to go to ruin at the hand of other forager most emphatically be not the way to ensure that something will be leave for her child
if one be to satisfy the proviso in a way that have some positive bearing on the preservation of mankind one as it apply to thing like apple ie food
but if one merely appropriate apple one be not satisfy the proviso with respect to apple
those who appropriate apple from the commons violate the proviso on any interpretation of it insofar as it pertain to apple
they generate the tragedy of the commons
since appropriate apple ignore the proviso with respect to apple the tragedy create by those who appropriate apple alter what the proviso mean as a constraint on appropriation of land
in other word some alteration of the rule of access to apple be necessary if the proviso with respect to apple be to be satisfy
the proviso itself drive us to make this alteration and so our interpretation of the proviso must reflect the fact that it drive us to alter the rule of access to apple ie to restrict access to apple
specifically to appropriate land be to restrict access to apple
and restricted access to apple tend somewhat paradoxically to be a precondition proviso with respect to apple one must appropriate land rather than apple
hence land appropriation be not a violation of the proviso given that the proviso apply first and foremost to food under those circumstance but must instead be require by it
i will say more about the proviso with respect to land at the end of the following section
""
assumption
two assumption i make in derive this conclusion be worth discuss
first in require that enough and as good be leave for others i take the proviso to be refer to future generation as well as to the present one
as sanders put it what possible argument could at the same time require that the present generation have scruple about leave enough for one another while shrug off such concern for future generation 
locke think the point of property be that it help preserve mankind which he undoubtedly mean to include future generation
this do not mean locke also intend the proviso s reference to the suggestion be surely a strong one
moreover if locke do not think of the proviso as protect future generation he should have and so should we
if we aspire to preserve mankind leave something for our own generation be not enough
the land must be save for future generation too
as scarcity rear its ugly head a given generation s preservation of the land for future generation discharge its obligation to satisfy the proviso in the only way that matter in the long run
and if we latecomer ourselves after all do not leave resource for the next generation we must somewhere along the line be fail to leave resource for others whether or not we read others as be define in terms of future generation
this be why i have insist that the proviso not only permit original appropriation which be a significant point in itself but actually require it
one might suppose that the proviso do not literally require original appropriation because lie down and die
perhaps this be right but if the intent of the proviso be to regulate original appropriation in such a way as to be conducive to the preservation of mankind then obey it simply by die miss the proviso s point
that be not to say member of the first generation will not sometimes rightly feel disadvantaged by appropriation of their contemporary perhaps even to the point where they wish their contemporary would lie down and die
nevertheless she who remove the first plot of land from the commons be do something the proviso require to be do by somebody because again tree leave in common be subject to ruinous overuse by those who do not care or can not afford to care give the logic of the commons about leave enough and as good for others
if someone object that he would rather have meet that requirement himself she can answer you be object to my do something that have to be do by someone
to do it and i pick me
you would have pick you which would have be similarly unobjectionable
but that be nt how it happen
""
he might well respond that he be nt object to her act of appropriation he be object to the way she distribute what she appropriate or the fruit thereof perhaps his argument be sound but in any event since his objection be not against the removal as such we have no quarrel with him here
he concede our point that people must acquire good to be able to save them for future generation
we concede his point that once one acquire good there be limit on what one can do with one s acquisition
for present purpose we leave open the possibility that among such limit be those pertaining to redistribution
moreover if population pressure be already severe enough to limit relative latecomer opportunity even in the first generation that mean population pressure will limit their opportunity whether or not appropriation be a living be a disappointment forage the commons elbow to elbow would hardly be a picnic
whether or not appropriation be allow relative latecomer all find themselves in the same position whatever generation they belong to either the land have already be appropriate or that which have not be appropriate can not be appropriate and be probably on the way to ruin
but when some of the land have be appropriate at least relative latecomer can hope to secure the opportunity to use land land that remain useful by trade their labor for it
those who appropriate land can see to it that something be leave for the future by assume responsibility for the land which mean assume the right to prevent those who would overuse it from do so
those who merely appropriate apple perform no such service
the proviso it should be note be a principle of justice pertaining to original acquisition not to rectify past injustice
the original situation be not fair and appropriate land do not appropriate land do not make it fair either
those who show up late in the race to appropriate land typically have little reason to suppose they would have do better by show up similarly late in the race to appropriate apple from the commons
on the contrary since the prize tend to be so much small in the commons they typically would do that much bad
that they have show up late through no fault of their own be something to consider when distribute prize
in contrast that they find themselves in the first kind of race rather than the second be something for which they should simply be thankful
my second assumption concern exactly what it be that must be leave for future generation
as our story go protect group ii s interest do not require that apple or tree or land be leave in common for group ii to build fence around but that the source of apple be preserve so that group ii will have something to eat
and it be a good for group ii
when that which be scarce be leave in the commons it will be overuse
to ensure that something worth have will be leave for group ii someone in the first group have to build fence around it
my second assumption then be that what future generation need be resource to use
they do not need resource to initially acquire
again this seem to be locke s intention more importantly it should be ours as well
latecomer arrive too late to acquire valuable land by original appropriation
if what be important be leave resource for use then leave resource for original appropriation be not necessary
thus leave land in the commons be not necessary
in fact it be imperative not to leave land in the commons give what will happen to it there
soon or later the only land worth have will be previously appropriated land
therefore the proviso can not be think of as provide for the preservation of opportunity to appropriation of land inevitably leave less land in common for others to appropriate it must at least violate the proviso with respect to land even if violate the proviso in this respect be necessary if one be to satisfy the proviso with respect to apple
carol rose for instance concede that to be sure any appropriation diminish to some tiny degree the amount of a resource that be available to others
 but this concession be a crucial mistake
it be not true that appropriation of land inevitably decrease the amount of land available to others
it only inevitably decrease what be available for original appropriation by others which be not the same thing at all thus appropriation of land be not only require by the proviso with respect to apple but be also permit by the proviso with respect to land
