contemporary holding
thomas mautner argue that theory of original appropriation have no contemporary relevance why not because even if we produce a workable criteria of just original appropriation be acquire in accordance with that criteria
but as a matter of fact the history of contemporary holding be generally lace with episode of force and fraud
nor do mautner think a theory of original appropriation would help in decide how to rectify historical injustice and i follow him in this respect
""
mautner s point be welltaken but my admittedly idiosyncratic reading of the proviso have a contemporary relevance that mautner do not anticipate
first a obvious point even today many resource be still largely hold in common
to give one example the coral reef of the philippine and tongan island be currently be ravage by destructive fishing technique
where fisherman once used lure and trap they now pour bleach ie sodium hypochlorite into the reef
partially asphyxiate the fish float to the surface and become easy prey
unfortunately the coral itself suffocate along with the fish and the dead reef cease to be a viable habitat
blastfishing also widely practice what go through the mind of these fisherman as they reduce some of the most beautiful habitat in the world to rubble perhaps some of them think quite correctly that if they do not destroy a given reef it will shortly be destroy by someone else so they might as well be the one to catch the fish
various group be try to save the reef by effectively remove them from the commons makng other group very angry in the process the issue of how such appropriation might be justify be of contemporary relevance if anything be
moreover my interpretation of the proviso imply that preserve the ecology of the reef should be regard as the pivotal issue which seem right on the mark to me
second and perhaps less obviously my argument also bear on resource that be appropriate long ago because it do more than show that thing could have work out so that original appropriation and subsequent history would have be legitimate even though it actually turn out otherwise
justify holding of course
nevertheless justify original appropriation do have the following critically important implication one can not in blanket fashion base claim of historical injustice on the a priori argument that current holding must after all have be originally acquire somewhere along the line
on the contrary claim of historical injustice must refer to the actual historical record of particular extant holding
third my argument suggest that there be a sense in which the proviso have justificatory significance over and above the role it play as a criteria of just original appropriation
consider that although remove good from the commons be necessary if good be to be preserve for future generation it be not sufficient for original appropriation by itself do not guarantee that good will be preserve for future generation
in other word original appropriation be require to satisfy the proviso and this fact suffice to justify original appropriation
but it do not suffice to justify any and all the way in which one s holding might be use fail to satisfy the proviso insofar as it pertain to the use of resource rather than to their initial acquisition
i will call this sense of the proviso the useproviso to stress the change of topic
we have be talk about the justification of property as a outgrowth of legitimate original appropriation
the useproviso in contrast concern the justification of property as a vehicle for preserving resource for the future the useproviso s satisfaction require that those who appropriate resource also practice in some sense ecologically sound management
satisfy the useproviso would mean that regardless of what have happen in the past a owner could claim that her holding be be properly care for and will still be there for future generation when she die
the useproviso s justificatory weight however much it have may be use to criticize as well as to defend current holding for renewable resource like forest and generally for resource that can be effectively use without be destroy like park land one ought to when one find it
for resource like oil that can not be effectively use without destroy them this requirement would be too strong
after all for good that can only be consume once someone will eventually have to deal with their already have be consume
so distant generation can not have the same claim to nonrenewable resource as proximate one
at most they will be able to point out that such resource should be replace by something as good and not necessarily the same kind of resource
of course this leave us with the problem of decide what as good amount to
one problem with this be that one person might claim while chop down redwood to make room for a hamburger franchise that he be leave enough and as good for others when everyone else agree he be simply spoil his land
in a similar vein we might ask if a person be inclined not to leave enough and as good for others when in the commons as good when it come to his own property undoubtedly a few owner will care so little about the future that they will ruin their own land despite the loss to themselves of its future value
and some tongan fisherman given ownership of a reef might prefer to destroy its future productivity for the sake of maximize a onetime harvest despite the fact that they will then be leave with nothing
nevertheless this lamentable folly be no reason for the rest of us to give such people the opportunity to ravage everything by leave it all in the commons
that they ruin their own property be bad enough
consider also that in the commons people have comparatively little incentive to save the land even if they do care about their future
even those tongan fisherman who would like to save the reef for their child continue to dynamite and poison the reef because as long as the reef remain in commons they do not have the option of choose between longrun and shortrun for themselves and shortrun gain for whoever show up next
exclusive control over a stream of benefit give us reason to maximize that stream s longrun value
once we lose control over this stream our incentive be to maximize the immediate value we can extract
this also hold if the future we care about be mankind be rather than our own
the property we save from ourselves can be preserve by us as we see fit but the commons we save belong to everyone and be subject to ruination by others whether or not we save it from ourselves
when one have control over a parcel of land its future and one s own be bind together as tightly as possible and this arrangement make the most of whatever tendency one have to care about the future
admittedly fence the commons be not a panacea
people sometimes ruin their own property
sometimes a injunction to care for it properly be needed but this be no reason to regret that the property have be the property be control by some identifiable party then at least there be some identifiable party who can be hold responsible for it
there be some person or group on whom the need injunction can be serve
""
conclusion
a key problem for the liberal theory of property concern the justification of initial acquisiton of resource from the common stock
my argument do not settle question of comparison among alternative property institution but it do settle that institution of exclusive control in general be immune to the sweeping objection that the initial acquisition of property can not be justify by the light of he proviso
in establish this my argument rebut a argument often level against private property but which apply equally to institution for establish exclusive control in general
if we should leave enough and as good for others we should above all leave enough and as good for future generation
to leave enough and as good for future generation we must above all protect them from presentday commons tragedy
remove resource from what we must preserve for future generation be opportunity to use resource not opportunity to originally appropriate them
this must be so because under condition of scarcity if we want resource to be there for future generation leave resource in the commons for them to remove on their own be out of the question
my interpretation of the proviso far from ruling out original appropriation actually require it
david schmidtz
yale university
in this essay i seek to advance the philosophical defense of private property ie of private holding of extrapersonal objects the defense proposed vindicates holding as matter of right
i argue that each person have a natural right to the practice of private property which consist in a right that all others abide by a system of rule under which individual may peacefully acquire transform and otherwise exercise exclusive and discretionary control over extrapersonal object
there be no natural right to specific extrapersonal object or to any share of such object
rather particular entitlement to extrapersonal holding arise through the performance of those action designate as entitlementconferring by the system of rule to which individual have natural right
as individual be bind to comply with the rule constitute the practice of private property they be bind to respect the particular entitlement that arise within that practice i attempt to show how the natural right of property and in turn the specific entitlement to holding that arise under the institutionalization of that right fit within my argument in this essay like all moral argument about property do not stand on its own
rather it rest on more basic philosophical consideration in this case on a foundational argument for natural right only a sketch of which can be present here
i shall proceed in the following manner
first i shall outline the main contention of those more basic philosophical inquiry
second i shall introduce motivate and characterize a rightsbased version of classical liberalism which i shall then simply refer to as classical liberalism
this classical liberalism in essence combine a doctrine of selfownership with a endorsement of entitlementconferring procedure which sanction the division of the extrapersonal world into private domain
while the selfownership component be present as a consequence of the philosophical inquiry describe in section i at this early stage of exposition the sanctioning of the division of the extrapersonal world into private domain be present simply as a natural extension or concomitant of the selfownership component
third i shall characterize act theory theory
fourth i shall criticize the general adequacy of act theory of private property
fifth i shall motivate characterize and defend the practice theory of private property including its incorporation of the truth normally resident within act theories 
act theory and the practice theory represent alternative strategy for justify private property within the classical liberal perspective
act theory support the coherence of classical liberalism by depict entitlement to private holding as arise solely through the exercise of selfownership or some aspect of selfownership
the practice theory support the coherence of classical liberalism by found entitlement to private holding in part on the exercise of selfownership but more importantly in part on a companion natural right of property which share a philosophical base with selfownership
if this essay advance the program of a rightsbased classical liberal account of private property in extrapersonal object it do so through its development of the contrast between act and practice theory and in its far elucidation and defense of the practice theory from the point of view of high drama theory do not make its full appearance until the fifth section of this essay

agentrelativity and selfownership
i have argue elsewhere for a version of moral individualism that display two distinct yet interconnect facets the first facet be the agentrelativity of value
what be of value what provide individual with goaloriented reason for action be essentially personally individuate
a given end e will be valuable with regard to alice will provide alice with a goaloriented reason to maintain or promote e only if it stand in a certain necessary indexical relation to alice eg the relation of be the fulfillment of her preference be her pleasure be a realization of her potential or be the continuation of her life
since value arise and exist within such relation of particular agent with specific end it be the agent within that relation for whom those end be valuable for whom those end provide goaloriented reason of value for action
hence from e be be valuable with regard to alice from e it do not follow in the least that e be valuable as such ie be agentneutrally valuable or that in virtue of such agentneutral value alan have any reason to maintain or promote e or even to abstain from destroy it
any e be be of value for alice in itself provide no reason at least no reason of a goaldirected sort for alan to maintain or promote or even not to destroy e of course in special circumstance there may be some overlap in the end including the most basic end that be of value to alice and alan
they may each take nonrivalrous pleasure in the local band s performance of sousa march and have reason even cooperatively to promote these events but within any largescale pluralist society the special sharing of goal that exist among particular individual and group will not even begin to provide the basis for goalbased rule or prescription have general interpersonal force across that society
on the contrary the agentrelativity of value which people owe allegiance and in the name of which the behavior of individual may legitimately be bend mold or constrain
for any notion of the social good which be not merely a appeal to fantastic organicism must be construct by aggregate combine rank or otherwise depersonalize the separate and variegated good of particular individual
but no such combinatory process make sense among the incommensurable agentrelative value of individual
the cost impose on alice to advance a human good realize in the life of alan be not furthermore a cost that advance some agentneutral goal such as the maximization of aggregate utility or the greatest possible enhancement of the less well endow social position for which alice as a rational or moral agent should be prepare to pay
the denial of morally authoritative common goal which each person as a rational or moral agent have reason to promote free individual from the threat of the justified subordination of their life and capacity to the promotion of such conception of the good
unfortunately from all moral constraint on their behavior towards others in the course of their respective pursuit of personal end
i argue however that this be mere appearance
for there be another connect facet of moral individualism
to affirm the agentrelativity of value be to acknowledge each person as have ultimate end of his own as possess distinctive end for his person to which he rationally ought to devote the element which compose his personal constitution
but to acknowledge such distinctive end for each person be to remove each person from the realm of mere thing that have no rational purpose of their own and that be therefore morally available for exploitation by other purposive being
as a endinhimself in the sense of possess his own distinctive and separate lifepurposes each agent be also a endinhimself in the sense of not be a mean to the purpose of others
the recognition of others as reasonbearing and valuepursuing being on a moral par with oneself do not then require allegiance to their good nor somehow to be construct out of everyone s incommensurable value
the rational recognition of others take instead the form of deontic constraint on one s liberty to use others
respect for sideconstraints on one s permissible treatment of others be the way in which in one s practical relation to others one can recognize the value and importance of their project and end without incorporate them into one s own plan of life or factor them along with all others project and end into some unified and common end morally speak to be a selfowner be to possess moral authority over one s personal constitution ie over those feature component or aspect of one s personal existence the rational goal of which be the advancement of one s lifedefining purpose
the component of one s personal constitution which one have reason to devote to one s good define the moral domain over which one have natural jurisdiction
thus the practical recognition of others as moral equal with oneself with separate end of their of each as a selfowner as a being with a special moral jurisdiction over the person he be
this be the initial key claim of moral individualism s theory of the right
alice can never provide other agent at large with reason to respect her possession and control of any extrapersonal object by point out that this respect be conducive to her good ie that she have reason to want that possession respect
the value for her of that possession may be real however it fail to command the compliance of others
on the other hand be she credibly able to invoke a authoritative common end which be serve by her possession then respect for her possession would indeed be imperative
but no such invocation be credible
as thing stand then if alice have a claim to some extrapersonal object which be good against the world it can not be in virtue of either the agentrelative or the agentneutral value of her possession of it
rather her claim must take the form with her peaceful enjoyment of that object
and this right if there be such a right must represent a portion of the recognition all other agent owe her as a separate reasonbearing and valuepursuing be on a moral par with themselves

rightsbased classical liberalism
the core of classical liberalism be the assertion of selfownership or some kindred right protective of the individual in his life and liberty along with the idea that this right codify at least part of the constraint on behavior that each individual may demand of others in recognition of his status as a moral endinhimself
moreover the motivation that champion robust individual right in person also seem to support a comparable division of the extrapersonal world into discrete domain each of which will lie but not inalienably within the moral jurisdiction of some particular person or perhaps some particular coalition of person
for such a division allow extrapersonal material to be secure to serve the purpose of individual agent in the same fashion as the ascription to each of a his natural endowment in the service of his end
certainly both of the philosophical giant of a natural right classical liberalism ie locke and kant be firm advocate of rightsbased immunity against seizure and interference with regard to both the individual person and his property
in the case of locke of course private property right be ground in in virtue of arise through the exercise of each person s right to his own labor which itself be a aspect of each individual s selfpropriety in kant the right over one s own person and to private property have a common grounding in a right to equal freedom 
of course the sovereignty of each over himself secure for individual inventory of personal resource that may be highly unequal
joe s geneticallybased bulge biceps may radically outclass wilbur s tiny triceps while joan s native intense intelligence may comparably outdistance wilma s wandering wit
the morally protect natural endowment of each need not jointly satisfy any privileged pattern or ratio
similarly for the seem natural and inoffensive that the division of extrapersonal material among person also need not satisfy any sanctified pattern or ratio we should though guard against the assumption that there will be any systematic correspondence between proportionate share of personal endowment and of extrapersonal endowment
or if there turn out to be a systematic correspondence it may be only because what retrospectively count as valuable share of personal endowment be precisely those endowment which turn out to facilitate the attainment of extrapersonal resource
just as the formal equality of selfownership may be satisfy without each selfowner possess a personal endowment sufficient even minimally to advance his purpose so too the envisioned division of the world of extrapersonal material need not guarantee each individual material sufficient even minimally to enhance his life 
thus fightsbased classical liberalism have the following defining feature
 it be rightsbased ie the fundamental legally enforceable constraint be those demand by individual right and these right themselves represent a interpersonal recognition of the separate moral importance of found upon any sort of transindividual overall social value
 it endorse a doctrine of moral selfownershipof each person s moral jurisdiction over himself or some functionally equivalent or near equivalent right such as a right against interference with one s person
 it take all particular right to extrapersonal object to arise through the performance of specific entitlementconferring action
it may be maintain that the entitlementconferring action be simply exercise of selfownership or its functional equivalent or some aspect of selfownership or its functional equivalent
or alternatively it may be maintain that the entitlementconferring activity be those action that confer title within a practice of private property to which each individual have a right
this correspond to the division between act theory and the practice theory
""
 as follow from and be presuppose by classical liberalism take the world of natural extrapersonal object to be initially morally up for grab ie to be itself thoroughly naturally unowned such fall within the respective moral domain of the person whose component and power they be no element of the natural world be as such morally attach to any individual
those moral attachment be instead produce by specific entitlementconferring action
 in virtue of its endorsement of selfownership classical liberalism operate with a strong presumption against any doctrine that assert or imply that some people have natural right to the product of other people s effort and endeavor
for it take such a right to the product and hence the effort and endeavor of others to clash fundamentally with selfownership
""
selfownership and act theory of private property
in the course of characterize feature of classical liberalism i have cite two alternative conception of the basis of private entitlement in extrapersonal object
according to one these entitlement arise simply through various exercise of selfownership while according to the other conception these entitlement arise through action in accordance with the rule and procedure define a practice of companion to the natural right of person over themselves
one might then proceed in terms of a distinction between the selfownership exercise theory and the selfownership companion theory
but put matter in these term would not do much to capture and convey the difference between the structure of the two strategy and the rationale for the latter strategy
it will in the end be better to have advance more slowly to the act versus practice characterization of these alternative
i turn therefore to a account of act theory of entitlement to extrapersonal holding
there be two main reason for provide this material
one reason be to get some sense of what truth there be to be glean from act theory for incorporation into any justifiable practice of private property
the second reason be to begin to build the case for go beyond act theory to the practice theory which assert that there must be within classical liberalism a distinct natural right of property which supplement selfownership
act theory of entitlement to extrapersonal object seek to account for or some set of exercise of selfownership or some functionally equivalent primary right or the exercise of some aspect of selfownership
each present rightholder exercise his selfownership in a certain way and this exercise extend his moral jurisdiction over some extrapersonal object
the agent s moral jurisdiction be extend by his action because his action extend the agent s vulnerability to the violation of his selfownership
each such entitlement be subject to a separate and selfcontained vindication
do the putative rightholder exercise his selfownership by transform create initiate the use of etc this extrapersonal object do the putative rightholder s action thereby extend his moral jurisdiction to the actedupon object if the answer be affirmative interference with or seizure of the object have the quality of violate the agent s selfownership and in virtue of this the agent be entitle to the object
the paradigmatic version of the act approach be the lockean labor theory of property or more specifically the lockean labor theory of just initial acquisition with respect to extrapersonal property be ascribe to all person
in the lockean case of course it be the right of each to his own labor which itself be a implication of each person s selfpropriety
this internal right provide or be supposed to provide a conduit for individual right to enter the external world
in the lockean paradigm a individual may exercise his right over his own labor and thereby mix his labor with extrapersonal material
since the labor be invest and not merely dissipate the resulting transformed object now contain something the agent s labor which be still morally attach to the agent
for others now to seize this object would be for them to seize the labor that have be mix with it
since seize the agent s labor would violate his general right to his own labor seize the transformed object now violate the laborer s right
thus original right to such transformed segment of the extrapersonal world be externalization of person basic internal right
the numerous candidate for this sort of bridgebuilding between internal right and the extrapersonal world
another prominent candidate be the right to liberty construe as a right against interference in the disposition of one s body talent energy and so on
under this alternative the crucial bridging act would not be the mixing of one s labor but rather the deployment of one s liberty through the use of extrapersonal object so that one s liberty be now hostage to others nonseizure of those objects the crucial bridging claim would be that the seizure of a object which one be use in ongoing purposive activity constitute a violation of one s right to liberty
much less be say by act theorist about nonoriginal private property right ie about right arise through or be convey by voluntary transfer
the characteristic theme of act theory be perhaps most fully retain in conception of legitimate transfer in which the prior owner in effect vacate ownership while at the same time the new owner s acquisition constitute a new be establish
thus the prior owner paul vacate perhaps to begin with in a way that allow only his chosen successor sally to commence her rightsestablishing act permissibly while sally by her investment of her labor or by the incorporation of the object in her ongoing purposive activity bring about a new externalization of the internal right to her own labor or the internal right against interference with her person and activity
right as such be never transfer nor do the prior owner s transfer of the holding to his successor as such bestow a right upon the latter which be a moral descendant of the original right
rather the prior owner paul s function be merely to restore his holding to the state of nature albeit to restore it selectively so that third party remain morally constrain not to appropriate the object before successor sally establish a new original right to it
any such reenactment conception of just transfer in effect close the gap between principle of initial acquisition and of transfer since essentially the same sort own object
any particular reenactment principle of just transfer will of course be no more plausible than the corresponding principle of initial acquisition
but give eg the labor or liberty principle of initial acquisition the cognate reeenactment principle be not terribly farfetched at least for transfer that be exchange
in the case of a labor reeenactment doctrine the claim will be that the labor present in the service or invest in the object that sally offer for the purpose of exchange combine with the labor sally invest in arrange or participate in the exchange be the labor permissibly invest by her in her newly acquire hold
exchange transmit investment from the object surrender to the object thereby purchase
in the case of a liberty reenactment doctrine the claim will simply be that a exchange constitute a permissible substitution of object in use in ongoing project and that the project itself may be the achievement of advantageous ie valueenhancing substitution
have permissibly and purposively acquire the object from paul it the service of sally s plan
in contrast reenactment principle must handle gift transfer somewhat less well
for gift transfer by their nature require less action on the part of the recipient
still perhaps what little any recipient must do to acknowledge receipt of a gift can be construe as a minimal permissible reenactment of the property generating act
furthermore surely something can be say about the giftgiver s moral power to convey to or otherwise establish in the recipient of his gift a entitlement to that object
and presumably whatever can be say will also apply to the seller s moral power to convey title
suppose that paul already have title to object o and be willing to convey o to sally so as to establish both her possession and title to o it seem that this must make it easy for sally to acquire title to o or must provide sally with a different way of acquire title to o than if paul do not have title of o and be could toward her acquisition of unowned o a major point in have a right over a object be to have a determinate say not only in how one will use that object but also about who if anyone shall succeed one in have that determinate say
what remain puzzling however be precisely how that moral power nifty as it may be to the rightholder arise out of the act by which property in a given object be established 
the core contention of act theorist be that through certain purposive and effective interaction with the extrapersonal world agent can project into the object of those interaction the personal moral inviolability which otherwise seem to extend only to the outer surface of their body
if one be willing to acknowledge the personal inviolability express in the idea of selfownership one must call forth a very determined normative skepticism to doubt the basic plausibility of this core contention
the lockean doctrine that initial right over previously unowned segment of nature arise through the mixing of labor with that segment of nature of literal physical mixing of one stuff with another by formulate it in terms of a person s investment of his talent time and energy his human capital in the now transform object
and once it be it be eminently plausible to maintain that the person who seize the transformed material expropriate the human capital of the investor and thereby engage in a action on a moral par with the direct seizure involved in forced labor
he who seize the transformed object simply cunningly wait until after the transformation occur and thereby evade the danger and difficulty of direct confrontation with and control of the productive party
it be essentially this lockean argument which be recast by nozick when he argue that
seize the result of someone s labor be equivalent to seizing hour from him and direct him to carry on various activity
if people force you to do certain work or unrewarded work for a certain period of time they decide what you be to do and what purpose your work be to serve apart from from you make them a partowner of you it give them a property right in you
just as have such partial control and power of decision by right over a animal or inanimate object would be to have a property right in it 
the argument from liberty be likewise plausible at its core
whereas the labor argument look backward to the investment of self in the extrapersonal world the liberty argument look forward to the projection of self into the world
people obviously do not live by past investment alone but also by necessarily prospective interaction with extrapersonal object interaction which when view from some later point may count as a investment of self
these projection of self have particular trajectory which be at least in part define by the extrapersonal object put to use and through the use of which the agent project the completion of his course

the natural right to the practice of private property
the human condition with regard to the role of extrapersonal resource in the pursuit of value be radically different from what could be infer merely from such a right of person over themselves
for besides be physical being literally occupy physical space human being extend beyond the space occupy by their respective body
this extended world be the field in which almost all human value be pursue and purpose be achieve
it be the field in which each of us encounter and interact with others
and within that field human goal be advance through the employment of individual ability insight and energy on the material object of the world both the raw material and that material as it have be mold and transform by past human purposiveness and inadvertence
human life understand as ongoing purposive selfsustaining and selfenhancing activity take place mostly outside of human body in and through the world of extrapersonal object
nor be the activity in which human life consist merely a matter of recurrent excursion or raid into the world of extrapersonal object
extrapersonal object enter into and help define the specific goal ambition and commitment through which individual compose their respective life
particular extrapersonal object become deeply incorporate into the specific strategy that individual formulate for their may be merely contingently connect with the pure concept of goaloriented activity

and emphatically this be true of all or nearly all human end not just those that might be mark off or denigrate as economic
the life of the religious crusader the political pamphleteer the athlete the aesthete the pornographer the family man and woman the tourist the gourmet and the gourmand all require extrapersonal vehicle and avenue
this necessary feature of human life strongly suggest that selfownership at least as so far explicate by waldron cohen and myself can not represent the entirety the single sturdy trunk of person fundamental and noncontractual right
it make it plausible that any story that be tell about the fundamental right of individual which do not find significant implication in this necessary feature of human life must be a incomplete story demand supplementation that supplementation may take the form the addition of another equally fundamental right correspond to the practical recognition of other human being as endsinthemselves who necessarily live their life in and through the extrapersonal world
since nothing be gain and clarity be lose by insist that all fundamental natural right must be part of selfownership i will take the strongly suggest need for supplementation to point to another equally fundamental right a companion to natural selfownership namely a natural right of property 
but must not any clearthinking advocate of classical liberalism reject anything which be strictly speak a natural right of property for it would seem that a natural right of or at least to property must assert that each person be born to entitlement in extrapersonal object just as he be born to a moral jurisdiction over himself

nevertheless it be not itself a entitlement to any particular extrapersonal object or any share of any such object
thus endorsement of this natural right be consistent with the classical liberal view that all right to extrapersonal object arise through the performance of entitlementconferring action

it be this natural right to the practice of private property which i shall argue be part of the practical recognition rationally require by each person s possession of a human life with a independent rational purpose of its own
there and practice theory of property right on the more familiar distinction between act and ruleutilitarianism
in choose the actpractice terminology i have succumb to this temptation
but it be necessary to clarify precisely how the present distinction draw upon the more commonplace one and how this temptation may lead one down misguided path
actutilitarianism be of course characterize by its direct application of the utilitarian conception of the good to the ranking of alternative available action
each action s rank depend directly on the agentneutral value of the world occasion by its performance the available action that most promote the agentneutral good be the high rank and hence the obligatory one
in contrast rule utilitarianism apply the utilitarian conception of the good to the ranking of alternative set of rule or practice
one set of rule be rank high than another if and only if compliance with the former more promote the agentneutral good than compliance with the latter
a particular action be right or even obligatory if and only a right action need not then itself have the power of more promote the agentneutral good than all other available particular action
indeed a action have in itself this power may nevertheless be wrong in virtue of its violation of some rule within the optimizing set of rules 
in adopt the actpractice terminology i intend to draw upon the familiarity of the contrast between i defend a particular act or hold by display the particulars s embodiment of the justifying quality and ii defend the particular act or hold by show its compliance with a rule or practice which itself be the direct object of moral justification
but three divergence from the act versus rule utilitarian distinction must be note
the first and relatively minor one be that act and practice theory of property right aim at the vindication of assertion of right while act and ruleutilitarianism typically seek to establish claim about the valueenhancing rightness of action
the second and more important divergence be between the theory of entitlement in extrapersonal object
within the former the point be to shift the utilitarian justification from the level of act upward to the level of rule
a central motivation for this shift be to render judgment about particular act less directly subject to any utilitarian calculus and thereby to provide these local judgment with a great deontic coloration
but the other side of this motivation be the desire of the ruleutilitarian to retain the fundamentally consequentialist appeal of his moral theory
in contrast the practice theory of property right be not at all motivate by a interest in make or reserving room at the commanding height of the theory for consequentialist reasoning
instead the practice in terms of which particular holding be to be vindicate be itself supposed to be the object of person natural moral right the legitimacy of particular holding be ultimately ground upon a deontic appeal to that right and to the normatively significant feature of individual life and value that underlie that right the third and perhaps most important divergence be that level of entitlementconferring rule the same justifying aim as the act theory employ on the level of particular holding
the practice theory do not seek to justify some set of entitlementconferring rule by show that this set of rule more protect or promote the exercise of selfownership than any other set of comparable rules the practice theory invoke a different right from that of selfproprietorship namely the natural right to the practice of private property or somewhat more precisely the natural right to others compliance with a system under which each agent can secure for himself the same sort of protected control over portion of the extrapersonal world as selfownership provide for each agent over his own person
any such system must exhibit certain feature
there must be rule specify entitlementconferring action
certain form of activity must count as establish title to previously unowned object other form of activity must count as dissolving existing title or as acquire title to object previously within the jurisdiction of others
but not every set of rule identify entitlementconferring procedure will be coherent the specification of entitlementconferring action must be such that noncompossible entitlement do not arise so that compliance with the resulting entitlement will always be possible
to be functional rule of the practice must be readily knowable to those govern by the practice sanction identifiable and predictable entitlement so that compliance with the confer entitlement be feasible to be comprehensive the rule of the practice must sanction or be subject to reasonable analogical extension so as to sanction the acquisition of entitlement to all previously unowned object
to be justifiable the practice must be compatible with selfownership
a justifiable system s entitlementconferring rule must in particular incorporate the plausible claim of act theory of private property to the effect that by means of certain exercise of one s selfownership one expose oneself to have that right violate by means of others interference with or seizure of one s external holding and one thereby acquire entitlement to those holding as extension of one s selfownership
let us say that a practice be fully comprehensive and justifiable
still in the abstract many different practice may qualify as fully justifiable relative to any given society in the abstract the right to the practice of private property be a right to people s compliance with some one of these fully justifiable practice
be any one of these alternative practice magically introduce at let us imagine a equally fanciful moment of mass entitlement amnesia in which all memory of who have entitlement to what under which specific rule be lose each person s right to the practice of private property would consist in his right to people s compliance with that introduced practice
compliance with that practice would be what each could reasonably expect of others in the way of respect for his natural right of property
have be introduce that practice would be the fully justify one
thus even at this level justice be historical one would not be justify in substitute any other practice which be equally justifiable in the abstract for the now establish and coherence or functionality of the effective system of property right for that society if apply retroactively it would nullify entitlement confer under a existing justifiable practice
even a existing practice which be not in the abstract fully justifiable can be justify and thereby will be resistant to be justifiably replace by a fully justifiable practice
it will be justify if it be roughly speak about as abstractly justifiable as can reasonably be expect in actual human affair
the case against substitution of alternative practice which undercut a system s coherence and functionality do not of course rule out reform and beneficial evolution with a society s justified law of property
such change aim at or at least result in the enhancement of the coherence functionality comprehensiveness or justifiability of the existing practice be to be guide or evaluate in terms of the organizing idea of the private property system ie the idea of sanction the expansion of personal sphere of authority so as to secure for individual inviolability of a justified practice of private property individual do acquire title to extrapersonal object by engage in the specified entitlementconferring action
although the specification of entitlementconferring action must embody the truth that may be glean from act theory of entitlement some entitlementconferring act under a given justified practice will not involve the sort of extension of selfownership which be the focus of act theory
those act nevertheless confer entitlement in virtue of their conformity to the entitlementgenerating rule of a justified practice
in addition although i be not sure what weight to give this factor the expectation with regard to protected holding that be generate under a existing justified system be legitimate expectation
as legitimate expectation they provide individual with reasonable claim against those who be bind to comply with that practice
when that compliance occur the entitlement generate by the action specify by a practice s rule and correspond to the agent legitimate expectation and sometimes far support by act theory consideration be respected 
the particular constraint with which individual have in fact come into operation in the society and which actual entitlementconferring action individual have in fact perform
justice in extrapersonal holding be as nozick maintain in anarchy state and utopia historical and unpatterned
the justice of any particular holding be a matter of that hold actually arise through certain specific procedure namely those that confer entitlement within the existing justified practice
a set of holding among people ie a distribution of holding be just insofar as the particular holding be independently historically legitimate
the justice of the whole follow from the justice of the part not the other way around
thus no characteristic of the whole can be the touchstone of the justice of the whole or of its constituent part
the justice of the whole distribution will depend neither on its presentation of a certain profile eg equality among holding or the maximization of the small packet of holding nor on the individual holding within that distribution map some other characteristic of the property holder absence of any preordained pattern to which the distribution of extrapersonal material must conform parallel the absence of any such regulative pattern for the distribution of personal endowment as be anticipted in the first paragraph of section ii

human being into

introduction
in his book moral by agreement david gauthier offer a stateofnature justification for a form of ownership which he believe closely resemble private ownership gauthier argue that first appropriation of land within certain restriction morally justify vest in the appropriator right resemble private ownership
gauthier be not alone in his use of a stateofnature justification of a form of ownership
locke rousseau kant and recently robert nozick have also offer stateofnature justification
i have already show how these other attempt at justification fail but because gauthier s attempt be far more subtle and complex his argument require me to do more than simply refer to what i have early say
i have argue that all stateofnature justification by first appropriation must fail because they presuppose unrealistic condition and be questionbegging
i shall prove that gauthier s stateofnature justification be no exception
i shall limit this discussion of gauthier s justification to his treatment of ownership of land and resource
gauthier s argument concerning do not depend upon a stateofnature appropriation and many of his conclusion about ownership of self and labor run parallel to conclusion i have reach
it be primarily gauthier s reliance upon a stateofnature firstappropriation justification of ownership which cause his argument to fail
the failure be methodological it do not depend upon substantive morality
his faulty methodology can not give determinate conclusive result
in the next section i shall show that gauthier s justification be questionbegging because he fail to establish that private ownership and only private ownership be derivable from stateofnature condition
i shall demonstrate in the third section that gauthier s justification of the form he believe resemble private ownership appear plausible only because it presuppose unrealistic abundance in the state of nature which thus make unnecessary any form of ownership at all in the final section i shall contrast gauthier s form of ownership with private ownership and show that the way in which gauthier s form of ownership differ from private ownership make his form of ownership impossible to put into practice
any moral justification of a form of ownership ground upon a original act of appropriation in a state of nature must show not only that the particular form be thus ground but also that no other form can be so ground
use private ownership as a example it be not sufficient to show that private ownership can be ground on original appropriation in a state of nature the argument must also show that no other form of ownership such as communal ownership can also fulfill the relevant standard of justification
let me explain more fully what i mean because this point be almost universally ignore
suppose that a gauthier or a locke try to prove that private ownership base upon original private appropriation produce more utility or benefit to each individual than the state of nature in which land and resource in effect constitute a commons available to all
while this argument may seem to justify private ownership the argument do not show that only private ownership be morally justify
there may be other form of ownership also produce more utility or benefit than a state of nature in which land and resource be a commons available to all
if the standard of justification be the production of great benefit or utility for each than the stateofnature commons then private ownership private usufruct and collective cooperative ownership may be morally justify
the problem be that this stateofnature justification show all three to be justify which mean that this stateofnature argument can not be use to decide which of the three be morally preferable
a complete justification would have to show that private ownership and only private ownership fulfill the standard of justification
other form of ownership must therefore be examine and show not to fulfill the standard
argument which show that private ownership or any other form be ground upon original appropriation but which fail to show that only private ownership or some other form be so ground i shall call partial justification
this distinction between partial and complete justification be different from and independent of the distinction between what be justification of ownership might conclude that one specific form and only one specific form of ownership be morally justify and thus morally require
by contrast moral justification of ownership might conclude that several closely related form of ownership be all morally permissible and that no one of them be morally require
adopt any one of the closely related form would be right
to be closely relate in this sense imply that these form of ownership be constitute by certain right of title such as the right to income or the right to manage or certain criteria of title such as bequest which be morally optional this be to say that either vest the right or withhold the right must be morally permissible
form of ownership would not be closely relate in this sense if vest the right be morally permissible and withhold it be not
just as a justification of a morally required form of ownership can be either complete or partial so also can a justification of morally permissible form of ownership be either complete or of closely related form of ownership be justifiable so that any form within the range be morally permissible
a complete justification of ownership would have to argue that these closely related form and only these closely related form fulfill the justificatory requirement
if the argument demonstrate that the closely related form fulfill the justificatory requirement without also demonstrate that other unrelated form fail to fulfill the requirement then the justification be only partial
any argument which ground a specific form of ownership upon some justificatory requirement without explain why other form can not be similarly ground fail to provide a complete justification and may also fail to provide reason for judge whether the form of ownership be morally permissible or morally require
gauthier as well as locke kant and nozick offer only a partial justification of private ownership
not only do gauthier never consider the possibility that other form of ownership might have the same result as private ownership but indeed there be other form of ownership which do have the same result
that be integral to his method as he see it
gauthier consider morality to be the product of agreement for cooperative interaction which be require to remedy the essential imperfection of the free market both the free market as a morally free zone and cooperative agreement to internalize external cost presuppose a impartial but not equal initial bargaining position of factor endowments this be to say that market presuppose people own something to exchange in the market and that bargaining presuppose that people start at some position of strength or weakness from which they may assess the value of various possible agreement
gauthier argue that in order for the output from the free market and from agreement to be moralize the input ie the initial position must be prove to be impartial
gauthier reject a equal initial position such as john rawls s because it permit free riders original impartial private appropriation be the necessary moral foundation which gauthier believe he need in order to moralize the output of the reason integral to gauthier s theory it must be notice that in general gift bequest and exchange be incomplete as criteria of title
each presuppose some additional criteria of title which would originally distribute legitimate title over thing so that individual could then transfer title by gift bequest or exchange
social contract theorist have solve the problem of original distribution in two different way
some have make the distribution prior to the contract while others have make the distribution part of the contract
rawls and hobbes make the distribution a result of the social contract
in the leviathan hobbes s contract empower the sovereign to make original distribution as well as to make the rule govern subsequent transfers rawls make the communal ownership of talent and ability part of the contract
by contrast hume and locke locate the original distribution in what exist prior to the convention or contract
for hume present possession at the time of the convention be the natural expedient for make the original labor on what be unowned as the criteria for his initial distribution
gauthier like hume and locke adopt the precontract rather than the contractdependent methodology
gauthier s justification of private ownership rest upon the following illustration
imagine that several person inhabit a island where the land and resource in effect constitute a commons available to all
use be in dividual each family provide primarily for its own need and interaction be noncooperative
suppose that eve the head of one of the family be aware that plan intensive cultivation would make the land more productive so that she propose to take a certain area of the island for her exclusive use in order that her family may benefit by maximize its productivity
she seek therefore a exclusive right to a certain portion of the island
eve seek the security of tenure which market compensation rather than full compensation confer
full compensation according to gauthier be compensation which leave a person without any net loss in utility
might realize through exchange
eve seek the more comprehensive protection which a right in the product of her labor would realize eve intend to better her family s situation through a system of right that determine her endowment for prospective market and cooperative interaction
gauthier argue that eve s appropriation need not be bring about by worsen the situation of the other islander
while eve might seek to appropriate a toolarge portion of the island which would violate the lockean proviso against worsen the situation of others there might be sufficiently abundant land such that she need not worsen the situation of others
eve s appropriation might be small enough and her increased productivity might be sufficiently large so that her fellow islander might be better off through exchange with her than they be before she privately appropriate her plot of land
gauthier conclude his derivation by show that if eve give up her right to the remaining commons and if eve s increased productivity would be beneficial to her as well as to others then her exclusive right of possession be in gauthier s word the great benefactress of human kind
""
i shall not at this point contest gauthier s conclusion that eve s appropriation can be beneficial both to herself and the other islander
in this section i shall assume that gauthier be right about eve s appropriation be beneficial
my problem with gauthier s method be that he give only a partial justification of possible form of appropriation in the state of nature
gauthier never consider other form of ownership in addition to private ownership that might be beneficial in much the same way as private ownership
the benefit of eve s private appropriation arise because intensive agriculture may produce great quantity of food per acre than unimproved land
vest in eve the right to use the land and the right to what she produce be necessary in order for eve rationally to undertake the labor of farming
as hobbes wisely maintain long ago agriculture as well as industry be not rational unless one can count upon the rightful possession of what if agriculture or industry be to be rationally undertake
while it be certainly true that private ownership vest in appropriator the right rationally need for such a undertaking it be just as certainly true that other possible form of ownership vest in appropriator right which satisfy the same rational necessity
gauthier s justification be only a partial justification because he do not consider form other than private ownership
suppose instead of eve s private appropriation that a group of person karl friedrich and rosa agree to collectively appropriate land for the purpose of intensive cultivation they agree to share evenly both the work of farming and the product produce
with their increased productivity karl friedrich and rosa could exchange their product with the other islander as do eve
this form of collective ownership have the same economic consequence in the state of nature as do eve s private appropriation
thus if eve s appropriation be morally justifiable then so be the collective appropriation by karl friedrich and s term sufficiently compensate any losers 
such collective ownership in itself might be a morally compatible alternative to eve s private appropriation which could be practice along with private ownership without any moral incoherence
but collective ownership could far evolve by stage consistent with gauthier s justification into a form of ownership which be morally very different from private ownership
this collective ownership by karl friedrich and rosa could evolve within the confine establish by gauthier into a islandwide social ownership
imagine that the other islander see the success achieve by karl friedrich and rosa so that they too desire to join the collective
so instead of exchange what they produce with the collective the other islander judge themselves better off by join the collective as coworker
since the land collectively farm could be expand or the number of product could be multiply karl friedrich and rosa could judge themselves better off as well
all islander might see the advantage of social ownership and management of the island
they could agree to social selfmanagement and ownership of the land and resource on the island 
neither the collective ownership by karl friedrich and rosa nor the social ownership by all the islander need be equivalent to private ownership in its variant form of joint or corporate ownership
such private ownership right as bequest exchange or alienation need not be include in the right which vest in the member of the collective
the form of ownership may not permit any right to alienate the land that be identify with the people who live on it
such be the case marx cite of primitive form of communism as well as with the concept of ownership hold by native american tribe
that karl rosa and friedrich agree to cooperate do not violate gauthier s assumption about human motivation
gauthier defend a subjective theory of value
a person be consider preference determine her reason for choice and action
even though gauthier s basic motivational assumption be the subjective theory of value he sometimes describe his or nontuistic
several commentator have note that gauthier s description be not equivalent a subjective theory of value do not logically limit a person s motivation only to choice that be selfinterested or nontuistic
someone may prefer to advance the interest of others eg the interest of friend and lovedones
selfinterest and nontuism of course limit the content of preference
gauthier have recently say that his selfinterest assumption be to prevent doublecounting in utility calculation such a practice would count some preference twice and thus upset pareto optimality gauthier s reply do not explain why the decision by karl rosa and friedrich to cooperate need violate his assumption whether it be describe as the subjective theory of value or as selfinterested
if karl rosa and friedrich prefer to cooperate then there be no incompatibility with a subjective theory of value

first of all as i remark early social contract theorist have deal with the problem of initial distribution by both precontract and contractdependent methodology

ownership and scarcity
in this section i shall focus upon the issue of scarcity in the state of nature
specifically and contrary to gauthier s expressed argument i shall show that eve s private appropriation can only fulfill the condition of the proviso against worsen the condition of others in extremely unrealistic conditions i shall show that the condition in which eve s appropriation be unlikely to violate the proviso be exceptional rather than condition which be generally fulfil
thus gauthier s justification may be successful only in exceptional circumstance
moreover in such exceptional circumstance any form of ownership would be unnecessary
gauthier seem to be aware of the problem of define scarcity realistically since he correctly admit that not be fulfil in any actual circumstances locke s criteria that a act of appropriation must leave enough and as good for others to appropriate could only be fulfil if object of appropriation be to exist in such superabundance that no act of appropriation diminish the amount others may still appropriate
one of locke s own example aptly illuminate this point
locke ask who could complain be someone to take a large draught of water from a great river if enough water remain for everyone else to do the same gauthier realize that neither land nor resource actually exist in such superabundance
but gauthier do not seem to realize that be locke s criteria fulfil no form of ownership whatsoever would be necessary
hume be well aware of this when he argue that scarcity be a necessary prerequisite of have any form of ownership
it be only because good of the world be scarce that ownership rule be necessary be good as superabundant as the water in locke s river there would be no need to objection to gauthier s use of a state of nature justification differ from a objection raise by david braybrooke
braybrooke argue that gauthier s contract unlike locke s can not be apply in history because of its fantastic demand on information which no contracting party could meet braybrooke focus upon the empirical impossibility of ever fulfil the condition of the contract
my point be different in that it rest on a conceptual not a empirical difficulty
i shall not be concerned about whether gauthier s stateofnature condition ever historically exist
my objection be that if gauthier s stateofnature condition could be fulfil there would be no reason to have any form of ownership whatsoever
the historical question about whether or not the condition of gauthier s state of nature ever could be fulfil be not crucial
gauthier s premise that eve s appropriation not worsen the condition of others seem to acknowledge that land do not exist in superabundance
the implication seem to be that eve s appropriation could make others bad off so that in a fixed limited supply
gauthier s assumption of scarcity appear realistic enough to avoid the unrealistic abundance which hume believe make ownership unnecessary
but once gauthier s assumption be examine more closely it be not at all obvious that eve s appropriation will not violate the proviso unless land exist in a unrealistically abundant quantity
gauthier argue that even though eve s appropriation of land may worsen the condition of the other islander because they lose the use of eve s land eve s increased productivity will actually enable her to improve the condition of the others
gauthier s argument be similar to the kaldorhicks improvement condition where one state of affair be judge better than another if the winner be able to but need not actually compensate the losers gauthier believe that eve s great efficiency and productivity will enable her to compensate the loser so that no one be make bad off but gauthier do not present any specific argument to support his belief
such argument would have to demonstrate that eve can be sufficiently productive be therefore necessary to estimate eve s productivity and the other islander s loss
what be the benefit eve and her family receive gauthier claim she intend to benefit herself and her family by a more efficient and productive cultivation of her land
gauthier far assume that those benefit eve seek must derive from a increased quantity of food which will be exchange with the other islander
eve might however have choose to benefit herself and her family by use her increased efficiency in production to create great leisure for her and her family
there be nothing in gauthier s subjective theory of value to preclude eve from judge her leisure as a benefit
obviously for gauthier leisure be not the kind of benefit eve must produce in order for her appropriation to be justifiable because it would not enable her to compensate the others
the gain that eve must intend to produce for herself and her family must be benefit that be divisible exchangeable and value by the other islander
eve must therefore intend better housing or clothing for her family
in any case the quantity of exchanageable material good which eve must produce in order to justify her appropriation will depend upon the loss of the other islander
the other islander lose their use of eve s land the right to manage it the income from it the fight to trespass hunt gather and so on which before eve s appropriation they have in common
these can be significant loss
if the quantity of land on the island be large compare to the population this reduce the value of the loss of land due to eve s appropriation
but by the same reasoning if the population be large compare to quantity of land the loss will be substantial
suppose for the sake of argument that the only benefit or loss relevant to eve s appropriation be the food supply
this be a much too narrow assumption in light of the variety of right which the islander lose to eve but gauthier s derivation depend upon unrealistic assumption about the land
grant this assumption the increase in eve s food production must be great than the loss of naturally available food the islander could appropriate before eve s appropriation
gauthier assert without argument that eve can produce more food by agriculture than be available before her appropriation
intensive agriculture may not however always be more abundantly productive
a great deal depend upon the level of technology the fertility of the soil the amount of rainfall the length of the growing season and so forth
it be possible to imagine many counterinstances in which our ecosystem might not be make more productive through intensive agriculture
land in some arid climate might produce grass suitable for graze wild animal but be much too dry for raise vegetable and fruit
in some tropical rain forest topsoil would be wash away if the forest be clear for intensive agriculture
in such case eve s private appropriation would not be justifiable because she could not satisfy produce sufficient surplus food
these counterinstances may not be a objection to gauthier s argument if he be try to show that private appropriation be justifiable only under some special condition
gauthier may not be argue that private appropriation be always rationally justifiable because he do not believe either that the free market or moral by agreement be always rational
but if this be gauthier s intention he would have to show that the two failure be extensionally equivalent ie he would have to argue that private appropriation fail where and only where both the free market and moral by agreement be also irrational
gauthier would have to show that there be no possible example such as a simple pastoral society in which both the free market and moral by agreement be rational yet the land lack sufficient fertility for intensive agriculture to produce additional food
gauthier to my knowledge never address this point
still to give gauthier s argument a sympathetic reading attention may be focus upon the condition in which and her family
this surplus must be sufficiently large to compensate all those who lose by eve s appropriation
but to render this argument germane to the actual circumstance eve must confront it be necessary to drop the assumption that food be the only good which be gain or lose by eve and the other islander
gauthier must therefore prove that eve s surplus be great than the loss of others
even with this expanded assumption only some of eve s gain be relevant to calculate her ability to compensate the loser
as previously note eve could not choose to benefit herself with great leisure because these benefit be not divisible and exchangeable with others
nor could eve use her spare time to manufacture widget unless widget be value by the other islander
eve s gain be thus in principle easy to measure ie eve s gain be a specific quantity of foodstuff and perhaps raw material for clothing and shelter which she can offer in exchange
the loss incur by the other islander lose the right to hunt and gather on eve s land
they lose the right to trespass upon her land
and they lose the right to any of the natural resource such as water which may exist upon her land
the size and value of their loss can not be calculate in any general or abstract way
any gain and loss of each act of private appropriation have to be calculate in each particular case
suppose for example that the land eve select for intensitive cultivation be unremarkable except for its location in a flat valley between two mountain and eve s cultivation prevent others use the valley for passage between the mountain
the value of the lost right to trespass could conceivably be great than the value of the surplus eve produce especially if many lose the right to traverse her land
eve s appropriation of the flat land might also reduce land space for the others to build living quarter
eve s land may be a breeding ground for rabbit which be easily multiply
gauthier must assume in order for this argument to be plausible in general that amply productive land be the rule not the exception
if his argument be to justify private appropriation of land as a impartial original bargaining position he must assume that good fertile land be not so scarce that counterinstances arise only in rare or exceptional circumstance
not only do gauthier fail to supply argument to support his assumption that land be sufficiently abundant he also supply no argument to show that eve s primitive attempt at intensive agriculture can actually produce the required surplus
gauthier must provide such argument if his justification of private appropriation be to have any general plausibility
otherwise gauthier s argument at best show that private appropriation be justify only in a few special circumstance
i do not think there be general argument show that land exist in the abundance which gauthier s justification require
even if it be possible to show that unowned land do at some early time exist in such a would be successful
first it be questionable what relevance such abundance would now have for the issue of justify ownership of scarce land and resource
braybrooke s argument about the lack of historical applicability be relevant here
it do not seem to be rational to agree to govern our behavior in general and under all condition by moral rule which presuppose circumstance that be rarely encounter in our experience
second and more important the abundance of land require to make gauthier s argument plausible be likely to make the need for ownership moot
in order to minimize the loss which need to be compensate unowned land would have to be so plentiful that it be difficult to see the need for any form of ownership at all
no one would have a reason to try to interfere with eve under condition of abundance because the cost of interference would likely be high than the cost of appropriate without interfere with eve
the other islander would not logically have to acknowledge that eve have right over what she in these special circumstance they should not interfere with eve s appropriation because noninterference be most costeffective
as kraus and coleman point out the motive for rational individual in the state of nature to cooperate be the existence of costs but if eve s appropriation require so much abundance that there be practically no cost to others there be no need for any right of ownership eve can simply be ignore
as hume argue and as locke s river illustrate in abundance there be no need for ownership
gauthier s argument thus seem plausible because he presuppose unrealistic condition of abundance which render any form of land ownership unnecessary
