ownership as theft
i borrow this title from proudhon not primarily because i believe that private ownership of land and resource be theft although i do believe it but because it point to a major difficulty in the form of ownership which gauthier attempt to justify in the previous section i have ignore the difference between gauthier s form of ownership argument with gauthier
i shall now show that gauthier s form of ownership warrant take what someone own without his permission hence the idea that gauthier s form of ownership resemble theft
the concept of private ownership must first be clarify in order to contrast it with gauthier s form
i shall rely upon am honore s work and define private ownership as be constitute by the right to possess the right to use the right to manage the right to income the right to the capital the right to security the right of transmissibility and absence of term honore s concept be consistent with that of john locke who say for truly i have no property in that which another can by right take from me against my consent
 let me call this locke s nontheft condition
this condition imply that the right which vest in private owner may not be take away against the owner s consent
while gauthier sometimes appear to recognize locke s nontheft of private ownership in other crucial places his form of ownership actually warrant take what another own without his consent
not only do gauthier violate locke s nontheft condition but his form of ownership may not be capable of actually be practice because of this violation
gauthier be well aware that his form of ownership differ from private ownership
eve the orignal appropriator do not gain all of the right enumerate on honore s list
eve do not first of all get the right to all use of her land nor secondly do she get the right to all possible income
if eve appropriate her plot of land with the intention of farming gauthier argue that her right of use over the land do not extend to any oil or other valuable mineral which might subsequently be discover on the land
gauthier s reason be that own the oil or mineral be not part of eve s original intention in appropriate the land and also that such a appropriation might make eve unclear why gauthier believe eve s original intention be relevant to the right of use she acquire over what she appropriate although he do follow kant here especially since intention be opaque or occur under a particular description while eve might appropriate the land with the intention of farming it might also be correct to describe her intention as a desire to use the land in any way that will maximize her family s utility
would gauthier have to concede that under this second description eve should receive the right to use any oil or other valuable mineral there be additional problem
suppose as in gauthier s original example eve do not obtain right over the subsurface mineral resource
if at some later time rosa wish to purchase eve s land in order to develop the mineral resource and assume rosa would not be a monopolist rosa could not acquire the mineral right with eve s land because eve do not have those right to sell
who have those right gauthier of the island collectively could exercise the right to subsurface mineral assume that anyone have those right
to vest right over what one own according to the intention at initial appropriation would create significant indeterminacy in actually practice gauthier s form of ownership
it would be difficult to prove where there be controversy what the initial appropriator s intention be at the time she first appropriate
after her death it may be impossible to ever establish beyond doubt what her intention be
ultimately it may become impossible to know what right owner may exercise over particular parcel of land especially since these right will vary from parcel to parcel because of the variety of initial intention
limit the use and management right of owner by their original intention make gauthier s form of ownership different from and much more restricted than private ownership where owner be not limit by their original intention
private ownership vest in owner be a unlimited right to use and manage what they own as they choose as long as they behave within a appropriator develop unowned land with a original intention of growing food but subsequently decide to use the land for a jogging track
private ownership which vest in owner the right to use the land as they please would permit this kind of change of use
private ownership would even permit the owner to let the land lie unused in any way
gauthier s form of ownership as he defend it would not permit a owner to change the use in this way
gauthier would have to argue that because a jogging track be not part of the original intention provided the intention could be determine and because the jogging track might not produce as much utility for everyone as do the growing of food the owner might not have any right to alter the use to which the land be put
the second difference between private ownership and gauthier s form illustrate how gauthier violate locke s nontheft condition
this difference concern the right to the income from what one own
gauthier believe rent produce by what they own
gauthier use the example of the income wayne gretzky may rightfully earn from the use of his self and his labor private ownership would vest in gretzky the right to any income he could obtain without force or fraud in a free market
gauthier argue that gretzky do not have this right
gretzky have no right to a income which exceed the minimum need to induce him to play hockey his marginal productivity because economic efficiency would not be achieve be he pay a premium or factor rent for his relatively scarce skill
this difference between the two set of ownership right be justify according to gauthier because his form promote economic efficiency and utility maximization in circumstance where a private ownership freemarket form do not
gauthier generalize from the gretzky example when he say in the state of nature if not always in society efficient use be a condition of rightful possession
although right be temporally openended they be subject to alteration in light of changed the right which vest in owner and may change the person in whom the fight vest
owner may lose right over what they own or even lose the thing they own if economic efficiency and utility could thereby be promote
the owner s consent be not a requirement according to gauthier for owner to lose what they own
thus locke s nontheft condition be clearly violate
locke s idea of private ownership and honore be as well do not restrict private owner to only economically efficient and utilitymaximizing use of what they own
there be a unresolvable problem which gauthier fail to notice when he say that in the state of nature efficient use be a condition of rightful possession
efficient use can only be measure after market be establish
market however presuppose not only that people already own something to exchange but also that the right over what they own be define and determinate
economic value depend upon the right which can be acquire
gauthier can not employ efficient use as make sense if the criteria for vest right be already presuppose
not only do gauthier s form of ownership violate locke s nontheft condition his form of ownership also violate what i call hume s dictum
hume s dictum be that possession must be stable no matter what else ownership rule happen to do not only must people be able to know what they own and what their right be but they must be able to know under what condition they may lose right over what they own and importantly be able to more or less control the condition under which they lose their right to what they own
gauthier s example of eve s appropriation rely upon the wisdom contain in hume s dictum
eve must be able to rely upon a fairly uninterrupted possession of her land in order for her improvement of the land to be rational
she must be able to count upon recoup her cost
if eve expect to enjoy the benefit of her labor she must be without any interference from others
other must not have the right to take what she improve and produce
this be why gauthier be correct in argue that some form of ownership be a necessary prerequisite for eve rationally to undertake her economically beneficial farming
ignore for the moment the circularity in attempt to define rightful possession in the state of nature by the criteria of efficient use gauthier do not seem to appreciate that his own condition of efficient use may undermine the stability of possession
suppose that the very real problem of decide who be to judge who be a efficient user and who be to judge efficient use for which purpose can somehow be resolve there be still the difficulty that deciding ownership upon efficient use may render possession too unstable to be efficiently develop or use
in the treatise hume discuss just this point he consider a actutilitarian criteria of title which would vest the right of ownership in person who could make the best use of what be own
the problem hume see with this criteria uncertain
 a person who might make the best use of something today might not be the person who could make the best use of it tomorrow
this uncertainty may deter owner from make investment in what they own because others might be able to make more economically efficient use of it
eve for example might be deter from improve her land for farming if she fear that rosa might find a still more efficient use and rightfully claim the land
allocate ownables by a criteria of best or efficient use may paradoxically imply less good or efficient use because people may refrain from risky investment and improvement
efficient use be selfdefeating where it violate hume s dictum
ownership be less secure in gauthier s form of ownership than in private ownership
gauthier might try to respond to this criticism by claim that in actual practice ownership will not be so uncertain as to undermine economically desirable improvement and investment
his argument will have to be ground upon premise concerning risk propensity and aversion ongoing debate over whether a propensity or aversion to risk be subject to rational assessment or whether it be merely a psychological disposition
even if it could be establish that there be rational condition for risk gauthier would still need to argue that his efficient use criteria would leave ownership sufficiently certain and stable for risk to be rational
but be such argument possible they could not be absolute or general
gauthier would have to examine actual condition in order to estimate the effect of his criteria of ownership on certainty and stability of possession in relation to rational risk
i have ignore gauthier s point that compensation may be pay to the less efficient user if what be own be appropriate by a more efficient user require compensation will reduce risk uncertainty and instability
i ignore compensation to isolate the problem in violate hume s dictum
compensation as gauthier be aware do lessen the problem
but lessen the problem in this case may or may not remove it
if compensation be person whose right be appropriate can establish the value to her of what be take away then ownership may not be sufficiently uncertain to violate hume s dictum
but a subjective evaluation of the level of compensation do not guarantee economic efficiency in fact it may obstruct economic efficiency eg in case where homeowner refuse even outrageously large offer from real estate developer
the idea of market value compensation might be think to be more appropriate
market value compensation be problematic as i note early discuss gretzky and efficient use because market value as well as efficiency presuppose determinate criteria for rightful possession
even so in situation where market value be less than subjective value the problem of uncertainty would not be solve
for high risk or for very costly improvement gauthier s efficient use criteria even with the payment of compensation may have the effect of reduce economic efficiency rather than promote it
i therefore do not believe gauthier have avoid the difficulty hume see in violate his dictum
 form of ownership which closely resemble private ownership by a argument from original appropriation in the state of nature fail in the way all such argument fail
they fail because of the unrealistic condition which must be presuppose and because of the partial questionbegging argument which be employ
i have show that even gauthier s ingenious argument fail to overcome the problem inherent in all stateofnature derivation
thus my contention that all stateofnature derivation fail still hold without exception
philosopher must avoid try to justify ownership by this unrealistic and therefore irrelevant method
gauthier s justification of a form of ownership also have problem which be independent of his method of argument
unlike private ownership gauthier s form of ownership justify sometimes rightfully take what a person own without that person s consent
this violation of locke s nontheft condition may also lead to a violation of hume s dictum
i have discuss these violation more fully in my book under the heading of the necessary logical structure of ownership
the failure of form of ownership demonstrate that philosopher
as philosopher continue to try to find moral justification for a form of ownership they must first show that the form they be try to justify fulfill the necessary logical requirement of ownership
instead of rely upon state of nature argument philosopher need to follow a methodology i have call a schema of justification a schema of justification illustrate the application of concept to actual empirical condition
a moral justification of a form of ownership would have to fulfill three task
first the form of ownership would have to be show to meet the necessary logical structure of all form of ownership second the form of ownership would have to either be derive from some rationally ground moral principle or if rational grounding be judge impossible be show to be consistent with our fundamental moral intuition
and third the actual societal condition in which the form of ownership be to be apply must be examine to determine what the rationally ground moral principle or our fundamental moral intuition require in each specific circumstance
always be able to demonstrate how to rectify injustice which occur in any actual circumstance but no methodology that i know of seem to be capable of accomplish such a task
a schema of justification nevertheless avoid the oversimplification and abstraction inherent in stateofnature argument
a schema of justification guarantee moral relevance
and because a schema of justification require that form of ownership be test against the necessary logical structure of all form of ownership there be a guarantee that it be at least possible to put the form of ownership into actual practice
james o grunebaum
buffalo state college
over the last decade and a half a group of philosopher have argue that justice be equivalent to or at least involve the historically base entitlement of a person to certain objects the principle which identify the source of those entitlement define a set of right hold by all human being according to these author
when this historical entitlement theory be conjoin to a theory of selfownership it constitute the libertarian theory of justice a theory which identify justice with the rightful entitlement of person to themselves and to certain object that they acquire by specified mean and to the freedom to use both as they choose
as such it be more than merely a theory of distributive justice for it delineate what it take to be a exhaustive list of right some of which be distributive or economic right but one of which be a right of selfownership which imply a right of selfgovernance or personal liberty
moreover this exhaustive list specify according to the libertarian both the purpose of governmental this list as well as its legitimate boundary ie the obligation to protect only those right and the duty to refrain from violation of them
while various aspect of this libertarian conception of justice have be laboriously investigate little attention have be devote to its implication for the theory of civil and criminal remediation this essay be a attempt to rectify that omission
in it i will argue that the libertarian theory in particular as explicate by nozick have certain implication for the theory of remediation that be startle and oppose to his own view about the appropriate public response to wrongdoing
specifically i will argue first that the libertarian thesis both entail a restitutionist and compensatory theory of remediation and exclude punitive remedial principles accordingly i will also maintain that the conception of toolong arise from libertarian consideration require the elimination of the criminal law as we know it
finally i will argue that libertarian theory as frame by nozick can not offer any justification for capital punishment but certain category of wrongdoer
along the way i will contend that some of these unexpected result arise due to the exiguous grounding provide for the libertarian scheme of justice by nozick and i will suggest that their resolution require a more robust ethical foundation
that recommended foundation however will only advance the case for compensatory remedy where restitution be not available
it will not provide support for criminal sanction as we traditionally conceive of them

remediation and justice
in order to determine which theory of remediation be entail by the libertarian thesis it will be necessary to formulate the view of justice which be expound in that thesis and the concomitant theory of wrongdoing which be imply by it
justice as conceivedof by libertarian theorist consist in the preservation of one s freedom of action with respect to those object to which one have legitimate title
these object include one s person and those extrapersonal object which one have justly acquire
to such object the holder have exclusive title
another category and unappropriated extrapersonal object as long as these action be take in accordance with certain rule which assure to all actor compatible sphere of autonomy
so define this conception of justice implicitly specify what sort of action be not in agreement with it ie be unjust those which consist in the use of object to which one do not have appropriate title but to which another person do or in the damage ie the alteration of such object
thus action in any society govern by strict application of libertarian principle will be consider rightful if they be take with respect to object own by their user if they be take with respect to object wherein permission have be voluntarily grant by the owner to another person to make use of them or if they be take with respect to object over which as in the case of unowned and unappropriated object one have certain usufructuary right
action which employ or alter object not own by their may employ suitable defense to prevent or resist such action
while the question of what would constitute a suitable defense be interesting enough the principal focus of this paper will be on what the appropriate ie the just response to a successfully complete unjust action of this kind ought to be
such a response could conceivably fall into one of three broad category response which seek recompense for the victim those which attempt solely to affect in some way the wrongdoer or some combination of the two
furthermore it be clear that unjust action can affect either one s extrapersonal holding or oneself or both
while it be obvious at least in outline what kind of act would be impermissible within a code of entitlementprotecting statute the sanction that would be provide for in that code be not immediately evident
would the law confine itself to the compensation of offended party or would it alternatively or additionally provide for punitive sanction would the latter if a disrupted moral balance by exact a retribution or would they be assign in order to prevent instance of wrongdoing in the future and if punitive remedy be inappropriate to a entitlement conception of justice what sanction would conform to it in case of personal injury where the realized harm be intend by its perpetrator and more problematically in the limiting case of murder
generally we can say that if any category of attempted remedial action systematically fail to restore a transgress entitlement it can not be the response require by the libertarian theory of justice because it fail to redress the particular injustice identify by that theory
that is there may be other ground for recommend such a response but they be not one provide by the libertarian thesis
furthermore if a suggested response to wrongdoing itself violate someone s right it be forbid by this theory of justice

the nature of rightful entitlement
the appropriate response to various category of wrongdoing according to entitlement theory must be of a rightful action in a entitlement context
such a analysis be embody in the following principle definition of rightful title a title to a human object be rightful if and only if it be claim with respect to one s own person
a title to a nonhuman object be rightful if and only if it be acquire by nozick s principle of justice in acquisition nja or nozick s principle of justice in transfer njt
a rightful title to a object o under description d be retain by its owner even if o be transform to on under dn
rightful title to any object be attain only by 
definition of rightfuluse action a action a be rightful and hence permissible if the actor a employ object human or nonhuman to which he have rightful title
a action a be rightful and hence permissible if the actor a employ previously untitled object according to nja
a action a employ object to which he do not have title with the uncoerced permission of those who do and only in way specify by them
no action be permissible except when perform in accordance with 
principle of rightfultransformation action a object o may be transform to on by a actor a if he have rightful title to it
a untitled object ou may be transform to oun by a actor a according to and only accord to nja
a object which be own by another may be transform with and only with the uncoerced permission of its rightful owner and only in way specify by him
no act of transformation be rightful except when perform in accordance with 
we conclude then that a wrongful action be one which violate the principle of rightfuluse action or the principle of rightfultransformation action
the wrong produce consist either of the illicit use of a object belong to another the illicit transformation of a object belong to another of a unowned object the wrongful act emerge from be implicitly define by nja
since nja be a largely undeveloped principle within contemporary entitlement theory and a subject of great controversy we will not attempt to characterize the wrongful act generate by violation of it
however the wrong describe by clearly consist in deprive the rightful owner of the use of his object o from time t to tn while the wrong delineate by consist in deprive the rightful owner of the use of his object o from t to tn and leave him with the use of the altered object on to which he retain title
in the former case he have be deprive of the use and fruit of use o from t to tn only
in the latter case he have be deprive of the use and fruit of the use of o permanently begin at t and obtain the use of which he be deprive in both instance be rightfully his the commission of the wrongful act in either case require that these use and effect be restore to him
however as they can not be perfectly restore to him in either case since the time interval during which he be deprive of the object s use be permanently lose to him and the object in the second case have be alter he have the right to claim their imperfect or approximate restoration
once this restoration have take place then according to entitlement theory the entitlement have be restore and hence the wrong however imperfectly and approximately have be remedy

the entitlement theory and punishment
appropriate punitive measure for wrongdoing without undercut the entitlement theory in his philosophical explanation nozick be unequivocal in his support for retributive punishment while throughout anarchy state and utopia he seem to assume that there be no theoretical opposition between his libertarianism and punitive remedy for wrongdoing
we may test the correctness of this assumption by answer two question
first can punishment whether employ for deterrence incapacitation or retribution be derive as a principle of remediation from libertarian theory second if it can not be so derive be punishment at least compatible with libertarian principle
let us consider the two type of wrongdoing to which we previously allude the illicit use of a object belong to another and the illicit tranformation of a object belong to another
let us expand the second category of wrongdoing so as to include the illicit destruction or consumption of object
restated then 
would proscribe the illicit transformation destruction or consumption of libertarian theory endorse both a principle of selfentitlement as well as a principle of the historical entitlement of human being to nonhuman object let us be careful to understand that and apply both to human and nonhuman object
now we may ask once restitution or compensation for wrong or have be achieve can any far remedy for them be exact on entitlement ground this be our derivation question
the answer to this question seem to be no
if the removal of a entitlement be the wrong created restoration of that entitlement or suitable compensation for its loss be the only possible remedy that can serve as a moral corrective
as for the possible imprisonment of the wrongdoer such a action must be instrumental to the restorative process in order to be give a entitlement justification
if for example it could be argue that a thief would not make his victim whole unless incarcerate and compel to do so then his imprisonment would be the entitlement theory then would seem to sanction only restitution or compensation as a appropriate moral response to wrongdoing
punishment when not implement as a mean of either restore transgress entitlement or produce recompense for them become a morally superfluous exercise
since the wrongful act must always be measure only in terms of its effect upon the offended holder or his duly appoint beneficiary of a entitlement any action take either purely in order to punish the wrongdoer or to prevent or inhibit future criminal action while it may be morally compatible with the libertarian criteria of justice receive no additional support from it
these two point require far elaboration
first there be the matter of punishment
it might be argue that entitlement theory in fact do entail some retributivist component as it must or ought to distinguish between degree of culpability by add to compensatory remedy punitive one as well
surely it may be contend the law should not assign the same sanction for manslaughter as it do for murder be identical the extent of responsibility for each offense differ vastly
libertarian theory it can be maintain ought to recognize this difference by insinuate a retributive constituent into its conception of criminal justice
but while the libertarian theorist be not preclude from acknowledge the full spectrum of moral culpability which can attend any harmful act there be no room for the inclusion of the culpability factor in his formulation of just response to wrongdoing
injustice consist wholly in illicit taking or damage
hence justice must consist exclusively in replacement restoration or compensation from a specific individual or individual
furthermore any additional action take against the person or holding of a wrongdoer beyond what be require either for the restoration of taken or damaged entitlement to the victim or for the compensation of the victim where restoration be impossible will result in a violation of the right of the wrongdoer not a justifiable remedial response to his wrongdoing
thus if a object belong to a be take forcibly from him by b a suitable remedy would be the return of the object plus the return of whatever benefit would have accrue to a during its absence and the compensation for any consequential damage suffer by a as a result of its removal
the principle involve here be that a be entitlement and their fruit to which ceteris paribus he would also be entitle be illicitly take by b and therefore be owe to him by b however to take more from b than be remove or damage by him be to take from him what be own by him and be not owe by him to anyone else
criminal debt on entitlement ground can only arise from the nonconsensual taking or alteration by someone of a entitlement that be not his
once that debt be discharge by the wrongdoer any additional forcible taking of object including his physical person own by the wrongdoer constitute the illicit seizure of a unencumbered entitlement and hence be itself a wrongdoing
punitive reaction to the nonconsensual use of the wrongdoer s entitlement be itself a wrong and as such require restitutive remedy
and if this be true for punishment which seek retribution from the actor for his moral error then it be true as well for punishment whose purpose be to deter or prevent by incapacitation or forcible rehabilitation the commission of future wrongful act
therefore entitlement theory not only fail to provide justification for punitive measure which exceed what be require to make rightful restitution andor compensation but it imply the wrongfulness of such measure
thus the answer to our second question be that the use of punishment as a remedy for wrongdoing be incompatible with libertarian theory
now this implication be surprising enough suggest as it do that libertarian theorist must argue for the elimination of the criminal law leave only tort and contract law in its place
however a still strong result become apparent when one begin to consider what sort of sanction libertarian theory can endorse for murder
while libertarian theory could subscribe to the view the victim for the loss of the future estate to which they would have be title and that he must suffer the loss of sufficient freedom to assure the fulfillment of that obligation it can hardly recommend that in addition he lose his life
for what would be restore in the process the life of his victim would not thereby be recover nor would the murderer s execution restore or repair any of the entitlement of the victim s heir
for these heir be not entitle to the victim who like all human being be according to libertarian theory entitle to himself
moreover once these heir have be compensate no far debt remain to be discharge
the execution of the murderer then would not only fail to serve a compensatory purpose it would be wrong as well for it would deprive the murderer of his entitlement to his physical person
it may be maintain against this disturbing result that the murderer have take the life of another own life imply the appropriateness or the absence of the inappropriateness of his execution or at least of his imprisonment beyond the term necessary to assure the recompense of the victim s heir
but what would be the basis of such a claim within libertarian theory perhaps the libertarian could contend that in take the life of his victim the murderer create a debt which can only be discharge through the taking of his own life
but to whom would this debt be own certainly the libertarian entitlement theorist can not argue that the debt be owe the family or heir of the victim for the entitlement conception adhere to the view that each person and therefore the victim be the exclusive owner of his own person
similarly the debt can not be literally owe the victim who be obviously in no position to collect
nor can the debt be owe to society its member have not be deprive of any of their entitlement through this murder
only one circumstance might ground
if someone unsuccessfully attempt to murder but nevertheless injure another and his victim require the transplantation of a organ in order to survive the injury that organ may be wrest from the attacker even if that should jeopardize the assailant s own life
if without the transfer of his own life to another the assailant will have successfully deprive another of his existence then the attacker become a debtor whose life if need be may be take to restore the life of his victim
give the radical restorationism imply by the libertarian entitlement theory it be not surprising that one of its adherent have defend restitution as a substitute for punishment in the allocation of criminal justice
what randy barnett in a essay argue for the elimination of retributivist and utilitarian standard of criminal justice do not do be to explicitly link his restitutionism to the entitlement theory so obviously embrace by him
what be surprising be that one of his critic also a libertarian entitlement theorist have maintain
that the civil remedy by itself be altogether inadequate in the case of criminal act
for the element miss from the mere tort but present in the criminal act be the guilty mind
the criminal have not simply harm you
he have affront your dignity
he have intentionally use you against your will for his own end
he can not simply pay damage as though his action be accidental or unintentional
how would this right the wrong 
therefore pilon argue
the original act thus create a right in the victim to use the criminal as he himself be use
only so will the party be treat as equal
for only so will the character of the original act be reflect in the remedy 
now this argument be ingenious it may even be correct
however in order for it to go through pilon must transcend the entitlement conception of justice that manifestly inform his view for it simply be not imply by that conception count among one s entitlement or holding as nozick call them a affronted dignity can not constitute a damaged property
however dignity may be characterize its status as a holding be dubious for it be neither a mental capacity like intelligence judgment memory nor a physical one
if dignity be not a holding or property its damage do not create a debt in its assailant that may be claim by the affronted party
clearly the libertarian entitlement theory alone will neither support nor tolerate punitive remedy
if such remedy be desirable on other ground adherent of the libertarian entitlement theory must import other complementary principle on which to make a defense of them or abandon the entitlement theory altogether
if the former appear unattainable and the latter be unattractive the libertarian theoretician must be content with restitutive or compensatory mean of rectify injustice

john locke believe that each person have a natural right to hold property particularly the fruit of his own labor it be through the mixing of one s own labor with land and its product that a right to appropriate and own property arise
but that right as we all know be subject to what robert nozick call and what have since become familiar as locke s proviso
 thus a integral part of locke s defense of private property turn on its omnipresent availability for appropriation in the state of nature
that is there must be unclaimed land as well as the produce of land free for the taking
the original appropriation of property by one person can be just only if enough and as good be available to the rest of humanity 
enough and as good the proviso in the state of nature
what do locke mean by his proviso more specifically how egalitarian be it mean to be of nature the less it would seem able to justify unequal property right under condition of scarcity 
locke put forward his proviso in at least three place in his famous chapter xxv in the first appearance he say
 for this labor be the unquestionable property of the labourer no man but he can have a right to what that be once join to at least where there be enough and as good left in common for others emphasis add
in the second he say
 nor be this appropriation of any parcel of land by improve it any prejudice to any other man since there be still enough and as good left and more than the yet unprovided could use emphases in original
the third version be much less often identify and discuss but be nonetheless a clear formulation of the proviso
a man could appropriate property by mix his labor with it
 so that to entrench upon the right of another or acquire to himself a property to the prejudice of his neighbor who would still have room for as good and as large possession after the others have take out his as before it be appropriated emphasis add
do these three formulation imply that individual in the state of nature must be equal in property holding however we interpret property holding some writer suggest that a condition of equality in the stock of land and produce of the land must exist after a appropriation
in all case hereafter i mean by a appropriation of land a lockean appropriation perform by mix one s labor with it
alan ryan follow other contemporary commentator and translate the proviso as require as much and as good be leave to others even though locke never use such a formulation
vincent barry require that in the state of nature two condition exist the individual be equal where this second condition clearly refer to some sort of equality of resources 
could locke have mean by enough and as good that equal amount of property must be available to each person to appropriate in the state of nature could he have mean that people actually must appropriate and thereafter own equal amount of property for if either requirement be part of locke s starting point equality of resource loom far large as a desideratum for locke than we might otherwise think
this in turn might weaken a broadly lockean commitment to strong property right in poststateofnature condition of relative scarcity ie where the proviso do not hold
this be precisely the direction take by virginia hold vincent barry and others as we shall see
what then could locke have mean by enough and as good enough whatever else can not mean a equal amount
it refer to some other characteristic of what by he who have already appropriate land or good of the land
it seem to compare what others have before a appropriator call him a appropriate and what those same others have after a be appropriation and whether their position have be worsen
it could mean that there must be enough leave that those who have not yet appropriate land do not have so little leave as to make them suffer physical deprivation for lack of property
but there be no textual evidence for this
a more demanding requirement would be that others be no bad off for the appropriation
this i believe be clearly what locke mean
in the second formulation of the proviso locke add a strong conjunct to enough and as good
that be there must still be more left than those who have not yet appropriate could use
so if they have more than they could use before a appropriation and more than they could use after then relative amount as appropriate be irrelevant 
the third formulation give added credibility to this reading because it require as large a possession leave to be appropriate
and clearly here locke mean not as large as that appropriate by a but as large as be there before the appropriation
but how could as large a possession be leave after some of it have be appropriate obviously only if the amount of land and its produce be practically unlimited so that a single appropriation make no practical difference to the amount still available
indeed locke tell us just this in a passage follow the second formulation
so that in effect there be never less left for others because of his enclosure for himself
for he that leave as much as another can make use of do as good as take nothing at all emphasis add
a few line later he compare such enclosure of land to take a drink out of a river
do it make any practical sense to say that what could locke mean by as good which appear in all three formulation of the proviso it can not mean as much as a have appropriate since then the force of enough or as large in the third formulation would be nugatory
the preposition as must compare ex ante and ex post situation of those have not yet appropriate all those except a
it seem a simple requirement that the quality of the land which be leave be the same
this make a important point because locke believe in the enormous multiplicative effect of labor upon land
one reason why the proviso can plausibly be effective in the state of nature in addition to the vast amount of land available be that mixing labor with land so increase its value and the reward reap from it
locke begin by say labor can increase the value of land tenfold then a hundredfold and at one point a thousandfold the point be that of inequality than any slight discrepancy in size of original appropriation
if you appropriate two acre while i appropriate only one and we both leave our land unimproved you have twice what i do but if i get maximum value out of my land by great industry and application of reason i might end up with time your wealth while own only half your original amount of property
locke however make clear that he be totally indifferent to even such radical disparity in wealth so that equality per se must be completely irrelevant to him 
the remarkable power of labor to produce so vast a multiplication of wealth might help explain the force of as good
locke clearly think of property in chapter xxv as real property and its product
thus he must require that the acreage left be as responsive to labor input as it be before a appropriation else the overwhelming force of labor input to create wealth could be lose
i submit then by that as original value to labor improved value
concretely for agriculture he mean as fertile and arable

the realproperty paradigm
the heldbarry thesis logically depend upon what we might call a zerosum characteristic of property
this is land outside the state of nature where there be no frontier
all of locke s thought seem to be base on the identification of property with land and the agricultural product of land although this distinction be not always make clear

what be the zerosum characteristic of land as archetypal property there be three salient logical characteristic of real property
first if i own a oneacre piece of property blackacre let us call it i have a right to prevent you and all others from own or use that specific parcel of land
second without a practically unlimited source of property ie a frontier there be a finite and limited amount of land the amount be fix ie it will neither grow nor shrink
as my farmer neighbor in ohio say they ai nt makin any more of it
third from the first reduce the total stock of land by one acre which be available to you to use or acquire without payment
these three characteristic together create a zerosum conception of property
i gain one acre you and everyone else lose one
that just be zerosum in the very same sense as lord bad s appropriation deny the appropriated land to peasant good nice and kind in the enclosure case set out above
thus it be your be exclude in this way from enough land where there be nt unappropriated land for you to acquire which might lead to your suffering physical deprivation
the kind of transfer of property contemplate by hold and barry be base on the realproperty paradigm be zerosum
what logical prerequisite must exist in order to have private property characterize by the realproperty paradigm any property that can be hold in private must be excludable as we see with blackacre above
that is it must be possible to exclude others from its use and enjoyment
indeed public good those thing that be not subject to privatization eg clean air excludability seem to be entail by the very nature of the economic conception of private property
it be also central to the legal conception of private property of course the economist s and the lawyer s notion differ in that the former concern the practical physical ability and therefore the cost to exclude while the latter have to do with the normative power to exclude
as we see above there be a closely relate but distinct characteristic entail by the zerosum conception of property which be often confuse with excludability
if i claim blackacre as my own excludability will insure that no one else can own use or enjoy without suitable permission that particular piece of land viz blackacre

let us see if we can make these condition explicit
spell out formally we may say that the zerosum characteristic of property be define by the exclusion condition ownership of xxp a specific individually identifiable piece of property ie xxp be a name by a imply that all others those not a be exclude from possession and use of xxp without the permission of a the finitude condition there be only xxn thing of type xxp of which xxp be a token in the world where xxn be a practically finite number ie small enough to offer genuine constraint scarcity in the economist s sense

as one would expect the real property paradigm use these three condition work extremely well for land with no frontier outside the state of nature

how well do these three condition work for other sort of property nonrenewable resource be by definition finite in quantity and that make all tangible personal property in some very abstract sense limit

soon if not now we will find all these resource practically limit
if this be the case then all tangible personal property manufacture from those resource be or soon will be practically limit in amount
for the reason cite above this claim may not be very realistic
nonetheless we shall assume that all tangible personal property be practically limit
this constitute a very strong and i would say highly artificial presumption in favor of hold s and barry s use of locke s proviso argument
thus tangible personal property be subject to the objection that accumulation lead to deprivation ie i can only get more by deny a equal amount to others
the kind of property most important to modern western capitalism however be intangible
the traditional legal distinction between tangible and intangible property be that the former be corporeal and therefore subject to physical dominion while intangible property be incorporeal and abstract
 intangible property include patent copyright trademark commonlaw trade secret and the vastly important domain of financial asset such as stock and bond
now come the central question in this essay be it possible that for certain sort of intangible property the exclusion condition may not entail the zerosum condition and thus the attendant zerosum conception of property hold and barry implicitly answer this question no
indeed to sustain their thesis they must
for they implicitly assume that all type of property outside the state of nature be characterize which we set out above
this they believe necessarily cause the violation of locke s proviso
they reach this conclusion by ignore the possible independence of the finitude condition and thus by conflate the exclusion condition with the zerosum condition 
but what if for certain sort of intangible property the excludability condition be independent of the finitude condition and do not by itself entail the zerosum condition put the question in a different way might there exist intangible property which be at once excludable but inexhaustible in amount if excludable it could be private property ie one could exercise control over it
if inexhaustible it could meet locke s proviso
it would satisfy locke s proviso in that never mind how much some have already there exist enough and as good for all others
in other word i might have a piece of property from which i can exclude you but there be a unlimited amount you need never suffer privation
you merely go appropriate some for yourself
and this would be true regardless of how much i already have appropriate for myself
thus the heldbarry thesis would fail for such a kind of property
the existence of a inexhaustible source of property would have vast moral implication for the justice or injustice of the institution of private property the accumulation of property as wealth and the distribution of that wealth
let us see how this might be so
the patent paradigm
the most obvious if not the most important example of intangible property of this sort be the idea a inventor of my acquaintance hold seventeen patent
these patent be his property every bit as much as my house be mine
true he hold right to them for a term of year and that make his ownership a bit more like a leasehold right
but in all other relevant particulars his patent have the salient earmark of be his property
the most interesting thing i consider it amazing be that he create them ex nihilo
property be create out of nothing but mental labor he do nt even need raw material as the farmer need land and seed or the potter need clay
of course he need a pencil paper a drafting board and a slide rule my friend be a oldfashioned inventor
but these be more like tool
he need no stuff with which to mix his labor
do my friend be patent idea meet the exclusion condition require of all private property yes they do for no one can use his invention without his approval for which he will normally charge a fee a royalty rather than rent but logically identical to one
so exclusion be both practically possible and normatively effective
indeed the machinery of the patent law be create precisely to enable him to exclude others from the appropriation or use of any of a inventor be patent idea
that ownership or use of that idea without his permission
however even in virtue of his exclusion of me from his idea do it make sense to say there be fewer idea out there which i now can think up appropriate by a patent and then use another way of ask this question be do my friend s patent fit the last two part of the zerosum conception of property what about the finitude condition let us assume a simpleminded platonism in which all idea thought of and not yet think of appropriate through the patent law and not yet appropriate exist
to be sure there be seventeen fewer unappropriated idea available for me to appropriate than before my friend start think
but have that lower the stock of unthoughtof and unappropriated idea still to be think up at all certainly not
the number of both notyetthoughtof and notyetappropriated idea be at least practically unbounded if not infinite
it be nt ever xxn and it be nt now xxn constraint
indeed subtract seventeen from the number of all the idea which i could still think up and appropriate do not seem to decrease the total number
this make the arithmetic of idea seem very similar to the arithmetic of aleph zero thus the finitude condition be violate
what about the zerosum condition itself excludability be enough to ensure that i can not appropriate and can not use without permission any presently extant and patent idea
moreover if i do receive a patent on a idea there be one fewer idea out of the finite number already think up and in existence for others to own and use
if we limit ourselves to the presently extant patented appropriated idea they behave exactly like blackacre ie in accord with the realproperty paradigm
however patent idea be not like real property without a frontier just because as we have see there be a source of a infinite or indefinitely large number of new idea which can be think of appropriate ex nihilo merely by hard and creative think
i do not have to pay anyone for those new idea and more importantly when i come up with one the number available to you be not thereby decrease
thus the zerosum condition be not meet
perhaps most important you be not deprive so long as you remain able and willing to exert mental labor
as it be with patent so it be with copyright and trademark
moreover court have decide that a number of other sort of highly abstract thing unbounded in quantity or number be property
one interesting example be a supreme court decision which hold that associated press have a property right in the news it have gathered all of these kind of property share the characteristic that while i can exclude you from the use of mine there be not thereby a small amount upon which you can draw to use or own
moreover as with locke s real property in the with it here the mental labor of thinking to apropriate it
it be otherwise free as it should be if there be a inexhaustible supply presently unclaimed
of course issue of distributive justice implicit in the concern of hold and barry be not thereby solve for not all of us be intelligent enough or intelligent in the right way to think up idea of sufficient novelty and value to be worth protection by patent or copyright
thus we can not all be equal in access to resource
what be even more disturbing for most of us if idea so construe be the only inexhaustible source of wealth produce by labor be that some of us willing to labor might nonetheless have so little as to suffer physical privation
hold and barry might also quite rightly point out that there be substantial transaction cost connect with obtain patent and copyright
theoretically this can be construe as part of the cost of record title rather the cost of perspective however it make very little difference since
such transaction cost do represent a hurdle to the poor
there be no simple answer to the heldbarry challenge
the availability of intellectual property may favor the industrious as locke and the author prefer
but it also favor the intelligent and that be not obviously fair
moreover as intelligence can be magnify by education and as the transaction cost of record title to idea can be high there be some tendency for such property to be more available to the rich or at least the welloff
there be a response however for there be another source of unappropriated property which seem to be even more available to all than intellectual property
ownership in business enterprise
there be no doubt that the notion of the patent or the copyright constitute a different paradigm of property from that of real property in a nonfrontier situation
there also be no doubt that it fit the lockean notion including the proviso far
thus the heldbarry thesis fail with respect to it
yet we assume for the sake of argument only that other kind of tangible property at least in theory fit the real property paradigm better
the number of bulldozer or bicycle or beer bottle be not unbounded in quite the same way as be intellectual property 
certainly patent and copyright be important in our economy but be they more important than all form of tangible property both real and personal no they be not
but ownership share in business enterprise eg common stock in corporation along with many similar kind of property constitute the single most important kind of property interest in our economic system at the very least they constitute the sort of property which capitalism must have in order to be capitalist ie which allow us to accumulate and exchange capital
i wish to claim that the patent paradigm characterize these most important kind of property in modern capitalism far better than the realproperty shall limit our discussion to common stock of corporation although i believe a similar analysis could be make of any financial asset
a ownership interest in a enterprise be abstract and intangible in the way require by the patent paradigm
there be excludability in the sense necessary for all private property
that is there be a finite number of ownership share of corporation presently extant far if i acquire one share of stock my have it deny ownership of that share to any other
thus if i own all the stock of xyz corporation then neither you nor anyone else can own any of it
if i own nine thousand of the ten thousand share outstanding then you can own at most one thousand
but of course the salient feature of the patent paradigm be that even as i exclude you from ownership of xyz corp there be not fewer share of enterprise in general out there for you to own
why not because in a exactly analogous way enterprise through your own effort and thereby create property ex nihilo or you can purchase the share of someone who have do this
""

let us assume that you open a hotdog stand
you use none of your own money instead you rent all of the fixed asset and borrow from a bank to finance the working capital
you be your sole employee
on day one you have zero equity in the business
you have a bit of luck with your location and build a large and faithful clientele

you then plow all the profit back into the business probably by make principal payment on the bank loan or by buy some of the fixed asset
 in the second and third year you make into the business
at the end of three year you have property worth where do this property come from from your original idea your effort and your entrepreneurial activity as much as the idea cover by the patent come from my friend s head
moreover your in property do not nor do it lower the stock of the total worth of enterprise out there to be build by others or the value of any other property they may hold
from here one can take the story in a variety of direction

he might expand and soon have a business worth 
whatever the denouement we have see that hold and barry be wrong for this case
more property for our enterepreneur do not mean less for anyone else
he have gain and no one have lose
his great stake of property have come from some source which if we have not yet and do not obviously detract from opportunity others might have for obtain more property
it be not zerosum in character
but how do this creation of intangible property work do it really bring such property within the ambit of locke s proviso let us see
a extremely simplify and somewhat simplistic version of the contemporary microeconomic account of how this creation of value occur might run something like this
we assume you do nt misrepresent your product or defraud your customer by use cheap filler for example
thus each time you sell a hotdog you make a customer better off to the extent that their use value for the hotdog be high than or at the limit at least as high as the exchange value you set on it the price

it do however require a commitment to a subjective theory of value if i value something you have more than something i have and you attribute reciprocal value to the two thing the potential for a trade exist in which we be both better off and no one else be bad off thus create a pareto improvement
the exchange of one hotdog with one customer at a price both you the hotdog entrepreneur and she the customer find acceptable be just such a transaction
such transaction be the paradigm market phenomenon of modern microeconomics

as he accumulate these gain he measure profit in his business
wealth in the form of intangible property the ownership of a company be just the accumulated profit
indeed modern worth of this company with its earned surplus or retain earnings

contrary to the heldbarry thesis nowhere do the accumulation of this kind of property by some necessarily require less property for others
james w child

a central theme in recent liberal argument for the freemarket have be a epistemological one
it be claim that the free market be a solution to problem of ignorance and that there be necessary limitation to the knowledge that any particular individual or subset of individual in society can possess
hence there be limitation to the knowledge at the disposal of any central planning board in a planned economy
the economic liberal argue that in contrast to these limitation of centralized planned economy the market overcome the problem of human ignorance
there be two source of these limitation to human knowledge that be particularly prominent in the work of economic liberal
the first be what hayek call the division of knowledge in society that is the dispersal of knowledge and skill throughout different individual in society much of such knowledge take the form of practical knowledge knowledge how rather than knowledge that which can not be articulate in propositional form
hence such knowledge can not in principle be pass on disperse throughout society of which any particular individual or subset of individual will be ignorant
a second source of ignorance be the unpredictability of human need and want
this be in part a consequence of the fact that a individual s need and want often can not be articulate
however it also have another basis
need and want change with the invention and production of new object for consumption
to quote a version of this point from a writer who be not a economic liberal
production not only provide the material to satisfy a need but it also provide the need for the material the need feel for the object be induce by the perception of the object
a objet dart create a public that have artistic taste and be able to enjoy beauty and the same can be say of any other product 
if one also accept popper s claim that the progress of human knowledge be in principle unpredictable if we could predict future knowledge we would already have it then it knowledge and want and need be create by human invention then human want and need be also in principle unpredictable
hence at any point in time we be ignorant about the full range of future human need and want
we have then two source of ignorance
the economic liberal claim that the market be a solution to the problem present by this ignorance
with respect to the first source of ignorance division of knowledge the problem be that of communicate between different actor that knowledge which be relevant to the coordination of their action
its solution require a mechanism which will convey to each agent the information he must possess in order to adjust effectively his decision to those of others
 the price system provide such a mechanism
by serve as a numerical index of change in the relation between the supply and demand for good it communicate between independent actor the information that be relevant to the coordination of their activity
it do so while allow each individual to make best with respect to the second source of ignorance the unpredictability of human want and need the problem be that of have a discovery procedure for uncover what such need and want will be
market competition between business be present as such a discovery procedure just as conjecture about the physical world be test and falsify by experiment so conjecture about future human need and want be test and falsify by competition in the marketplace
the business of those who conjecture wrongly about future need and want fail others pass the test although it be possible that at some future date they in turn will find their conjecture falsify in the market
competition between business in the market prallels competition between conjecture in the science business be realization of economic conjecture
such parallel between competition in market and in the science have be develop far in way which i will discuss later in the paper
the economic liberal claim then that the market solve the problem of human ignorance
in consequence the it possible for a planning body to possess all relevant economic information
two critical point one might make of this defense of the market be central to this paper
the first concern the assumption at the base of the argument that there exist only two way of distribute information in society either through a decentralized market mechanism or through a centralized planning agency
the strength of the epistemological argument for the market depend in part on the implausibility of assume that all knowledge could be centralize upon some particular planning agency
the argument ignore however the existence of the decentralized but predominantly nonmarket institution for the distribution of knowledge and information notably the profession in particular the institution of the scientific community
the contrast between market institution and the institution of the scientific community will be the focus of this paper
the second critical point which be particularly relevant in this regard be that the epistemological defense of the market tend to ignore the way in which the market itself be a source of the problem of ignorance market system there be a disincentive to communicate information between actor who be in competition
put simply if producer a and b be in competition and a inform b of his or her activity and b do not reciprocate then b be in a position to adjust his or her behavior in order to compete more effectively than a in this situation standard game theory apply
while cooperation through mutual communication might be beneficial to both party if one cooperate and the others do not the noncooperating party benefit
given that both party be selfinterested the rational strategy be to act noncooperatively
noncommunication be a competitively stable strategy one sphere in which such noncommunication between competitor be prevalent in the market be that of scientific and technical knowledge
competitor in the market as rational actor actively keep novel scientific and technical work nonpublic
a feature of the market be the existence of a incentive to secrecy and confidentiality in technical information
this feature of the market lead to major conflict where the that associate with the scientific and academic community
the increasing encroachment of market relation into the scientific community have lead to a conflict between the proprietary secrecy of the market and the open communication of traditional science
as nelkin note
conflict of interest be bind to arise in situation in which university faculty be directly involved in commercial venture
the academic responsibility of open communication inevitably conflict with the commercial responsibility to maintain proprietary secrecy 
the detail of such conflict be to be find elsewhere and i will not discuss them in this paper my central concern rather will be with the normative question what be wrong if anything with the employment of market mechanism in the scientific sphere to what extent if at all should the market play a role in the activity of scientific research and the distribution of the result of such research i will approach these question by focus on the difference and possible conflict between the kind of property system presuppose by paper be compose of two section
in the first i undertake some necessary preliminary clarification of different sense in which one can talk of intellectual property the sense in which this be presuppose in the context of the market and the sense in which it be presuppose in modern professional science
in do so i point out some of the confusion in the literature on science study that arise from mix these different sense of intellectual property
the analysis in this section take as its starting point a dispute in the sixteenth century between tartaglia and cardano which highlight the difference and conflict between these distinct system of intellectual property in a particularly vivid way
this example rather than a example of a modern conflict also have other advantage as a starting point for discussion
in particular it enable us to concentrate on the question of the appropriateness of market relation to science and to avoid a added complexity that arise in the modern context ie that scientist in commercial science the result of their research belong not to themselves but to the corporation that employ them
this feature of the modern situation add a far dimension to the normative problem of the involvement of market in science concerning a individual s alienation of right to the fruit of his or her labor
this issue be a important one but be not one i shall pursue here my sixteenthcentury example lack this added complication
as a initial example it allow us to focus on the issue of what if anything be inappropriate in the market as a institutional framework for science in the second section i turn to this central issue of the paper whether market mechanism be appropriate in the scientific domain
i
to understand the dispute between tartaglia and cardano require a examination of the social and economic context of their work
both mathematician belong to the tradition of cossist algebra predominant in italy and germany in the sixteenth century
this algebraic tradition be closely link with the rise of mercantile capitalism and the new textbook produce in the cossist tradition employ predominantly mercantile example and often also include detailed economic information alongside the mathematics
moreover mathematician like tartaglia earn a income from the employment of mathematical skill on behalf of merchant
in this context publication of mathematical result often serve as a form of advertisement for mathematical skill
another important form of publicity come from competition in which mathematician would set each other problem often with a side bet on the winner
success in such competition required novelty in algorithm for the solution of mathematical problem
the origin of the dispute between tartaglia and cardano lay in one such competition
tartaglia have develop a algorithm for solve cubic equation a algorithm which have be develop early by ferro who have keep the solution a secret to himself and a few student
one of these student fior who have use the algorithm to win a series of mathematical competition challenge tartaglia to a contest and lose
on hearing of the contest cardano seek out tartaglia and according to tartaglia at least he be swear to secrecy
however on find that the solution have be discover by ferro cardano publish tartaglia s solution in ars magna cite ferro and tartaglia as independent inventor of the algorithm
despite this citation cardano s publication produce a heated response from tartaglia and a major dispute between cardano and tartaglia 
this dispute be significant in that it reveal a contrast in the notion of intellectual property between that predominant within the cossist tradition and that which have develop in science in the succeeding century
a comment by mahoney on the dispute be to the point here
to the modern scholar imbue with the notion that as xxr k merton have put it a idea be not really yours until you give it away ie through publication tartaglia s attitude seem strange
yet in sixteenthcentury italy where mathematics be a competitive business among the cossists the attitude be more than reasonable 
implicit in the dispute view of intellectual property the first illustrate by tartaglia ferro and others in the cossist tradition be one associate with the market
property here involve as macpherson put it a individual right to exclude others from the use or benefit of something and relatedly the right of individual to transfer some or all of these right to other individual
while these right be not legally enforceable there be clearly a assumption on the part of cossists like tartaglia that they do involve ethical claim on others
tartaglia s attitude to his algorithm be that it be in a real sense his and that he have a right to circumscribe the use which cardano make of it
more generally it lay at the base of the secrecy that be prevalent in cossist algebra
mathematics be as mahoney put it a competitive business
the second view of intellectual property be the paradoxical mertonian concept mention by mahoney a idea be not yours until you of intellectual property in science
as a piece of property the research report be a rather unusual object
the property come into existence only by be make available for use by others 
on this mertonian view then one make a claim to intellectual property by make public a independently develop original result
a result that be unpublished be not recognize as yours
give this view of intellectual property what count as publication become of central importance and significant for this be the growth of the scientific journal as a primary vehicle for publication particularly in the early nineteenth century and the kind of editorial and peerreviewing process associate with it it be through publication in journal or book form that one lay a claim to property right over a theory or result
it might be object here that there be something problematic in talk of property right at all
when one talk of property it normally imply right to use or benefit from a thing ethical force
give this conception of property the publication of scientific result make them public or common property the benefit and use of the theory become the right of anyone within the limit of plagiarism and copyright
einstein s theory of relativity be not the property of any particular individual
it be common property indeed merton also refer in this regard to the communism of science
the substantive finding of science be a product of social collaboration and be assign to the community
they constitute a common heritage in which the equity of the individual producer be severely limit
a eponymous law or theory do not enter into the exclusive possession of the discoverer and his heir nor do the muse bestow upon him special right of use and disposition 
what sense then be there in talk of a individual claim intellectual property through the act of publication in a minimum sense it might be note that we use the possessive in refer to theory einstein s theory of relativity
however this in itself can not be say to be a basis for talk of property
we can also talk for example of einstein s haircut without thereby indicate any property relation
if talk of property be to make sense there must be some sense in which the producer of the theory gain certain right or power in virtue of the act of publication
the right which merton and ravetz be concerned with in their discussion of intellectual property be right of recognition most notably through citation and in some case eponymy and right to the benefit that accrue from such recognition
thus merton continue the quotation above as follow
property right in science be whittle down to a bare minimum by the rationale of the scientific ethic
the scientist s claim to his intellectual property be limit to the recognition and esteem which if the institution function with a modicum of efficiency be roughly commensurate with the significance of the increment bring to the common fund of such recognition
yet this intellectual property be none the less real and important to those who possess it
as a verification of the scientist s accomplishment it can bring immediate reward
and as a implicit guarantee of the quality of his future work it bring in interest for some time after its publication 
however i remain uneasy about the way such talk of the right to recognition and benefit which a producer attain through publication of a theory be cash out in terms of property right over the theory
it would seem more appropriate here to talk simply of publication make a theory common property and refer merely to right to recognition on the side of the producer
the metaphor of the producer s intellectual property be not in itself a problem as long as it be clear what be be say
however problem do arise when the reference to such propertyrights be develop in way appropriate to its more normal use as private property
thus for example later discussion of the nature of intellectual property in science
thus he go on to argue that citation in addition to other function represent a payment for use of the material
 the picture here be that of property in the sense in which it be involve within the market in which a individual with exclusive right to something alienate these property right in exchange for certain payment from those to whom use of the theory be grant
indeed ravetz even go on to talk of imagine a ideal social contract between producer and user of theory
the metaphor however be inappropriate
if one accept the mertonian model of intellectual property as result from the publication of a theory a individual do not thereby alienate property right to the theory on the contrary it be only through the act of publication that it be recognize as that individual s
moreover as a functional explanation of citation ravetz s payment model be implausible there be after all nothing hagstrom s view that academic publication be a instance of giftgiving the concept of giftgiving like that of market exchange assume a model of property as imply exclusive use of a object
the difference between market exchange and giftgiving be that property right be alienate to others in the absence of any contractual expectation of repayment by others
there will of course be other kind of expectation of reciprocal action but failure of such repayment in the case of gift represent not failure of contract but rather indicate that the personal bond between giver and receiver be not in order hence concept such as personal slight become appropriate where reciprocal action be absent
the problem with the property metaphor then be that it can result in import into the sphere of public science concept of property which be inappropriate
we have then two distinct possible concept of property in science
first a concept of property appropriate to the market which indeed be find that which be find in professional science in which theory be common property but where the publication of theory by the producer issue in right of recognition and the benefit of recognition
these two conception of property be incompatible in way illustrate by the tartagliacardano dispute
as merton again put it the communism of the scientific ethos be incompatible with definition of technology as private property in a capitalist economy
 ii
the problem discuss in the previous section concerning the use in the study of science of concept of property appropriate to the market be theoretical they lead to inadequate descriptive and explanatory model of scientific activity
in this section i turn to the normative question which be central to this paper what if anything be wrong with the employment of market mechanism in science be there any reason to suppose that the kind of professional public science that have develop since the sixteenth century should be prefer to the kind of market mechanism that we find for example in the cossist within private firm
there be two kind of objection that might be raise against the employment of market mechanism in the knowledge industry
first there be those which claim that there be condition a item must meet to be the sort of thing that can be a commodity and that scientific theory and information do not meet these necessary condition
second there be those which claim that the kind of property relation appropriate to the market necessarily conflict with good scientific practice
in the following i will argue that the first set of objection fail
i then develop and defend some version of the second
""
the first group of objection which be to be find in the economics literature highlight feature of theory and information that appear to entail that they can not be commodities the first and most significant of these be that they can not be alienate one can not it might be argue sell a theory a proof a piece of information and the fruit or a car after the transaction the seller retain the capacity to use and benefit from the good in question
