this objection however be premise on a misunderstanding of what it be to alienate property it presuppose a mistaken view of property as a thing and not as a set of rights clearly it be not possible literally to transfer a theory in a act of exchange in the same way one can if one sell a car or a bag of apple
however to alienate property be not to alienate a object as such but to alienate a set of right and capacity to use and benefit from a object this be as possible in the case of information and knowledge as it be in the case of commodity such as car and apple
indeed the sale of education and training facility by firm and government provide a good example of how theoretical and practical knowledge be already partially realize as a commodity
a second difficulty that be claim for information as a commodity have access to it
thus for example arrow write
there be a fundamental paradox in the determination of demand for information its value for the producer be not know until he have the information but then he have in effect acquire it without cost 
this problem i believe be overdrawn
it be not necessary to know the content of a theory or item of information in order to be able to assess its probable market value
its potential market value to a purchaser can be measure in terms of behavioral capacity ie in what it enable a individual to do
indeed it be precisely this point that be part of the rationale for competition in the cossist tradition
moreover it be true of most commodity that their quality can only be fully appreciate in the process of consumption
there be nothing then that be peculiar to theory and information in themselves that make them inappropriate item for the market if there be a problem with the use of market and information be inappropriate for the market but that the market be inappropriate for the practice of science
""
the second group of objection concern the way in which the property relation appropriate to the market undermine good scientific practice
i will develop three of these that market mechanism be incompatible with the open communication in science which be a necessary condition for the growth of knowledge that the market as a institutional framework for science disassociate the external reward assign to a contributor to science from the value of his or her contribution to the development of science that private property in science undermine a commitment to the practice of science
i will begin however by consider a case for the defender of the opposing view that far from
be inappropriate as a institutional framework for science the market have all the feature that will make for the best development of science
a good starting point for such a case be the parallel which the the market which i outline at the start of this paper
market mechanism be appropriate to science since they encourage competition between different research group
science like business be at its best a competitive enterprise
the virtue of competition in both sphere be that it encourage innovation
the proper argument for competition in science as in business as a mean of improving knowledge be that it promote alternative conjecture and their critical examination 
indeed it might be note that my early example support this point
cossist algebra be important in the development of mathematics
where mathematics in the university of the period be moribund the competitive pressure of commerce encourage a novelty in algorithm of which tartaglia s work be a notable example
a similar kind of argument might be make for commercial science
for example research work in the pharmaceutical and electronic industry hardly suggest that market competition be a brake on the growth of knowledge
one might argue then that give the competitive nature to it as a institutional framework
a initial point that must be make about this argument be that the reference to recent example of marketbased research just note be unsatisfactory
innovative research in the market sector have take place against the background of a domain of public knowledge
the science have operate within a mixed economy basic scientific research have be carry out within the public professional domain commercial research have be parasitic on this public domain
the problem which be increasingly a practical as well as a theoretical one be whether public science be a necessary condition for scientific development or whether it be possible for all science to take place within a market economy
as nelkin note of new liaison between professional science and commercial enterprise
academic science have be a public resource a repository for idea and a source of relatively unbiased information
industrial connection blur the distinction between corporation and the university establish private control over a public resource
problem of secrecy and proprietary right be inherent in these new the public interest 
this raise the first and central objection to the market as a institutional framework for science touch on at the beginning of this paper
there be in a competitive market economy a disincentive to communicate information
the market encourage secrecy which be inimical to openness in science it presuppose a view of property in which the owner have right to exclude others
in the sphere of science such right of exclusion place limit on the communication of information and theory which be incompatible with the growth of knowledge
thus for example the most obvious defect of the competitive nature of cossist algebra be the kind of secrecy exhibit by tartaglia and ferro which inhibit the spread of the result to other scholar in a position to contribute to their development
it be partially for this reason that tartaglia s response to cardano appear unreasonable to modern who be sympathetic to a norm in which theory be publish and thereby become public property
the development of scientific knowledge depend upon the publication that science tend to grow when communication be open
rather there be a necessary connection between publication and the growth of knowledge
a necessary condition for the acceptability of a theory or experimental result be that it pass the public critical scrutiny of competent scientific judges a private theory or result be one that be shield from the criteria of scientific acceptability
since the judgment of competent peer be a necessary condition for the acceptability of a scientific result the publication of scientific work for the judgment of the scientific community be a necessary condition for its be a contribution to the growth of knowledge at all
open communication for this reason be a essential condition for the scientific enterprise
this be not to say that secrecy or nondisclosure of result be absent from the scientific community
individual and research team do not keep rival inform at each stage of their progress
science be a competitive enterprise
however the pressure for nondisclosure in science be for nondisclosure of premature work
it remain a essential condition for in the public domain
competition in science be competition between individual and group to be first to place before the community a result which will be able to withstnd the critical scrutiny of competent judge
where such a appraisal be successful one can claim right to appropriate recognition
the defender of the market as a institution appropriate for science might respond at this point that my argument fail to note a way in which the market itself can provide a public test for conjecture which be quite akin to that in science
consider the following parallel between the scientific community and the marketplace draw by loasby
after note the point that i have just make that in science we have to rely on intersubjective criteria for appraise theory he write
that should not be a disturbing proposition to economist use to invoke intersubjective judgement of value in the market result from the appraisal and decision of competent wellinformed economic agent
the parallel go far
scientist seek to advance knowledge but can do so their fellow and to comparison with other new idea from other scientist just as entrepreneur seek to better existing offering must expose themselves to the appraisal of customer and supplier and to the risk of be surpass by competitor offers 
loasby here be only point to parallel between scientific and market competition he be not suggest that the market be a appropriate institutional framework for science
but it be open to the defender of the market in science to exploit the parallel
what would be wrong with use the market itself as a public test of the acceptability of theory theory and result that fail to pass the appraisal and decision of wellinformed competent economic agent would fail as they do when subject to the scrutiny of the scientific community
in a free market in knowledge good idea force out bad
this defense of the appropriateness of a market framework for science can not be sustain
the market provide the wrong kind of public test of scientific knowledge
it do so the market provide the wrong kind of community of evaluator for theory
by this i mean something more than that the community of evaluator would include others apart from scientist
there be something wrong with the very parallel that loasby draw between science and the market for loasby as the value of a scientific theory be determine by judgment of competent wellinformed scientist so value in the marketplace be determine by the judgment of competent wellinformed economic agent
however the appeal to competent wellinformed economic agent be disingenuous
the market be in one sense a egalitarian institution any individual s preference count in determine the market value of a good provided it be back with cash
any particular property of a individual s personal skill capacity and competence be irrelevant to whether his or her judgment count
the only property that count be their capacity to pay
inform and uninformed judgment all count equally
market value be not determine by the appraisal but by the appraisal and decision of economic agent per se incompetent as well as competent uninformed as well as informed
science in contrast be inegalitarian in this sense
only certain judgment count
the appraisal of the value of scientific work do require competent and inform judge
the judgment of those without the requisite competence be irrelevant
the market do not provide the right kind of community of evaluator for scientific work 
neither do the market provide the right kind of criteria for evaluation of scientific work
the value a theory have to the development of scientific knowledge be not appropriately relate to its market value
the market value of information and theory be instrumental it be a measure of their immediate usefulness in the service of commerce technology or even as be the case in the cossist tradition in gain publicity for one s marketable skill through victory in competition
such usefulness be only contingently relate to the significance of a theory to the internal development of the science for which simplicity and the like be the appropriate criteria of judgment
relatedly market will value theory that have immediate to nearfuture implication theory and information of more significance to the internal development of science have implication over a long time scale
it be such reason that be at the basis of the observation that market favor research with immediate application and disfavor research of a more fundamental kind
this last point raise the second objection to the market as a institution appropriate to science give the employment of market mechanism the value of a contribution to the development of science be disassociate from the external reward that the institution that support science assign to the contributor
because the market value of information and theory be instrumental and be at best only indirectly relate to the significance a theory have to the internal development of science its reward to the contributor to science be not properly relate to the significance of the contribution
in contrast the process of assign recognition develop by professional science such as peer review be not perfect be at least of the right kind to ensure that the contribution to the internal development of science be match by external reward appropriate recognition and its related benefit
this problem can be state usefully in terms of alasclair macintyre s distinction between practice and institution the practice of science be characterize in terms of its internal good ie those good which can not be identify without reference to the kind of activity it be
the institution of science be concerned with the distribution of external good ie good such as material wealth power and recognition which can be identify independently of any particular activity
in thesystem of property
in science that have emerge over the last three century the institution of science be of the right kind to support the practice of science whereas the system of property distribution associate with the market be not
this distinction of macintyre be between internal and external good raise a third possible objection to the introduction of market mechanism and its related property science be incompatible as such with a commitment to the internal good of science
the exclusivity of property right of market good be incompatible with a commitment to such internal good to exclude other individual from the use of a theory who be commit and able to contribute to the far development of a practice be thereby to indicate a failure of commitment to the development of the practice itself
thus ferro and tartaglia in keep secret their algorithm reveal by their behavior that the goal of the development of algebra be subordinate to goal of a exclusively competitive kind the communism of science highlight by merton be a particular case of a communism implicit in all wellordered human practice
the use of property relation of the marketplace in science be incompatible with a commitment to the internal good of science
theory and information be not the kind of item to which exclusive property right be appropriate give a view of science as a autonomous practice with its own internal good
hence to bring the market into
however this objection as it stand be open to the following rejoinder
the argument above confuse a individual have the right to exclude others from a theory with a individual s exercise of that right
while it be the case that a individual be exclude others from a contribution to science do show a failure in his or her commitment to that practice the use of the system of private property involved in the market be in itself neutral
it be open to the individual to exhibit his or her commitment to the practice of science by waive the exercise of the right of exclusion
this response be i believe a strong one although within a market economy each individual be force to exercise at least some of his or her right of exclusion
let us concede that the third objection fail as state
however its central point can be restate thus give a introduction of market property relation into science the act of publish without some form of payment individual who so act become the selfsacrificing giftgiving altruist find in hagstrom s idealized model of the scientific community
what the market will have effect be a institutional redefinition of a individual s selfinterest which narrow its range
whereas in existing scientific institution to publish one s result be to act in a selfinterested way the market redefine this as a act against one s own interest
hence given that the scientific community be not a community of rationalist saint the market undermine a commitment to the internal goal of science
the main point here be a aristotelian one for aristotle the correct response to the egoist who ask question such as why have friend or why act virtuously be that the egoist have a narrow conception of what his or her good be
the egoist assume a narrow range of good the big share of money honor and bodily pleasure and ask how friend or virtue bring these good
one should respond not by try to show friendship and virtue but by point out that the egoist have misidentify what the good of life are this basic aristotelian point however need a sociologial dimension for it be the institution themselves that define what count as one be interests in particular the market encourage egoism not primarily because it encourage a individual to be selfinterested it would be unrealistic not to expect individual to act for the great part in a selfinterested manner but rather because it define a individual s interest in a particularly narrow fashion most notably in terms of the possession of certain material good
in consequence where market mechanism enter a particularsphere of life the pursuit of good outside this narrow range of market good be institutionally define as a act of altruism
for this reason the market undermine the pursuit of the internal good of practice like those of science
john oneill
university of sussex brighton england
a favorite topic in academic political philosophy in the last third of the twentieth century have be the shortcoming of the economic system under which most of us live
though in recent year there have be some recognition of the advantage of the market and the difficulty with alternative economic system this have not slow the steady stream of criticism of this or that aspect of the free enterprise system
the purpose of this essay be to give a account of the geography of various criticism of this system and to argue that most of those in the current philosophical literature suffer from a common drawback or defect of real importance
toward the end of this essay i shall offer some positive suggestion about how critic might repair this defect
first a analytical question
what be mean by the term the free enterprise system this term be systematically ambiguous
we can think of it as describe actually existing economic system or as describe some kind of ideal type that realworld economic system only approximate
include the economic system of western europe north america and part of the pacific rim
in these system though there be state monopoly in certain industry eg education utility communication and the state try to influence the economy in various way most production do not take place in stateowned firm and the state do not undertake or otherwise direct most new investment
in this sense a free enterprise system be any system in which most of the mean of production be privately own and the state do not determine most investment
on the other hand the term free enterprise system be sometimes use to refer to something more abstract
theoretical discussion by critic and defender of the free enterprise system often seem to be about the economic system of a hypothetical libertarian society with a nightwatchman state
in such a system all mean of production be privately own and there be no attempt at state direction of the economy
the state s role be strictly limit to enforce no need to resolve this ambiguity about the term free enterprise system for the purpose of this essay
however this term be understand systematic criticism of the free enterprise system be either explicitly or implicitly criticism of the privateproperty right that constitute the framework of that system
these right can be understand as the positive legal right that constitute actually existing economic system but only insofar as these right resemble those that would be find in the hypothetical libertarian society allude to above
let us begin with a taxonomy of these criticism
the main function of any economic system be to produce and distribute exchangeable good and service
one important kind of complaint against the free enterprise system be that it do not do a very good job at this that is the system be inherently dysfunctional with respect to some range of good or service
the basic idea behind criticism of this sort be that the system be not produce or distribute the relevant good or service as efficiently as it could be
these efficiency come from a variety of source
welfare economist often charge the freeenterprise system with market failure
market failure be defect of the free enterprise system associate with externality or public good
externalitites be positive or negative effect of voluntary transaction on noncontracting third party
the benefit from a vaccination program and the harm associate with industrial pollution be often cite as example of positive and negative externality respectively
the usual charge be that the free enterprise system overproduce good associate with negative externality and underproduces good associate with positive externality
for example production of a consumer good that pollute the atmosphere be at a high level than it would be if the manufacturer or the consumer have to compensate those who suffer from the pollution
overproduction in this case be overproduction relative to what would take place in a ideal market system
similarly for underproduction of good associate with positive externality
a ideal market system be define in terms of some very strong assumption about perfect information welldefined property right no monopoly there be no uncompensated externality in this model of a economy
in orthodox welfare economics a ideal market system serve as a kind of benchmark against which realworld system be judge
the reason for this be that it be a theorem of welfare economics that a ideal market system achieve a pareto optimal allocation of resource producer and consumer good this be a distribution in which no one can be make better off without someone else be make bad off
the main policy implication of this theorem according to orthodox thinking anyway be that realworld economic system should be make more like a ideal market system to the extent that this feasible since this would result in distribution of good and service more closely approximate pareto optimality
for example if the state prohibit pollution above a certain level this directly or indirectly lower production of the good in question this low production be closer to the level of production that would occur in a ideal market system
this mean that production be have achieve pareto optimality
for this reason a change in the system of property right that result in movement toward a pareto optimal allocation of good and service be think to represent a efficiency gain for the system
a similar strategy be employ with public good problem
public good be define in terms of nonexcludability or jointness of supply and nonrivalrous consumption
in other word a public good be something nonpayers can not be feasibly exclude from consume and consumption by one person do not diminish the quantity of the good available to others
commonly cite example of public good include lighthouse and national defense
it be claim that public good like good associate with positive externality tend to be underproduced in a free enterprise system because roughly of excludability problem
as in the case of negative externalitites the solution to public good problem be seek in governmental action
the state provide the good in question and force everyone to contribute in virtue of the fact that the good be pay in theory free enterprise system be inherently dysfunctional insofar as they suffer market failure that is problem associate with negative and positive externality and public good problem
these failure be explain by reference to the system of property right in the mean of production characteristic of the free enterprise system
in the real world however market failure be mitigate by governmental action which be as it should be according to these critic of the free enterprise system
the state provide some public good such as national defense and it reduce negative externality by for example regulate pollution
nevertheless some negative externality remain and not all public good problem be solve
but perfection be not to be expect
amelioration be however and that be what governmental action be supposed to deliver
charge of market failure constitute one important type of efficiency criticism of the free enterprise system
two other type of efficiency criticism be worth mention
one concern inefficiency associate with monopolistic of oligopolistic pricing
the charge be price be high and production level be low than they would be in a ideal market system which by definition have many supplier or producer for any given product perfect competition
this market imperfection be supposed to be cure by antitrust policy or by direct governmental regulation of price or both
the cure may not be complete but it be better than the disease at least according to these critic of the free enterprise system
a final type of efficiency criticism be that the free enterprise system have certain inherent macrolevel instability which be make manifest in the business cycle
keynesian for example maintain that the free enterprise system can and have suffer persistent and chronic unemployment of human resource because of insufficient aggregate demand
as in the case of other efficiency criticism state action eg through fiscal or monetary policy be advocate to correct these perceived defect of the free enterprise system
these efficiency criticism have provide a theoretical justification for much if not most century
what all these criticism have in common be a charge that the free enterprise system a system of private property right in the mean of production be inherently dysfunctional in one way or another
the remedy for the problem thus identify be always state action
state action can take the form of a government program which be supposed to deal with the problem at hand or it can involve a more direct truncation or abrogation of private property right or both
the thinking be that if government can change the rule of the free enterprise system or otherwise intervene so that the system s distribution of good and service more closely approximate pareto optimality it should do so
after all it be the rational thing to do on the collective level
of course some of this justification for state intervention be after the fact
antitrust legislation for example do not await midtwentieth century development in welfare economics
nevertheless much government regulation and intervention in the free enterprise system have be advocate the system have some inherently dysfunctional feature which can be correct or ameliorate by governmental action that in some way restrict private property right
radical criticism of the free enterprise system have for the most part follow the same general line
according to radical criticism the free enterprise system the capitalist system be severely dysfunctional
it be so inept at do what any economic system be supposed to do namely meet people s want and need for exchangeable good and service that it ought to be fundamentally alter
the language of crisis pervade radical criticism a language that seem more or less plausible at different time
radical and moderate differ in their respective judgment about the seriousness of the problem in question and about the appropriateness of different response
moderate believe that the inefficiency of the free enterprise system be significant but not catastrophic they further maintain that institutional tinkering can noticeably improve efficiency
by contrast radical be inclined to believe that the situation be so bad that only major institutional surgery can suggestion about who the surgeon should be
the literature detail all of these efficiency criticism have not go unchallenged commonly voice objection to the criticism pertaining to public good and externality include the following the socalled public good in question be not really public good that is they can be privatize by redefine or simply enforce property right the provision of public good can be tie to private good which be excludable externality can be internalize by a proper redefinition of private property right or even the enforcement of already existing right
implicitly or explicitly these criticism make the point that the unfettered market be more resourceful and more efficient that its critic believe
in a similar vein efficiency criticism about monopolistic pricing and the instability of the business cycle have be challenge by austrian and neoaustrian economist who argue that state intervention not market force be primarily responsible for both of these problems leave to its own device the free enterprise system would not face problem of monopoly pricing not to the extent that it do when the government intervene
what all these objection to the criticism outline above have in common be the idea that the free enterprise system can meet the challenge the critic pose without the government restrict or abrogate private property right
to the extent that these argument succeed they show that the free enterprise system be not inherently dysfunctional in the way that critic charge
only the most rigid and uncompromising defender of the free enterprise system deny the justice of any and all of the efficiency criticism that have be level over the past century or so
however a different kind of response to these criticism have emerge over the past twentyfive year in the writing of the socalled publicchoice school among others central to their countercritique be the idea that the critic can not simply assume that government or more exactly government official have as their sole or even primary aim the promotion of the public good when they intervene in the economy
critic of the free enterprise system government intervene to correct for some market failure
in a more positive vein these thinker argue that the same assumption and technique use by standard economics to analyze and understand decisionmaking in the private sphere can be use to analyze and understand decisionmaking in the public sphere and that the application of these method do not support the critic prescription about what ought to be do
this mean that market inefficiency do not necessarily get corrected indeed they can get bad when the solution to some efficiency criticism be seek in governmental action and the restriction of private property right this entail
put another way this extension of standard technique of economic analysis into the public sphere have result in the discovery that public ie governmental decisionmaking have inefficiency peculiar to itself
in short there be government failure as well as market failure
all this imply that it be not enough to show that the market fail in some way or other and that in theory the state could correct show that public institution or decisionmaking through public institution would produce a better result from the point of view of efficiency than would the market and the private property right that constitute it
absent a account of alternative and how they would bring about the desired result efficiency criticism of the free enterprise system remain incomplete and suggestive at best and misleading academic exercise at bad
they be incomplete without a adequate account of alternative and how such alternative would work they be misleading academic exercise to the extent that they lead people including people with political power to believe there be governmental solution to what may be effectively unsolvable problem
for the purpose of this essay the most important feature of the public choice countercritique as well as the other objection mention above be that they all focus the issue between the defender and the critic of the free enterprise system so clearly which set of institutional arrangement best achieve a certain agreedupon goal eg avoid or reduce unemployment provide public good with externality or monopoly indeed it be not necessary to accept all of austrian economics or public choice theory to recognize that the real issue on these efficiency question be a choice of which alternative institutional arrangement can best solve a given problem
this issue reduce to the question of how property right ought to be distribute across private and public actor to best achieve a certain result
despite the award of the nobel prize for economics in to james buchanan one of the founder of the public choice movement it be hard to say how widely this insight have be recognize among economist
much of economics in general and welfare economics in particular continue to consist in abstract mathematical modelbuilding and theoremproving there be correspondingly little attention pay to the really difficult question of what any of this tell us about how realworld economic system ought to be structure
although most mathematically inclined welfare economist have be reluctant to move precipitously or even at all from the identification of a certain defect to particular recommendation about how to correct the problem this have not prevent their work from be appropriate by those who do have a political agenda to advance
in addition economist who say yes there be a real problem here but there may be nothing that government official can do that would nt make matter bad tend not to get consulting contract or high visibility
economist criticism of the free enterprise system can almost always be conceive of as efficiency criticism of one sort or another
in evaluate economic system economist generally take end as give and debate the issue of mean
the reason for this be various
sometimes they seem to believe that question about end can not be rationally debate or less charitably they have not be teach how to carry on such debate
sometimes they appeal to democratic and individualistic ideal according to which each individual s value be as important as any others s
on this way of thinking the only question worth debating mean for achieve already give end
by contrast philosophical criticism of the free enterprise system tend to go beyond or behind this meansends nexus
this type of criticism often start with some intuitive value judgment or moral judgment unfavorable to life in contemporary society
the objectionable state of affair be trace to the free enterprise system or more exactly the private property right that define that system
a common type of criticism concern the scope of market exchange
the basic idea be that while the market may be a perfectly acceptable institutional framework for produce and distribute some good and service there be others that be currently produce and distribute in this way for which it be not
for example it have be argue that housing and workplace health and safety be not properly speak commodities a similar view about human organ be widespread in the medical ethics community
the general idea be that there be something about the character of each of these thing that make it inappropriate for any of them to by the market or by marketlike mechanism
that is there be something inappropriate about people have private property right in these thing in the same way they do with other owned object
the criticism be not that the market inefficiently produce or distribute these thing instead the charge be that there be something inherently objectionable about a system that produce or distribute these good or service in this manner
for example if a destitute filipino be willing to sell one of her kidney to a rich american the problem with a economic system that permit this sale be not according to this way of thinking that the market in human organ be too thin for robust bargaining to take place or even that the market be a inefficient way
to allocate transplantable organ
rather the charge be that there be something objectionable about the very fact or be it the very idea of people sell their own body part
because these criticism be direct at the scope of the free enterprise
the main function of the free enterprise system indeed of any economic system be to meet people s want and need for exchangeable good and service
economist efficiency criticism criticize how well the free enterprise system do this job whereas philosopher scope criticism focus on how extensive that job ought to be
however there be another type of criticism come from philosopher that do not easily fit either of these category
some criticism be direct not at the free enterprise system qua economic system but instead at some side effect of its operation
the free enterprise system can permit and even require allegedly objectionable thing to happen that be not directly relate to this main function
for example egalitarian charge that the free enterprise system permit and indeed promote morally unacceptable inequality in wealth and income
civil right advocate charge that the free enterprise system have permit morally objectionable racial discrimination and segregation in housing
the purpose of the economic system be not to generate income inequality or segregated housing a foreseeable side effect of the system s operation
accordingly let us call criticism such as these sideeffect criticism
although philosopher who offer scope and sideeffect criticism of the free enterprise system sometimes do not conceive of themselves as criticize the economic system per se their criticism can be conceive of in this way because they be direct at the property right that define that system
private property right permit and indeed encourage the objectionable thing to happen
philosopher who offer these criticism conceive their central task to be the theoretical justification of the intuition that there be something objectionable about the current state of affair
why should occupational risk not be distribute by the market what be wrong with significant in equality in wealth and income why be the lack of equal opportunity a injustice the theoretical justification for the relevant moral judgment usually consist of the articulation of part of a moral or political theory which include some general principle that imply the intuition
if this be well do it the author and those who share the author s intuition
it be a interesting question which can not be pursue here whether this procedure merely systematizes the prejudice of the author and those who share her sentiment or whether there be something more objective take place
that potential difficulty to one side what i now want to suggest be that many if not most scope and sideeffect criticism of the free enterprise system face the same problem that have plague economist efficiency criticism
the critic have either fail to specify their preferred alternative to private property right or to the extent that they have specify a alternative they have fail to explain how it will solve the problem they have call attention to without result in something equally bad or bad
let us consider scope criticism first
often those who offer such criticism of the free enterprise system do not have much to say about how the good or service in question ought to be produce or distribute except that market mechanism be rule on costbenefit analysis as a basis for decisionmaking about worker health and safety elizabeth anderson devote nearly her entire article to the reason why market or mechanism that mimic the market should not beused in this area
the discussion of alternative by contrast be limit to less than a half a paragraph of vague remark about the advantage of participatory institution 
other scope criticism offer specific advice about what ought to be do but fall to consider systematic unintended negative consequence that may result from attempt to institute their proposal
for example in a recent article in philosophy and public affair margaret jane radin argue that private property right in rental housing ought to be significantly restrict by rent control on the ground that housing ought not to be treat as a mere commodity
despite the detailed blueprint for rent control legislation she draw up nowhere in her article do she consider the possibility that the people who frame and interpret this legislation will not be most interested in do what radin believe be right from the interest of the intended beneficiary
this be important in light of the fact that in numerous city where rent control have be implement welloff and articulate tenant have benefit significantly from rent control policy which have not only ruin many landlord but also harm poor and inarticulate tenants as marxist like to say this be no accident
""
the same problem that face scope criticism also face sideeffect criticism
the first kind of difficulty the failure to articulate genuine alternative be most evident in case where the criticism of the free enterprise system be indirect
for example ronald dworkin offer a qualified defense of equality of economic resource as a political ideal naturally this equality be not realize or even approximate by the free enterprise system
implement this idea require a political authority to equalize difference due to natural endowment by compensate those with disability and impose a progressive income tax on those with exceptional natural talent
to carry this equalization out political authority need a market to determine the as alexander rosenberg have point out however the kind of market dworkin envision could never exist in reality since it assume away crucial problem imperfect information time constraint etc realworld market system have to confront it might be respond that dworkin s ideal market be a analytical device intend to help us think through what equality of resource amount to as such it be not intend to describe a actually existing institution
but this response concede the very point at issue namely that dworkin have fail to describe a alternative to currently existing institution
some sideeffect criticism of the free enterprise system do specify alternative institutional arrangement but fail to explain how the new rule will solve the problem the critic have identify without result in something equally bad or bad
a telling example can be find in john rawls s discussion in a theory of justice of the implementation of his principle of distributive justice
rawls envision a re distribution branch of government in a market society with private be to preserve a approximate justice in distributive share by means of taxation and the necessary adjustment in the right of property the purpose of these levy and regulation be not to raise revenue release resource to government but gradually and continually to correct t he distribution of wealth and to prevent concentration of power one need not be a marxist to believe that the state often represent someone s interest other than the public interest or even more implausibly the interest of justice
it be rather naive of rawls to suppose that political authority could find no use for the vast power require to implement this substantial redistribution of wealth and income other than insure distributive justice
casual empiricism concerning the behavior actually existing state suggest that once the state have the power to finetune the distribution of wealth and income the chance that a society s actual distribution of wealth and income will even approximate the demand of justice whatever those demand might be be remote at best
throughout this section and indeed throughout the book rather complicated ideal to determine the working of the political system
there seem therefore to be a general problem about alternative face philosopher scope and sideeffect criticism of the free enterprise system
philosopher like economist have not think through alternative to the economic system they be criticize
can anything be say on their behalf to investigate this question let us consider how the philosophercritic might try to defend himself
the most obvious excuse be to appeal to the division of labor
one can not do everything and the philosopher be best suit to establish or expose systemic defect of contemporary social institution it might be modestly admit that philosopher do not have the relevant empirical background knowledge or expertise to spell out the alternative
in addition it might be argue that new institution have to come about through concerted political action which require a correct reading of the current political situation the philosopher have no special expertise about that
on a more positive note it might be argue that the the normarive or ethical evaluation of existing institution
there be some suggestive parallel on this score in ethical theory and epistemology that make this position look attractive and defensible
ethical theorist and epistemologist who have reflect long on the relation between theory and practice in their subject matter might well come to something like the following general conclusion human being be a pretty sorry bunch in their personal and cognitive behavior
there be no hope of reform them of get them to clean up their act
any serious attempt to do so will either be irrelevant or make matter bad
the task of the theorist be simply to evaluate and explain their practice in accordance with the appropriate intellectual standard
so the ethical theorist might say that he be only interested in evaluate human action andor character it be fanciful to believe that ethical theory can or should result in less immorality in the world
in a similar manner a epistemologist might maintain that his only aim or purpose be to evaluate human cognitive activity the idea that among the result of his epistemological investigation could be a general improvement in cognitive hygiene be as fanciful as the belief that the practice of ethical theorizing could reduce the severity or incidence of sin
by analogy it be enough for the political philosopher to identify in a systematic way the defect of existing institution including the free enterprise system
propose alternative need not be part of that critique
if he can propose a feasible or realizable alternative more power to him but there be nothing in his enterprise qua political philosophy that require any account of alternative
it may well be that there be no internal inconsistency in this position as it apply to political philosophy or for that matter as it pertain to ethics or epistemology
the problem be that even if this be a consistent position it be incompatible with what critic of the free enterprise system evidently beleive they be do
these critic seem to conceive of their task as provide reason for social change institutional rule especially property right
this be true even of relatively abstract theory of justice such as what one find in the writing of rawls and dworkin
these theory very often clearly imply that the free enterprise system have certain defect defect that warrant or justify institutional change
we know that institutional change be not a completely rational process in the sense that social change closely track the best argument of the day but no social thinker believe himself or herself to be so remote from the lever of social change that his or her writing could not have a impact on the shape of social institution
perhaps more importantly if the critic of the free enterprise system do not conceive of his task as at least in part provide reason for social change he be leave open the possibility that genuinely beneficial change in the economic system in some particular respect might well be impossible
this possibility reflect a pessimism or conservatism that few critic of the free enterprise system seem to endorse
moreover a serious possibility intellectual honesty would require that one call attention to it
since critic of the free enterprise system have not call attention to this possibility without exception as far as i can tell and be we shall presume intellectually honest they must believe that there be potentially feasible alternative to the way thing be currently do
for these reason failure to specify alternative be not a live option for philosophercritics of the free enterprise system
to the extent that these critic have fail to specify alternative institutional arrangement or explain how the latter would solve or ameliorate the problem they have call attention to without cause something comparably bad to happen they have fail to come to grip with the conservative point of view
this will come as no surprise to partisan of this perspective
the general conservative line be to admit that existing social institution be plague with a variety of defect and problem of varying seriousness but that nothing much can be do about them without make matter worse more detail since it represent a kind of stand threat to social criticism as it be currently practice by philosopher a threat to which most contemporary political philosopher have be oblivious
when the institution be criticize be the free enterprise system there be basically two possible conservative responses one deny that the free market or the private property right that define it be responsible for the problem instead the government be to blame or perhaps the problem lie in human nature
a second response grant that the system have the problem to which the critic have call attention but deny that any effort should be make to do anything about it at least at the institutional level in particular state action restrict or abrogate private property right either will not solve the problem or will create some systematic unintended consequence that be at least as bad as the original problem
notice the parallel between these conservative response to philosopher criticism and the two critique of economist efficiency criticism discuss early in this paper absolve the free enterprise system of the charge the critic have lodge against it by blame something else
on the other hand conservative be sometimes willing to concede usually sotto voce the critic s complaint against the free enterprise system but like the public choice theorist they object to the idea that state restriction or abrogation of private property right be the best or even a good response to the problem
the conservative position on any of these question may not be the correct one but this be something that philosophercritics of the free enterprise system must show
what exactly do this entail what must the critic of the free enterprise system do to defeat the conservative challenge that do nothing be the best counsel it be important that the argument of this paper not face the selfreferential paradox of fail to provide positive suggestion about how critic should proceed at one level the answer be fairly obvious the critic must specify alternative institutional arrangement and explain how these arrangement will solve or ameliorate us consider in some detail what each of these requirement amount to
because scope and sideeffect criticism of the free enterprise system be direct at a system of private property right in the mean of production the proposed alternative will involve systematic change in those right
those change have to be spell out
since any system of property right be a system of permission and prohibition on certain activity associate with whatever be own a proposal for change in property right be a proposal for a change in this system of permission and prohibition
when private property right be under critical scrutiny this proposed change usually take the form of private individual or group be require to or forbid from do something that have previously be merely permit
for example it might be propose that business should be require to maintain certain health or safety standard that have previously not be require
or it might be propose that employer be to be forbid to fire employee at will and must instead show just cause and respect arrangement include a new or expanded government program as well as a restriction of private property right
in the case of scope criticism there might be a proposal for a government program to deal with the want and need that elicit a market response in the first place
implicit in some sideeffect criticism eg some criticism of the distributive justice of the free enterprise system be rather extensive government program to correct the problem allegedly cause by the operation of the free enterprise system
finally implicit in many radical sideeffect criticism as well as radical efficiency criticism be proposal for a entirely different economic system usually a socialist one
this system have to be define in terms of the property right it envision
just as the critic must articulate the change in property right he or she have in mind and the associated government program if any it be also necessary to argue that these change will in fact have the desired effect
one thing this mean be that it be result
politician often entitle their legislation in terms of the hopedfor result eg the paperwork reduction act social critic must avoid this way of thinking
it will always be a contingent question whether the envisioned institutional change will do what they be intend to do
to illustrate these requirement more concretely let us consider two criticism of the free enterprise system one of which adequately address them and one of which do not
up until the mid the economic system of the united state in virtue of law recognize and enforce private property right permitted owner of public accommodation to refuse service to anyone for whatever reason
owner of many business in the south and elsewhere refuse to serve black people or segregate their facility base on this right
many people come to believe that the law respecting unrestricted private property right in public accommodation be unjust in this instance
this be a sideeffect criticism of the economic system
passage of the civil right act of curtail private property right in public identifiable injustice and it will come out that way on just about any theory of justice
obviously after the fact it be easy enough to specify the alternative but even before the fact it be not difficult to spell out the proposed institutional change
the envisioned change be narrow and relatively welldefined no more segregated lunch counter colored only drinking fountain rest room etc
""
the government be not tell businessman how to run their business they be only say however you run your business do not discriminate on the basis of race
in short what be required and what in the end be enact be a law that prohibit racial discrimination in public accommodation
it be also possible to foresee that the law outlaw discrimination in public accommodation would for the most part be effective even if the exact extent and duration of resistance could not be foretell
it be reasonably clear what the prohibited behavior be those whose right be and by the midsixties the federal government have the will and the mean to enforce the law
in addition there be threat of private action eg boycott in case of noncompliance
all of these factor come together to make it rational for most owner of public accommodation to comply with the law whatever their personal feeling
one final factor that explain the success of this change in property right be that businessman be about the most easily intimidated group in contemporary society which be why they be often call upon to lead the way in matter of social change
as a result black people in the us today do not suffer the systematic indignity visit on them in the past when they be routinely deny equal access to public accommodation
some conservative who oppose the civil right act do so on the ground that there be nothing morally objectionable about segregation and discrimination
that is they do not see a problem that need solving
at best this manifest a certain sort of insensitivity conservative concern be that this act would set a bad precedent
it would give federal government increased power at the expense of state and local government and it would set the stage for more pervasive governmental interference in the future
here the concern be with unintended negative consequence of a proposed change
the proponent of change can grant that these be legitimate worry but still maintain that the change ought to be institute on the ground that the benefit in terms of utility justice or whatever outweigh the risk
moreover even if these conservative bad fear have come to pass it be surely a oversimplification to attribute the resultant problem to antidiscrimination statute
these concern to one side however the main point of this discussion be that this be a case in which the free enterprise system can be and indeed be criticize in such a way that the demand for a specification of a alternative could be meet
let us consider now a case where a criticism of for a alternative
in elizabeth anderson s survey article refer to above value risk and market norm the author nicely articulate a number of reason why it be objectionable to allow issue of worker health and safety to be decide by the market or costbenefit analysis which be supposed to mimic the market
in answer to the question what ought to be do she say
the people who be place at risk should have the opportunity to participle directly in the decision which affect them
they should have the power to propose debate and vote on alternative health and safety project and to participate in the implementation of these project
for example customer of and resident put at risk by a local power company could elect representative to a committee join by elected representative of worker and stockholder in the firm which would be invest with the power to make health and safety decision regarding the plant 
this passage be typical of discussion of alternative that the free enterprise system
although it look as if the proposed change be describe in terms of a institutional process it be in fact a description of a result namely widespread participation by those affect
only in the third sentence be the reader give any idea about what institutional mechanism be supposed to insure this result
moreover the proposed institutional change be so thinly describe that it be not even clear that it be coherent
the main difficulty be that it envision a transfer of some but not all management right from the original owner to this new committee
base on what anderson say it appear that this committee be supposed to have the power to order expenditure institute program and so forth
assume the manager retain other management right this mean that management right be fragment among different and independent group
the problem be that it be not clear that such a pattern of right could persist in anything but name only
because this committee could significantly affect the profitability have a strong incentive to do everything it could to control it
it be not obvious how this could be prevent without transfer effective control of the mean of production to this committtee or some third party eg the state
in defense of anderson it might be point out that she explicitly recognize in a footnote near the passage under discussion that she be not propose a institutional framework her word as a alternative
moreover she refer the reader to chapter of james campen s benefit cost and beyond for a more elaborate discussion of alternative
however this footnote be reveal in two respect
the very fact that she have relegate this crucial issue to a footnote indicate importance she attach to the discussion of a alternative in a critique of the free enterprise system
far in the work to which she refer the reader the author state that this participatory alternative require the replacement of the free enterprise system with socialism
campen say in the of bca benefitcost analysis require a democratic socialist society
 if anderson endorse these sentiment in her critique of the free enterprise system in this article then she be really advocate some version of socialism in which case she should say so and defend its feasibility
moreover the consideration adduce in the second previous paragraph support campen s contention that socialism would be require
under these circumstance it be disingenuous for anderson to avoid mention the s word
finally and most importantly in the absence of a defense of the feasibility of some alternative nothing anderson say refute the claim that despite its drawback the current system be the best way to deal with risk in the workplace
this problem be especially press in light of the fact that no existing socialist system deal with worker health and safety in anything remotely resemble the way she recommend
feasibility in the above sense should not be confuse with
political practicality
judgment about what be politically practical be timesensitive be legitimately beyond the philosopher s purview
perhaps more importantly the political practicality of a proposed change be really a question of the likelihood that the change can be make not the chance that the change if institute will achieve the desired result
the upshot be that effective and intellectually responsible social criticism do not require a practical political blueprint for initiate social change
maybe a better term to describe what be need be realizability
what the critic must sketch be a realizable alternative
this require not only the articulation of change in the existing system of property right but also some kind of argument or explanation for how these change will produce the desired outcome without at the same time produce comparably bad systematic unintended consequence
what in general term might such a argument or explanation look like
what be need be some sort of plausible story about what people will do if and when private property right be alter in specified way
such story can be tell at different level of abstraction apply the formal technique first develop in microeconomics to generate explanation and qualified prediction about what happen when governmental decisionmaking property right supplant private decisionmaking property right
however this be not the only way to think about what happen when change in property right be institute
a more informal method involve simply ask what positive and negative incentive would be create by the proposed change and how the affected people would respond to the change
for example if the proposal be that the law should be change to require or prohibit certain action on the part of those who own or manage productive resource some reason have to be offer to persuade us to believe that the law can be efficiently enforce
one need not assume that those affect be especially venal in order to see the point of this
it be part of the nature of the situation that these people be not spontaneously do what they be supposed to do
the whole idea be to use the force of law to get them not do
there have to be some reason to believe that they will actually do it and not succeed in take evasive action
this potential problem may not be very serious when the envisioned change be a nottoodrastic restriction on the exercise of some ownership right and a plausible story can be tell about how it will be enforce eg the civil right case sketch above
on the other hand the problem be potentially much more serious when the proposed change significantly disrupt previous way of do thing and when there be additional positive and negative incentive for noncompliance
the imposition of affirmative action quota in hire and promotion come to mind as a obvious case in point
the sort of storytelling describe in the preceding paragraph assume imperfect rationality and rather limited benevolence
of course these assumption be not universal truth about human nature but they do not have to be
they need only be roughly accurate description of most of the affected people in the society under discussion
that point to a abstract picture of human nature which can then be manipulate more systematically
however it be not obvious that this would improve predictive power over what common sense can tell us
the whole idea of the approach advocate here be to use common sense to make some rough prediction about what ordinary people would do if proposed change in property right be to go into effect
what result from speculation of this sort will be lack in analytical rigor and potentially contestable
however there be no reason in principle why such speculation should tell us less about what would happen in the real world than do highly abstract model of human behavior favor by many economist
perhaps more importantly this way of thinking be perfectly suit to address conservative concern about systematic unintended negative consequence of institutional change
the conservative say ordinary people face with the institutional change you envision be go to frustrate your design by do or not do x y and z the approach outline above take this challenge seriously time and again philosophercritics of the free enterprise system have fail to do thi this in part account for the air of unreality that surround much of contemporary political philosophy
what be at stake in all of this be of some general importance
there be a long history of critique of modern institution especially the free enterprise system that have not be accompany by proposal for alternative institutional arrangement beyond the vague intellectual armwaving
the appearance of modesty involved in plead ignorance about empirical matter may well belie a unwillingness to come to grip with the possibility that not all desirable change be really feasible not just for the moment but as far into the future as it make sense to look
until philosophercritics take seriously the problem of think through alternative institutional arrangement their critique of existing institution will be incomplete and political philosophy will continue to be largely ignore by practical man and woman who directly shape the structure of social institution

mueller hollingsworth and cross a describe simple statistics which quantify the repetitive nature of trip between region of equal size mark with line on the floor of a open field
a single trip consist of a sequence of movement between adjacent region and be terminate when the animal reverse direction or complete a tour of the perimeter
trip length be define as the number of region enter line cross during a trip

fortyeight us air force academy cadet be study to examine the effect of individual attitude and organizational reward structure on the performance of a complex integrative task
a attitudinal survey be used to measure each subject s preference for cooperative or competitive situation
distinctly different group environment be create by give four group of six subject competitive instruction and another four group cooperative instruction
the performance criteria be the sum score across eight trial of a complex arcadetype computer game which require one subject to control horizontal movement and another to control vertical movement
although neither attitude nor reward structure alone influence performance their interaction be find to be very significant subject perform poorly when the reward structure do not match their individual orientation
implication for military and professional training program be discuss
deutsch identify two type of situation as end point on a continuum of interpersonal relation within group
he define cooperative situation as those in which the goal of all group member be positively relate ie the success likely
in contrast competitive situation be define as those in which the success of one member make the success of others in the group less probable
deutsch find that group and individual attitude perception and performance often reflect these different reward structure
since deutsch educational social and industrial psychologist have study the effect of alternative reward structure on a variety of task in many different setting
although most published report suggest advantage for cooperative reward structure johnson johnson many institution continue to employ individual competition in attempt to increase motivation and enhance performance klein 
other study have suggest that enduring individual difference in belief orientation or preference ie trait be a primary influence on behavior epstein jackson paunonen 
a study by cohen show not only that some subject have a marked preference for either competitive or cooperative reward structure but that these preference affect a variety of individual and group outcome belief or value system
in real life such personal epistemology be often more potent predictor of performance and satisfaction than traditional individual difference measure such as speed or intelligence greeno 
although result of study of the effect of attitude on group productivity be somewhat inconsistent cooperative person tend both to engender and to report high level of satisfaction shaw 
in this study we seek to vary independently both reward structure and individual attitude toward these structure
reward structure be manipulate to create either competitive or cooperative group of six subject
base on their response to a attitude survey subject be selectively assign to group with either competitive or cooperative orientation
the primary criteria be performance on a demanding arcadetype computer game modify to require coordinated input from two subject simultaneously
hence this study seek to identify the main and interactive effect of situational and individual factor on performance and satisfaction
it be hypothesize that advantage associate with cooperative reward structure and cooperative would extend to this complex interactive task
method
fortyeight freshman cadet fortyone male and seven female between the age of eighteen and twentyone volunteer to participate in this study
although subject do not receive remuneration participation in this experiment excuse them from two hour of unpleasant training and prize be offer for top performer
as cadet our subject be part of a select group of young adult
cadet at the air force academy have average sit score of be in the top of their graduate high school class and earn one or more varsity letter in athletics
as a group since cadet display such homogeneity on many measure of academic and athletic achievement they be often a poor experimental sample for individual difference study
their distinctiveness from the general population and restricted range be both problematic
however cadet do represent many young adult who be competitively select for entry and education in the most demanding profession
it be also true that despite their similarity in achievement fiveitem attitudinal survey be used to measure subject preference for cooperative or competitive environment figure 
subject be require to indicate their agreement or disagreement with each statement on a point scale
three of the statement reflect individually competitive orientation ie and and two reflect cooperative orientation ie and 
the sum of a subject s response to the competitive statement be subtract from the sum of hisher response to the cooperative statement the difference be use as a measure of cooperative orientation
the whale game a arcadetype computer game be the criteria task
specially develop to study human performance this game require subject to guide a blue whale to accomplish two distinctly different task eat plankton or crashing kayak
planktoneating be a tracking task which require subject to guide the whale toward a randomly drift plankton target
this task be generally simple but the unpredictable movement of the plankton make it uncertain and rather demanding
in contrast kayak appear at discrete location on the screen perimeter at predetermined time throughout the game
once on screen the kayak move one space horizontally and vertically toward the whale
this pursuit continue until either the kayak reach the whale or crash into one of twenty stationary iceberg display on the screen throughout the game
subject lose point for be harpoon but gain point if the kayak crash
subject be give explicit priority instruction at the beginning of each trial tell them which of the task be more important ie worth ten time more point
group of eight subject complete the attitudinal survey and receive basic instruction in the whale game during a initial onehour session
they accomplish eight practice trial four of each priority and record their score at the end of each trial
subject be then assign to eight sixperson group such that each group s average performance during the initial session have be equivalent
seven of the group contain one female and five male cadet the eighth be all male
no
within these constraint distinctly competitive or cooperative group be create to accentuate individual attitude through mutual reinforcement
a onehour experimental session take place approximately six week after the initial training session
the second independent variable in this study be the taskreward structure
four group receive competitive instruction another four receive cooperative instruction
a competitive reward structure be impose by tell the six subject in a particular group that only the top scorer among them would be invite to a pizza party
although most college freshman would not see this reward as very significant our subject seem quite take by it
the same reward be offer to cooperative group but the criteria be change
the cooperative reward structure be establish by tell subject that the combined score of all group member would be compare to the score of other group all member of the group with the high total score would be invite to the pizza party
thus in the competitive group the object be to perform better than other member to maximize the performance of the whole group
two different dependent measure be of interest
task performance be measure by the total number of point score on the two game task eat plankton and crashing kayak
the game itself be identical to the one subject have learn during the initial session but the way it be play be not
the six subject in each group share three computer
for each trial one subject control the horizontal movement of the whale and another control the vertical movement
this manipulation forced subject to interact with one another as would a aircrew

furthermore student may learn only a small percentage of fact for which overt response be not require
the above interpretation attribute the pretestposttest difference between active only and active passive module to the presence or absence of passive fact
although this interpretation be plausible it must be accept with some caution

this proposition require independent evaluation
present passive fact in outline as opposed to sentence form do not affect any of the measure

the result of this experiment suggest that there may be a advantage to include passive fact in training student may learn more fact for every training minute when passive fact be include in computerbased training screen
future research should conduct parametric analysis to determine if some ratio of passive to active fact include in computerbasedtraining module could retain the training efficiency advantage of passive fact without reduce training effectiveness

give criticism involve take initiative the motivational proactive step to practice that skill

introduction
the relationship between primary degenerative dementia of the alzheimer s type pddt and normal aging remain a controversial subject
copeland and giaquinto have argue that pddat and normal aging be separate entity but other worker have argue the opposite uren brayne calloway deary whalley 
however there be general agreement that the early phase of pddat be indistinguishable clinically and neuropsychologically from normal aging of the alzheimer s type may be a continuum with normal aging but in the early stage the difference be only quantitative uren

research technique which be sensitive to central nervous system cns change with age would have the greatest chance of identify and quantify early change in patient with pddat

its use in psychiatry be relatively recent and have be largely confine to the investigation of antidepressant and antianxiety agent hindmarch alford hindmarch
