discussion
critical flicker fusion threshold measurement have receive considerable attention from psychopharmacologist in recent year but the technique have not be investigate in patient with pddat
in a previous study of normal elderly volunteer curran wattis shillingford and hindmarch demonstrate a tendency of the cfft to decrease with increasing age but this fail to reach significance
in the same study the difference between fusion and flicker threshold be find to be negatively and significantly correlate with age
this reduction be due almost entirely to a fall in the flicker threshold and may reflect a reduction of the cns to suprathreshold flicker with increasing age
if pddat be a exaggeration of the normal aging process one would predict low cfft value in demented patient compare this have be clearly demonstrate
one would also predict that the reduction of the flicker threshold see in normal elderly subject with increasing age would be exaggerate far result in the fusion threshold be great than the flicker threshold
this have also be clearly demonstrate in demented patient
in normal volunteer the flicker threshold be great than the fusion threshold but with increasing age the flicker threshold tend to decrease with little or no change in the fusion threshold curran et al 
in demented patient this relationship be reverse the fusion threshold be great than the flicker threshold
the cfft have be clearly demonstrate to be significantly low in demented patient compare with normal volunteer
it could be account for by a specific reduction of the flicker threshold so that the cfft in the patient group be low than the volunteer group cfft
alternatively both the fusion and flicker threshold could decrease simultaneously so that the resultant cfft be low than the volunteer cfft
the result from this study clearly demonstrate that group and the volunteer group whereas the flicker threshold be significantly different in the two group
the demented patient have significantly low flicker threshold than their age sex and occupational classmatched counterpart
the reduction of cfft score in demented patient be account for by a reduction of flicker score
one interpretation of this be that in patient with pddat there be a large reduction in the sensitivity of the cns to suprathreshold flicker
this be observe as a trend in normal elderly subject the degree of reduction in flicker threshold be great with increasing age
the influence of increased reaction time in demented patient pirozzolo christensen ogle hansch thompson and shift in the response criteria be unlikely to be alternative explanation
one would expect these to influence the flicker and fusion threshold equally
the result be consistent with pddat be a exaggeration of the normal aging process at least as far as sensitivity to suprathreshold flicker be concerned
measurement of cfft be a simple and quick technique environment in contrast to other functional measure such as the eeg and positron emission tomography
these be not only considerably more expensive but take more time to complete require skilled personnel and be not available to the vast majority of patient especially those with borderline dementia
like other neuropsychological and clinical measure there be some overlap with normal elderly subject
the measurement of cfft and flicker threshold may be particularly useful for longitudinal assessment of borderline case of pddat
under these circumstance the ability of cfft and flicker threshold to predict outcome could be evaluate
choice of unit of analysis be a critical problem in evaluate environmental assessment item
the ecological fallacy involve interpret result base on ecological entity such as environmental setting as apply to individual
a less familiar error the individual difference fallacy involve interpret result base on individual as apply to setting
although this second error have be ubiquitous little be know about the empirical consequence of use different unit of analysis in item analysis
this study examine this issue when the unit be individual observe setting or artificial or random setting
neither item validities base on individual nor item validities base on setting yield unequivocal result
however a measure develop specifically for environmental research the splitsample correlation appear useful for identify environmental item
researcher construct environmental assessment scale should select item with both high splitsample correlation and high settinglevel item validities
the ecological perspective in psychology barker bronfenbrenner stern willems assume that the attribute of environmental setting influence or indeed constrain or determine a wide variety of cognitive affective and behavioral response
consequently researcher from this perspective have explore a number of approach to assess the characteristic of environmental setting astin holland barker craik feimer holland moos pace richards stern 
such environmental assessment involve a number of relatively unique psychometric problem craik feimer pace 
the present study address one such problem the choice of proper unit of analysis
for many year behavioral scientist have be aware of the ecological fallacy robinson the error of interpret variation among ecological unit such as environmental setting as though it apply to variation among individual
it be equally erroneous however to interpret variation among pace richards 
a recent theoretical paper richards suggest this error which have be ubiquitous in previous research on environment gottfredson hybl gottfredson casteneda be label the individual difference fallacy
a common approach to the construction of environmental assessment scale be to use question about the environment that be similar to the question typically use in objective personality test pace stern moos 
the individual difference fallacy be likely to be a especially serious problem for such scale because the item could function as a disguised measure of personality or other psychological characteristic of individual rather than a true environmental measure
accordingly richards use hypothetical data to argue that no analysis use individual as the unit be capable of distinguish between a valid environmental measure and a disguised test of personality
only analysis use environmental setting as the unit could make this distinction
a empirical study richards confirm these theoretical finding but reveal additional complexity
the data be base on individual in environmental setting classroom who respond to six environmental scale
data also be sort randomly into artificial setting of the same size as the observed setting
these random setting approximate a situation in which the scale be a pure disguised test of personality
in addition to individual and set level alpha the scale reliability be assess by a special index richards the splitsample correlation that be design specifically to address the unique problem of environmental measurement
the splitsample correlation be a analog of a splithalf test reliability base on odd item vs even item
to compute one assign number from to xxn to the individual within each setting and compute two summary score for that setting one base on individual assign odd number and the other on individual assign even number then summary score be correlate across environmental setting
alpha coefficient base on individual as the unit of analysis necessarily from observed or random setting confirm that no individual level analysis can throw any light at all on the setting level reliability of environmental assessment scale
the setting level alpha for observed setting be quite substantial but so be the alpha for random setting
thus a standard reliability analysis with setting as the unit also may not distinguish clearly between a valid environmental measure and a disguised measure of personality
the splitsample correlation however be high for observed setting but low for random setting
thus only a index develop specifically for environmental research yield unequivocal result
the present paper extend these argument to the context of item statistics and item analysis
the analysis report here emphasize a traditional index of item validity the adjusted partwhole correlation
however the same point would apply to item characteristic curve in the context of item response theory lord 
method
sample of individual and setting
the data for this study like the data for the scale reliability study richards reduce disorderly behavior in charleston south carolina middle ie junior high school gottfredson gottfredson karweit gottfredson 
specifically the analysis for this study be base on separate assessment of classroom the environmental setting by middle school student the individual
although some student may have assess more than one classroom the set of individual assess the various classroom be essentially independent
only classroom with at least respondent be deem eligible for this study
the number of respondent within classroom vary from to with a mean of a standard deviation of and a median of 
the number for both individual assessment and for environmental setting be large enough to provide highly stable estimate of item statistics
environmental assessment item
analysis be base on student response to abbreviated fouritem version of six of the classroom environment scale develop by moos trickett 
therefore the total number of item be 
moos and consist of truefalse question about the characteristic of the classroom
the following specific scale be include involvement affiliation teacher support task orientation order and organization rule clarity
unit of analysis
the psychometric property of the item in these six scale be examine for three different unit of analysis
first individual ie the student assessment be use as the unit of analysis
for this analysis each item be score or with be assign to the response associate with high standing on the characteristic imply by the scale title
second observe environmental setting ie the classroom be use as the unit of analysis
the summary score for each observed setting or classroom or each item be the mean of the item score for student in that classroom
because the item score be score or these set summary score can be interpret as the probability that a individual in that setting would respond artificial or randomize setting be use as unit of analysis
these setting be construct by sort the individual assessment into a random order and then divide them into group with the same number of subject as the observed classroom
the summary score for each artificial setting on each item be the mean of the item score for individual randomly assign to it
statistical analysis
the first step in the statistical analysis be to compute the adjusted partwhole correlation coefficient or item validity between each item and total score on the scale of which it be a part
the adjustment eliminate the contribution of the item itself to the total score so each adjusted correlation be mathematically equivalent to the zeroorder correlation between the item in question and the total of the other three item in its scale
therefore statistical test for zero order correlation be apply to these coefficient
the reliability procedure include in the spssx statistical package spss be use in compute these correlation
in addition the splitsample correlation richards be compute for each item
splitsample correlation for item directly address the central issue of whether or not different individual agree about the characteristic of given setting on given item
result
table summarize the statistics for individual item
because the number of individual and setting be relatively large even rather small correlation be nominally significant
accordingly the absolute magnitude of the various statistics appear more relevant than their significance level and table summarize the central tendency and dispersion of the various statistics across the item
the mean in table for each statistic except the splitsample correlation for random setting would be significant beyond the level if it be a zeroorder correlation base on the number of individual and setting for this study
the average adjust partwhole correlation for individual be typical for item analysis research but necessarily be identical whether the individual come from the observed setting or from the random setting
this fact provide confirmation that item analysis use individual item measure the characteristic of setting and item measure the characteristic of individual
the average partwhole correlation for observed setting be both fairly high and somewhat high than the individual level correlation
at first glance this result would seem to indicate that to some degree these item be measure the characteristic of setting
surprisingly however the average partwhole item correlation for random setting also be fairly high and of approximately the same magnitude as the correlation for individual
it be unclear why this be the case for theoretically this correlation should be close to zero richards f test at the scale level confirm the adequacy of the randomization richards 
one possible explanation be that randomization do not absolutely equate setting but merely insure that only chance difference persist
therefore the correlation for random setting will approximate the correlation for randomly choose individual
whatever the explanation these result clearly indicate that set level partwhole correlation also can not distinguish unequivocally between item measure setting characteristic and item measure setting be fairly substantial however a clear indication that to some degree these item be measure setting characteristic
more important the average splitsample correlation for random setting be low
thus the splitsample correlation which be design specifically for environmental measure appear capable of distinguishing item which at least in part be measure setting characteristic from item measure only individual difference
at the same time both theoretical consideration richards and the typical property of ecological correlation robinson suggest that the splitsample correlation for item that be measure only set characteristic should be high than the correlation obtain in this study
indeed the splitsample correlation should be for a pure environmental item with no measurement error richards 
the relatively low value obtain here suggest that while these item be to a degree measure the characteristic of setting to a equal or large degree they be measure the characteristic of individual
this conclusion be support by the result obtain previously at
the result confirm the result of a early study of scale reliability richards and suggest that substantial change be need in the itemselection procedure typically use to construct environmental assessment scale
the typical procedure have be to select item on the basis of item statistics for individual frequently individual within a single setting
this procedure not only be incapable of identify item that measure the characteristic of environmental setting but also be virtually guarantee to select item that largely or entirely measure individual difference
therefore item analysis base on individual should be eschew in future environmental research even as a first step and report base on such analysis should no long be welcome in scientific journal
even in the initial stage of scale construction environmental setting should be the unit of analysis in computing item statistics including item characteristic curve
moreover the number of setting must be relatively large perhaps as large as the minimum number of individual need for a conventional item analysis
thus future research aim at more complex and more expensive than have be customary
consequently such research will be more difficult
this great difficulty appear to be the necessary price of obtain scale that measure environmental characteristic however and researcher should not allow such difficulty to deter them from use the proper unit of analysis
it will not be sufficient however simply to select item on the basis of adjusted partwhole correlation with environmental setting as the unit of analysis
such correlation will be substantial for item that measure environmental characteristic but they also can be substantial for item that reflect only individual difference
the itemlevel splitsample correlation be need to distinguish between these two kind of item
in construct environmental scale therefore researcher should select item that have both a high setting level partwhole correlation and a high splitsample correlation preferably high than the splitsample correlation obtain here
because item have never be select in this way no information currently be available that would guide researcher in construct such item
as experience accumulate with possible to identify in advance the type of item most likely to meet both selection criteria
it then would become easy to construct environmental assessment scale that minimize individual difference contamination
this study seek to determine whether or not a disease prevention program might have a negative impact on attitude towards disease victim
knowledge of and attitude towards aids and several other serious disease be assess before and after college student view a filmed educational program on aids
result show that compare to a control group participant who have see the aids film report significantly great fear and dislike of a hypothetical aids patient
the film also significantly enhanced participant perception that aids be a preventable disease
result be discuss in terms of the possibility that healtheducation program emphasize preventability may inadvertently increase people tendency to blame the victim
diseaseprevention program be design to inform people about the cause and course of a disease motivate them to adopt diseaseprevention behavior and teach them prevention skill somers 
the question of whether or not such program also alter reaction towards victim of the disease be generally not address when program be evaluate
from the standpoint of disease sufferer this may be a adverse impact on societal attitude towards victim can such a effect reduce the quality of social support they receive
a substantial literature attest to the fact that the social environment in general and social support in particular can influence personal health
the protective effect of social support have be demonstrate for several health outcome including mortality and the development of chronic disease broadhead et al 
social support have also be find to play a important role in a person s ability to cope with and survive cancer bloom funch marshall lichtman taylor heart disease mallick ruberman weinblatt goldberg chaudhary diabetes heitzman kaplan as well as other disease see dimatteo hays dimond maybury brewin 
give the potential impact that social support have on one s ability to cope with a serious illness it to a reduction in that support
attitude towards the victim of disease comprise one such factor in that if one hold a negative attitude toward sufferer of a particular disease that negativity will probably color hisher interaction with the sufferer
those with a serious illness often find negative social reaction to be as difficult to cope with as the illness itself wortman dunkelschetter 
diseaseprevention program which by their very nature seek to instill in the audience a sense of control and responsibility may unintentionally produce a negative shift in attitude towards disease victim
by increasing belief that most of the responsibility for diseaseprevention rest with the individual such program might increase one s tendency to blame and derogate the victim of disease
one might infer a character flaw to exist in a person who could have act to prevent a serious disease yet fail to do so
in fact previous study have show that victim of preventable disease receive more derogation than victim of unpreventable one katz hass parisi gruman 
the present study seek to explore the hypothesis that a health education program which emphasize the preventability of a disease may increase people negative evaluation of a person suffer from that disease
specifically participant evaluate a aids victim before and after view a popular madefortv aids education program
method participant
thirtynine university undergraduate female and male with a average age of year participate in this study for which they earn extra course credit
procedure
participant who agree to take part in what be describe as a study of health attitude be ask to read a one page interview in which a person with aids disclose personal feeling about have the disease see table for excerpt
after read the interview participant be ask to record their impression of the aids patient on a impression rating scale irs

the film answer common question concerning the transmission of aids and emphasize the step one should follow to prevent contracting aids
follow the film participant who view the film as well as those in the control group again complete the irs and hbq
each phase of the study be present to participant as a separate investigation in the hope that participant would remain unaware of the experimenter hypothesis
the fact that several of the questionnaire deal with a broad spectrum of disease help to make the separate study cover study plausible
questionnaire

in addition they rate the stimulus person s psychological

discussion
finding in this study support the notion that diseaseprevention program may inadvertently do a disservice to the victim of disease
specifically while the film have the intended effect of make participant view aids as more preventable it also increase their tendency to fear and derogate a victim of aids
while the finding suggest that it may be the perception of aids preventability that mediate the derogation of the victim no direct test of this be make in the current study
additional research be need to determine which facet of diseaseprevention program may have the
it be also interesting to note that those who do not see the film feel substantially more positive towards the aids patient at the posttest period suggest that in the absence of the film information repeat exposure increase rather than decreased positive feeling
since social support may enhance a person s ability to cope with and survive a serious illness and since such support may depend on societal attitude towards disease victim the implication of these result be grave indeed
however several caution be warrant in interpret these finding
first one must keep in mind that participant react to a hypothetical aids patient
future research might explore the generalizability of these finding to the evaluation of real aids patient
second because the study be limit to a small sample of undergraduate student the result may not be representative of the general population
far test with more diverse group be necessary before undue confidence be place in these finding
finally only one diseaseprevention program and one disease be test
represent a general phenomenon or one that be idiosyncratic in nature a variety of disease and program should be evaluate
despite its limitation the study should alert those responsible for design healtheducation program that their best intention may sometimes go awry
while such program may be successful in protect healthy individual they may also have the undesirable consequence of increase the burden of cope for those who suffer
the frequency with which verbal uncertainty expression be employ suggest that they play a important role in the communication of state of uncertainty and may have a important role in emerging technology such as expert system
this article critically review empirical study of verbal uncertainty expression span two decade of research between and with the principal conclusion that people be highly internally consistent in their use of verbal uncertainty expression no conclusion about betweensubject variability be justify principally because a there be currently no consensus as to what be to count as consistent or inconsistent use and b there be several factor that confound purported analysis of betweensubject consistency such as the composition of the stimulus set and the scaling task themselves one study suggest that assessment of the meaning of verbal uncertainty expression may be condition by the prior perceived probability of the event they describe
however other interpretation of this study be open
the review also discuss the more general epistemological question of whether be really amenable to the unidimensional framework within which empirical study have be conceive
one of the most salient feature of uncertainty be that people including expert in many field frequently communicate aspect or degree of uncertainty by the use of verbal expression such as possible probable likely very likely highly likely and so on
the following abstract from the protocol of a medical expert diagnose abnormality of the cardiovascular system provide a illustration of the use of such expression for denote both absolute and relative state of uncertainty
there be also a unusual shadow see in the right side represent very likely a anomalously course pulmonary vein a diagnosis outside of total anomalous connection be unlikely even though the av canal be a remote possibility this pulse rate be highly unlikely if that patient have congestive heart failure it be unlikely that this be a total anomalous pulmonary venous connection below the diaphram to the inferior vena cava as be see with the total anomalous connection to the portal venous system this be most likely a prominent tricuspid closure sound suggest the possibility of right ventricular hypertension the second hunch be a atrial septal defect of the primum type with a small righttoleft shunt which be either due to a anomaly to the av canal or even less likely due to pulmonary vascular disease my hunch at this point be a total anomalous pulmonary venous connection either to the vertical vein or to the azygous vein
much less likely be a total anomalous pulmonary venous connection to the inferior vena cava with scimitar syndrome johnson et al emphasis add
uncertainty have be highlight by a number of expert system that have employ verbal uncertainty expression to communicate aspect or degree of belief to the user fox et al van melle bonissone et al 
with the exception of fox a these treat verbal uncertainty expression either as probability value probability range fuzzy probability bonissone et al for example communicate uncertainty to the user use set of linguistic uncertainty term define as trapezoidal highly regular fuzzy membership function on the unit probability interval
one such set base on the result of beythmaron and the associated fuzzy parameter be show in table 
in the context of decision technology such as expert system the frequency and naturalness of verbal uncertainty expression suggest that they may provide a graceful interface for communicating uncertainty to system user
however the question of their appropriateness in interface design be dependent upon a clear account of their use particularly factor such as withinsubject variability betweensubject variability and context specificity of meaning
if people be not internally consistent in the meaning they assign to verbal uncertainty expression or if betweensubject variability be high at the appropriate level of resolution then attempt to incorporate verbal uncertainty expression into a interface will be unsuccessful
moreover if the meaning of verbal uncertainty term be find to be dependent upon contextual knowledge and a model of how it affect the meaning of verbal uncertainty expression to use them appropriately
finally if verbal uncertainty expression be to be model as probability value range or fuzzy subset of the unit probability interval then it must be establish that the semantics of the expression employ permit unidimensional mapping
treat nonunidimensional object as unidimensional would force them into a semantic straight jacket that may both ignore the richness of the information they convey and lead to communication error
in short a comprehensive account of the use of verbal uncertainty expression be a prerequisite for successful application in expert system and other technology

finally with the exception of the expression tossup the range of subject assignment be great for expression nearer the center of the distribution than the extreme

critical discussion
in the introduction a number of question relate to withinsubject variability betweensubject variability and context dependency be raise in connection with the use of verbal uncertainty expression

withinsubject variability
withinsubject variability be generally find to be low johnson bryant and norman beythmarom budescu and wallsten rapoport et al

the time between replication be too small in other study
betweensubject variability
there be conflicting conclusion with respect to betweensubject variability
a bryant and norman budescu and wallsten or specifically point to large individual difference wallsten et al
b rapoport et al

""
the basis for this apparent disagreement appear to be the variety of scale procedure employ and implicit notion of resolution
the study that have report range variance statistics have do so with little or no theoretical rationale and have not attempt to quantitatively draw out the implication of their finding
whereas a standard deviation of in numerical assignment would constitute low variability in some circumstance it might be consider high in others
a consensus measure of betweensubject variability would be beneficial though it be also clear that such a measure must embody some notion of the granularity of information in the task for which it be to be use
the same apply to the interpretation of the significance of rank inversion
generally communication failure will occur only with unlikely or likely and definite but not because of ordinal variability between similar term such as probable and likely
indeed empirical estimate of the resolution level of uncertainty expression appear to be approximately about the number of different category that can be reliably process miller 
two factor that confound the analysis of betweensubject variability be stimulus set composition and the nature of the scaling task themselves
stimulus set composition
many study employ a large number of distinctly nonprobabilistic or not uncertainty base expression
these include frequentistic expression usually seldom and slightly moreless than half the time lichtenstein and newman always sometimes and never bryant and norman always never often frequently seldom rarely usually and usually not budescu and wallsten never kong et al

the inclusion of these expression both undermine the specificity of result to the domain of uncertainty expression and inflate the apparent value of rangevariability statistics by require subject to scale what be heterogeneous strictly noncomparable stimulus on the same unidimensional scale
scale task
the problem with the scaling task be twofold
firstly direct scaling task be of low ecological validity
in general when reason about uncertainty people do not translate verbal expression into numerical estimate even if the precision of the available information be high
verbal estimate like numerical value be essentially way of summarize the available information into a particularly good at translate one frequently used way of summarize uncertainty into another seldomly employ representation the fact that people rarely communicate uncertainty numerically question the use of numerical assignment task for assess verbal representation of uncertainty
secondly and more significantly assess the property of verbal uncertainty expression such as betweensubject variability context effect can not be achieve by the direct assignment of numerical value since these have their own scaling property which confound the analysis
adequate assessment can only be achieve by the use of independent measure of probability such as the spinner task employ by wallsten and colleague where there be a independent scale against which assessment can be compare
in sum there appear to be little justification for assess the variability of verbal uncertainty expression by the use of direct assessment of numerical value
context dependency
the study of johnson find no difference in task context and the study of beythmarom produce result that be difficult to interpret for reason discuss early
the study of estimate assign to verbal uncertainty expression may be influence by the perceived base rate of the event be describe although the alternate interpretation be that the apparent conditioning on base rate be a artefact of average the result of different processing strategy rather than represent variation within sample of homogeneous processing strategy
if verify however their suggestion would have a number of implication for the use and interpretation of verbal uncertainty expression in al though demonstration be await
firstly it would follow that interpretation of verbal uncertainty term will be expect to be influence by factor that affect perception of base rate including availability and other cognitive bias
secondly information concerning perceived base rate or prior would need to be incorporate into a interface that seek to communicate degree of uncertainty to a user
thirdly it suggest the intriguing possibility that such expression may serve partially to act as indicator of change in confidence rather than of confidence level per se
such a notion be embody in the certainty factor formalism develop in the expert system assumption of unidimensionality that the expression employ can be characterize as point region or fuzzy subset on a unidimensional scale pervade all the study report but be explicitly address in only one reyna 
this study provided data that be not incommensurate with a unidimensional view of uncertainty but have a number of methodological flaw describe early
thus the question of dimensionality be empirically open
what be clear however be that many of the expression employ in the study describe do not fit neatly into a unidimensional mould see discussion of betweensubject variability for example
it have also be argue that the pervasiveness of the unidimensional assumption have have the effect of obscure the rich semantics that underlie many verbal uncertainty expression eg fox a b teigen 
conclusion
overall there be little evidence to suggest that verbal uncertainty expression be inappropriate for communicating uncertainty in expert system and other decision technology
equally however their appropriateness await validation distribution

this paper give a account of some of the major aspect of buddhist psychology
the survey be confine to the text of early or theravada buddhism that is the canonical text and their early pali commentary and related expository text
the importance of psychological concept in the philosophy and practice of buddhism be highlight
the problem inherent in the study of buddhist psychology be discuss including the problem of translation and interpretation
the paper then describe and analyze several key early buddhist psychological notion including basic drive that motivate behavior perception and cognition consciousness personal development and enlightenment meditation and behavior change
the relationship between theory and practice in buddhist psychology be comment on with special reference to meditative technique and other behavior change strategy
finally comment be make on the possible interaction between buddhist and modern psychology
introduction
this paper aim to provide a descriptive and analytical account of buddhist psychology
it do not attempt a comprehensive review of the subject the literature literature be too vast to permit a comprehensive review in a single paper
what be present here be essentially a selective account of the psychological notion find in buddhism
only some of the major concept be discuss
some practical aspect of buddhist psychology that have a relevance to therapeutic practice be also review
the paper be selective in another important way
it be confine to theravada buddhism also refer to as early buddhism and do not deal with later development including zen
for a account of theravada buddhism see gombrich for a discussion of the different school of buddhism see kalupahana snelling and thomas 
the literature
the literature of early buddhism be in the pali language
it consist of the original buddhist canon which be put together soon after the buddha s death and commit to write in the first century bc the early pali commentary on the canon that be in their present form by the end of the same period which be best describe as expository and interpretive works
the canon consist of three part sutta pitaka which contain the discourse of the buddha on various occasion throughout his preaching life vinaya pitaka which contain the rule of discipline for the monk and abhidhama pitaka which contain highly systematize philosophical and psychological analysis which be finalize in their present form about bc later than the material in the other two part
a full account of the pall canon be give in webb 
the individual book of the canon be list in table 
the early pall commentary include major text such as sumangalavilasini manorathapurani papancasudani and dhammapadatthakatha which be commentary on specific part of the canon
the early expository and interpretive text include among others visuddhimagga milindapanha and nettippakarana
problem of translation
the entire canon and the majority of the commentary and expository works have be translate into english and publish by the pali text society 
however the english version be often beset with problem of translation and interpretation
perhaps it be worth illustrate this problem with example
a major example be the term dukkha sanskrit duhkha translate by many as suffering
this have lead to buddhism be describe as essentially a pessimistic religion as suffering be state as characterize all existence
some author have offer alternative translation such as unsatisfactoriness disharmony and painfulness gunaratna matthews 
none of these offer a precise rendering of the original term and rahula among others leave the term untranslated
another example be the very challenging term papanca sanskrit prapanca derive from pra panc to spread out
in his book the principle of buddhist psychology david kalupahana consistently translate this as obsession
this be clearly misleading although the official palienglish dictionary of the pali text society rhys as one rendering of this word
this be a key term in buddhist psychology and have be variously translate as impediment conceptual proliferation manifoldness diffusion complex and imagination among others
this will be return to in a later paragraph
it should be clear from these example that the problem of translation be a major obstacle to one s understanding of early buddhism or indeed any other ancient system of thought
for this reason the material in this paper be draw from the original pall text
the buddha and buddhism
before focus on buddhist psychology it be necessary to make a few introductory comment on buddha and buddhism
the buddha the word derive from the root budh to know to comprehend literally mean the enlightened one live in the foothills of the himalayan range of mountain in northern india from to bc for excellent account of the and schumann useful account be also available in carrithers and saddhatissa 
the main teaching of the buddha be contain in the four noble truth
see rahula and saddhatissa for a full discussion of the main tenet of buddhism
these be i that life be characterize by suffer and be unsatisfactory dukkha ii that the cause samudaya of the suffering be crave or desire tanha iii that this suffering can be end nirodha via the cessation of crave or desire this be the state of nibbana and iv that there be a way magga to achieve this cessation which be call the noble eightfold path eg samyutta nikaya xxv 
the noble eightfold path be also call the middle path as it avoid the extreme of a sensuous and luxurious life on the one hand
the eight aspect of the path be right understanding right think right speech right action right livelihood right effort right mindfulness and right concentration
the person who undertake a life base on this path renounce worldly attachment hope eventually to attain the arahant state which may be describe as a state of perfection the word arahant literally mean the worthy one
this state mark the attainment of nibbana
the other teaching of the buddha include the negation of a permanent and unchanging soul anatta and the notion of the impermanence or transience of thing anicca eg majjhima nikaya 
buddhism also exclude the notion of a god there be no creator or a supreme be who rule purvey and control the universe
thus there be no absolutism in buddhism either in the form of a external god or a unchanging universe or a unchanging soul
for the laity the vast majority of to the immediate quest for nibbana the buddha provide a sound and pragmatic social ethic
they be expect to lead a life characterize by restraint and moderation respecting the right of others and be dutiful to those around them
such a restrained and dutiful life be consider not only to be a necessary prerequisite for one s ultimate religious aim it be also value as a end in itself
for example the buddha advise his lay follower to abstain from alcoholic beverage because alcohol indulgence could lead to demonstrable illeffect such as loss of wealth proneness to socially embarrassing behavior unnecessary quarrel disrepute illhealth and eventual mental derangement sigalovada sutta digha nikaya iii 
this empirical and pragmatic approach be a prominent feature of the ethical stance of buddhism
for a discussion of buddhist ethics see saddhatissa and tachibana 
the psychology of buddhism theory
the considerable interest show by modern student in buddhist psychology become entirely understandable when it be realize that
some part of the canonical text as well as later writing be example of explicit psychological theorizing while many of the others present psychological assumption and much material of psychological relevance
for example the abhidhamma pitaka contain a highly systematize psychological account of human behavior and mind and the translation of one of the abhidhamma book the dhammasangani be give the title a buddhist manual of psychological ethics by its translator caroline rhys davids when it be first publish in 
the practice of buddhism as a religion and a way of life involve much in terms of psychological change
the ultimate religious goal of the arahant state both reflect upon and require major psychological change
the path towards the achievement of this goal the noble eightfold path involve step which can only be describe as psychological eg right think right understanding
as the goal be attainable essentially through one s own effort it be not surprising that buddhism have much to say about one s thinking god one can turn to for one s salvation
nor do the buddha claim to be able to ensure any of his follower the attainment of the goal
on the contrary the buddha explicitly state that he be only a teacher who could show the way and that the actual task of achieve the goal be up to each individual s effort
as a muchquoted passage in the dhammapada which be part of the khuddaka nikaya say the task have to be accomplish by yourself
the enlightened one only teach the way
some basic notion
in the following section some of the main psychological aspect of buddhism will be discuss
motivation
perhaps the most logical starting point be the theory of motivation
what drive people in their behavior what motivate human action the unenlightened person s behavior it be say be govern and drive by tanha or crave which as note in a previous paragraph be give as the cause of suffering or classify into three basic form kama tanha crave for sensory gratification bhava tanha crave for survival or continued existence and vibhava tanha crave for annihilation eg samyutta nikaya xxv 
it be interesting that these three primary drive in buddhism have be compare by some author to the freudian notion of libido ego and thanatos respectively de silva 
like freudian theory this theory of motivation may be see as a primarily reductionist one all action have as their source a small number of drive
while crave be see as the source of suffering the term tanha be not exclusively use in a negative sense
there be several instance in the literature where it be acknowledge that one can also develop a tanha for the cessation of suffering
thus tanha can take the form of or can be turn into a desirable force
for example the expository text nettippakarana say here
while the unwholesome kind go with the unsatisfactory worldly existence the wholesome kind lead to the abandonment of crave
""
in a far analysis of motivation buddhism identify three factor that lead to unwholesome or undesirable behavior
these be raga passion or lust dosa hatred or malice and moha delusion or false belief eg anguttara nikaya i ii 
all unwholesome action be see as derive from a set of fundamental root
in fact the text explicitly refer to these as root mula
they be call akusalamulas for example unwholesome or unprofitable root
it be not make explicit whether these always operate at a conscious level
on the other hand certain clearly nonconscious factor also have a part to play in determining behavior
one such group of factor mention be anusaya translate as latent tendency latent bias predisposition and latent disposition
always in bad sense rhys davids and stede xxp 
the term itself from anu si to lie down lie dormant indicate that these be nonconscious factor
these dispositional factor be part and parcel of one s personality acquire through past experience and they play their part in influence one s behavior and contribute to the perpetuation of the cycle of suffering
seven type of anusaya be often mention
the list give in samyutta nikaya xxv be as follow tendency to want pleasure tendency to anger or disgust tendency to speculation tendency to doubt tendency to conceit tendency to want continuous existence or growth and tendency to ignorance
another group of factor which be nonconscious and which influence one s behavior be the asavas sanskrit asrava from the root sru to flow or ooze
this term have be variously translate as influx and canker
these be factor high
it be say that they intoxicate and bemuddle the mind rhys davids and stede xxp 
they color one attitude and thwart one s insight
in one s endeavor for selfdevelopment one have to excise them and this be do through wisdom
the influx be describe as arise from different factor sensuality aggression cruelty body and individuality be give in one account digha nikaya iii 
other list include among others gain loss fame disrepute and evil intention anguttara nikaya iv
motive for good or wholesome action be usually express in negative term
the most consistent account be the one which give araga nonpassion or absence of passion adosa nonhatred or absence of hatred and amoha nondelusion or absence of delusion as the root of good action the opposite of the root of unwholesome behavior anguttara nikaya i term as caga renunciation metta loving kindness and panna wisdom understand anguttara nikaya iii
it be state that one must strive to develop these in order to combat their opposite
perception and cognition
perception be base on twelve gateway or modality ayatana six of these be the five sense organ plus the mind or inner sense and the other six be the object of each of these samyutta nikaya ii 
the status of mind mano be special
it have the ability to reflect on the object of the other sense so in this way it be link to the activity of all the sense kalupahana 
each combination of sense organ and its object lead to a particular consciousness vinnana for example visual consciousness arise because of the eye and material shape
when consciousness be add to each of the pair of modality one get eighteen factor of cognition be present in table

the meeting of the three ie eye material shape and visual consciousness be contact because of this contact arise feeling what one feel one perceive

however the buddhist exposition go beyond this

it will be recall that the term papanca be cite in a early paragraph as a example of a word pose particular difficulty for the translator
in this passage the verbal form papanceti be use
thus the final stage of the process of the term in various context relate to cognition show that it refer to the gross conceptual aspect of the process as it be consequent to vitakka reasoning
once a object be perceive there be initial application of thought to it follow by papanca which in this context be best take to mean a tendency to proliferation of idea

he be overwhelm by concept and linguistic convention

they be all bind up with the notion of i and mine
this mark the intrusion of the ego into the field of sense atta sanskrit atman but the delusion of self affect all one s behavior sutta nipata 
one of the aim of personal development be to enable oneself to see reality as it be without the essential distortion arise from the various factor that characterize the unenlightened person be function
a major aspect of reach the state of arahant be indeed the freeing of one s perception from these distort influence
when one reach a state of perfection one s perception become free of such distortion and allow a direct appraisal of the object
the arahant state
it be perhaps the appropriate place now to consider the arahant state and its attainment
the religious goal of a buddhist be to attain this state which mark the end of the cycle of suffering
this require a process of personal development involve disciplined living sila serious meditative effort mark by concentration samadhi and wisdom panna which be attain through such effort
but what there be numerous description of a arahant in the text
for example
the arahant have destroy the canker live the life do what be need to be do set down the burden achieve wellbeing shattered life s fetter and be free by perfect knowledge
he have apply himself to six thing to dispassion to detachment to harmlessness to the destruction of crave to the destruction of rasping and to nondelusion
anguttara nikaya iii
in psychological term the arahant s action no long emanate from the common basic motive of passion hatred and delusion
he be however capable of joy or positive sentiment
he have loving kindness metta to all and compassion karuna
he indulge in nothing and be restrain in his behavior
nine standard of behavior be list which a arahant can not and do not transgress take life steal sexual contact utter falsehood enjoy the comfort of wealth delusion and through fear anguttara nikaya iv
they contribute to society by be teacher and adviser and be no burden on their fellow being
practical aspect of buddhist psychology personal development and meditation
it be note above that the attainment of the arahant state require personal development base on both restrain and disciplined conduct and meditative effort
this explain why meditation be give a central place in buddhist text
in addition to numerous canonical discussion large section of buddhaghosa s visuddhimagga be devoted to a consideration of this subject in great detail
it be significant that the pall word for meditation bhavana etymologically mean development or cultivation
""
as there be a large and still growing amount of literature on this subject in english only a few brief comment will be make here
detailed discussion be available in pradhan soleleris and vajiranana see also claxton and kwee 
two form of meditation be and the other vipassana insight
while far form of meditation have be develop in later form of buddhism and these include various tibetan and zen technique these two represent the early buddhist technique date back year
it be worth note that meditation of the samatha type be also find in some other ancient indian system while vipassana be a uniquely buddhist development nanamoli rahula 
the word samatha mean tranquility or serenity
samatha meditation be aim at reach state of consciousness characterize by progressively great level of tranquility and stillness
it have two aspect a the achievement of the high possible degree of concentration and b the progressive calming of all mental process
this be do through increasingly concentrate focus of attention the mind withdraw progressively from all external and internal stimulus
in the end state of pure and undistracted consciousness can be achieve
the samatha meditation procedure start with effort at concentrate the mind of state of what be call jhana or mental absorption visuddhimagga 
vipassana or insight meditation also start with concentration exercise use appropriate object on which one focus
in this procedure however once a certain level of concentration be achieve so that undistracted focusing can be maintain one go on to examine with steady careful attention and in great detail all sensory and mental process
through this contemplation one become a detached observer of one s own activity
the object of this contemplation be classify as fourfold body sensation mental state and mental object for example various moral and intellectual subject
the aim be to achieve total and immediate awareness or mindfulness of all phenomenon
this lead it be claim eventually to the full and clear perception of the impermanence of all thing and being majjhima nikaya i samyutta nikaya xxv 
it be hold that samatha meditation by itself can need to attain this goal
while the former lead to temporarily altered state of consciousness it be the latter which lead to endure and thoroughgoing change in the person and pave the way to achieve the arahant state
benefit of meditation
the practical implication of the claim make in buddhism for meditation be quite clear
the meditative experience of both type when properly carry out and develop be claim to lead to great ability to concentrate great freedom from distraction great tolerance of change and turmoil around oneself and sharp awareness and great alertness about one s own response both physical and mental
they would also lead more generally to great calmness or tranquility
while the ultimate goal of perfection will require a long series of regular training period of systematic meditation couple with major restraint in one s conduct the more mundane benefit of meditation should be available to all serious and persist practitioner
from a applied perspective buddhist meditation technique may be see as a instrument for achieve certain psychological a stressreduction strategy comparable to the more modern technique of relaxation
there be a substantial literature in present day clinical psychology and psychiatry which show that meditation can produce beneficial effect in this way carrington kwee shapiro west 
study of the physiological change that accompany meditation have show several change to occur which together indicate a state of calmness or relaxation woolfolk 
these include reduction in oxygen consumption lowered heart rate decrease breathe rate and blood pressure reduction in serum lactic acid level and increased skin resistance and change in blood flow
these peripheral change be generally compatible with decreased arousal in the sympathetic nervous system
there be also certain central change as show by brain wave pattern
the amalgam of these physiological change relate to meditation have be call the relaxation response by some author benson 
interestingly the buddha himself advocate meditation for what we would today meditation be use to achieve trouble free sleep and as a way of control pain vinaya pitaka samyutta nikaya xxv 
it be perhaps worth dwelling briefly on the use of mindfulness meditation for pain control
a study publish in by kabatzinn lipworth and burney report that ninety chronic pain patient who be train in mindfulness meditation in a tenweek stressreduction program show significant improvement as measure by various index in pain and related symptom
a control group of patient who do not receive meditation training do not show such improvement
the rationale for select this strategy for the treatment of pain be explain as follow
in the case of pain perception the cultivation of detached observation of the pain experience may be achieve by pay careful attention and distinguish as separate event the actual primary sensation as they occur from momenttomoment and any accompanying thought about pain
kabatzinn et al xxp 
in another paper kabatzinn rationale for use mindfulness meditation for pain control
he show how mindfulness meditation can enable one to focus on sensation as they arise rather than attempt to escape from them
it help one to recognize the bare physical sensation unembellished by psychological elaboration
one learn to observe these psychological aspect as separate event
this uncoupling have the effect of change one s overall experience of pain
to quote the nociceptive signal sensory may be undiminished but the emotional and cognitive component of the pain experience the hurt the suffering be reduce kabatzinn xxp 
it be this detached observation of sensation that mindfulness meditation as describe in the buddhist text help one to develop
this make such meditation a particularly wellsuited strategy for pain control
in fact the reference in the text to pain control by mindfulness meditation appear to make this very point
for example it be state that the venerable ananda the buddha s personal assistant
on hear from the patient that he be in much pain and that his pain be get bad ananda advise him to engage in the meditation of mindfulness
a similar episode be record with reference to another householder manadinna ananda once again offer the same advice
similarly it be record that the buddha himself visit two ailing monk mogallana and kassapa who be in pain and advise each of them to engage in mindfulness meditation
perhaps the most impressive and most explicit in terms of the rationale for this use of meditation be the account give of the venerable anuruddha
he be sick and be grievously afflict
many monk who visit him find him calm and relax ask him how his painful sensation evidently make no impact on his mind
he reply it be because i have my mind wellgrounded in mindfulness
this be why the painful sensation that come upon me make no impression on my mind
the implication here be that meditation aspect of the pain for example while the physical sensation may remain intact one s vulnerability to subjectively feel pain be reduce
the above account be all from the samyutta nikaya which state this position quite explicitly in a different passage
the untrained layman when touch by painful bodily feeling grieve and lament and be distraught but the welltrained disciple when touch by painful bodily feeling will not weep nor grieve nor lament

samyutta nikaya iv 
the view of pain contain in this expository account be quite clear physical pain sensation be usually accompany by psychological correlate which be like a second pain
the disciple who be train in mindfulness meditation however see the physical sensation as it be and do not allow himself to be affect by the psychological elaboration of pain
thus his experience be limit to the perception of the physical sensation only
it be this account of pain that provide the rationale for the instance cite above where those in pain be advise to engage in mindfulness buddhism also contain a wide range of behavior change strategy other than meditation used and recommend by the buddha and his disciple which can only be describe as behavioral
this aspect of buddhism have be neglect by modern researcher until very recently
it be only in the last few year that these behavioral strategy have be highlight and discuss de silva 
these strategy be remarkably similar to several of the established technique of modern behavior therapy
thus if buddhist psychology be akin to modern humanistic transpersonal and existential psychology in view of its emphasis on the individual his problem and anxiety his predicament and his development through personal effort it also have a clear affinity to presentday behavioral psychology in view of these behavioral technique
the way in which the overall approach of behavior modification and that of buddhism may be see as broadly similar have be discuss by william mikulas 
some area of similarity highlight by mikulas be the rejection of the notion of a unchanging on testability stress on technique for awareness of certain bodily response emphasize the here and now and dissemination of teaching and technique widely and publicly
give this broad similarity and the general toolong attitude of buddhism as exemplify by the kalama sutta anguttara nikaya i in which the buddha advise a group of inquirer not to accept anything on hearsay authority or pure argument but to accept only what be empirically and experientially verifiable it be not surprising that specific behavior change technique be use and recommend in early buddhism
it be also entirely consistent with the social ethic of buddhism which recognize the importance of behavior conducive to one s own and others wellbeing as a goal in its own right
when and where specific behavior change be require both in oneself and others these be to be affect through the use of specific technique
the range of behavioral strategy find in the literature of early buddhism be wide
when these be describe use modern terminology and list modern behavioral therapy manual these include fear reduction by graded exposure and reciprocal inhibition use reward for promote desirable behavior model for induce behavioral change the use of stimulus control to eliminate undesirable behavior the use of aversion to eliminate undesirable behavior training in social skill selfmonitoring control of intrusive thought by distraction switchingstopping incompatible thought and by prolonged exposure to them intense covert focus on the unpleasant aspect of a stimulus or the unpleasant consequence of a response to reduce attachment to the former and eliminate the latter graded approach to the development of positive feeling towards others use of external cue in behavior control use of response cost to aid elimination of undesirable behavior use of family member for carry out behavior change program and cognitivebehavioral method for example for grief
detail of these have be discuss in previous publication which also give reference to the original text de silva 
a full discussion here therefore to cite a example of this behavioral approach in buddhism and indicate its similarity to modern parallel
for the control of unwanted intrusive cognition which particularly hinder one s meditative effort and can therefore be a major problem for a buddhist several strategy be recommend
these be present in a hierarchical fashion each to be try if the preceding one fail
switch to a opposite or incompatible thought
the first be to reflect on a object which be associate with thought which be the opposite of the unwanted thought
this mean that if the unwanted cognition be associate with passion or lust one should think of something promote lustlessness if it be associate with malice one should think of something promote loving kindness and if it be something associate with delusion or confusion one should think of something promote clarity
this exercise of switch to a thought that be incompatible with the unwanted one like a carpenter get rid of a coarse peg with a fine one be claim to
if however the unwanted thought still keep arise one be advise to ponder on the peril and disadvantage of the thought that is to consider its harmful consequence
this would help one to rid oneself of the thought in question like in the case of a young man or woman who be eager to look nice and clean who would be revolted and disgusted if heshe find the carcass of a snake round hisher neck and would immediately get rid of it
ignore and distract
if that too fail the technique of ignore a unwanted thought be recommend
one be to strive not to pay attention like a man who close his eye or look in another direction in order not to see a visual object that he do not wish to see
it be suggest that various distracting activity may be use in order not to pay attention to the unwanted cognition
these include recalling of a doctrinal passage one have learn concentrate on actual
reflect on removal of cause
if the problem still persist then a far strategy be recommend this be to reflect on the removal or stop of the cause of the target thought
this be explain with the analogy of a man walk briskly who ask himself why be i walk briskly then reflect on his walking and stop and stand then reflect on his standing and sit down and so on
control with forceful effort
if this strategy too fail then a fifth method be advocate which be forcefully to restrain and dominate the mind
this use of effort be liken to a strong man hold and restrain a weak man one be to use the effort of one part of the mind to control the other
