this account be base on the vitakkasanthana sutta of the majjhima nikaya and its commentary papancasudani
the similarity between some of these early buddhist strategy and the technique use for this and related thoughtstopping thoughtswitching distraction wolpe marks rachman hodgson and covert sensitization cautela be all foreshadow here
it will have be notice that the increasingly popular technique of habituation training that is instruct the client to expose himself to the thought repeatedly andor for prolonged period rachman be absent from this account
however a parallel of this in early buddhism be find in the satipattthana sutta also part of the majjhima nikaya and the mahasatipattthana sutta of the digha nikaya 
these discourse outline the important meditational technique of mindfulness which be refer to in a early section
mindfulness training be not simply a formal method of meditation but be a general selfimprovement skill with the person training himself to be aware of his body and bodily action of feeling and sensation and of thought and idea as they happen
in developing mindfulness or awareness one might be advise to be alert to all thought that arise including unwanted one
if a unwanted thought arise one be advise to face it directly and continuously to look straight into that thought and dwell on it
it be say that then gradually that thought will lose its intensity and will disappear gunaratna 
the similarity between this and the habituation training paradigm of presentday therapist need no comment
similar comparison can be make between most of the other behavioral strategy find in the buddhist text and those establish in present day behavior therapy for similar purpose de silva mikulas 
the significance of the presence of these technique in the buddhist text be manifold
firstly it reflect the fact that buddhism be not only concerned with one s endeavor to achieve the ultimate religious goal by a process of selfdevelopment as note early it also have something to offer in the area of daytoday management of behavioral problem often as a s own and one s fellow being benefit and happiness
thus these technique be applicable irrespective of whether one have commit oneself to a life devote to the aim of personal development and ultimately the state of arahanthood
secondly be clearly behavioral these be welldefined easy to use and above all empirically testable
indeed the buddhist approach be one of try out various strategy until one that be effective be find
as see above the vitakkasanthana sutta offer the disciple five different technique for deal with unwanted intrusive cognition each to be try if the preceding one fail to produce the desired result
the buddha s advice to the kalamas on the importance of not accept any view as hearsay authority and so forth but only on empirical ground reflect and embody this approach
indeed the buddha s own quest for enlightenment follow this path have try out various method and teaching available at the time he reject each of them as they fail path
thirdly the technique be for use on oneself as well as for influence the behavior of others numerous example be find for both type of use
relevance of buddhist behavioral change strategy
from a applied perspective the relevance of this aspect of buddhism be abundantly clear
a range of clearly define technique be available for use with common behavioral problem
the fact that they be similar to modern behavioral therapeutic technique in remarkable way have the implication that their validity and utility be already establish as many of the latter have be subject to rigorous clinical and experimental investigation
there be a strong case too for those buddhist strategy that so far have no counterpart in modern behavioral modification to be empirically test use clinical and experimental research method
if ground be then find for consider them clinically useful they can then be fruitfully incorporate into the repertoire of technique available to the present day therapist
it can also be argue that these technique will have particular relevance to the practice problem that arise in use method derive from western science with client population of a different cultural background be that the technique offer may seem alien to the indigenous population
thus they may not be readily accept or if accept the compliance with therapeutic instruction may be poor
these cultural difficulty in therapy and counseling have be fully recognize in recent year dardenne and mahtani draguns ward on the other hand if the technique that be use and offer although they may be a integral part of a western psychological system be show to be similar to idea and practice that be accept historically by the indigenous culture then they would have a great chance of gain compliance and success
how a behavioral therapy program be successfully devise for a hindu patient which include the hindu religious concept of karma yoga have be describe by singh and oberhummer 
similarly therapeutic package that include traditional zen practice have be use successfully with neurotic patient in that modern behavioral therapeutic strategy will be more readily acceptable to buddhist client group if their similarity with those find in the early buddhist literature and the use of the same or similar technique by the buddha and his early disciple be highlight
the use of meditation technique as a stressreduction strategy with buddhist group in several place provide a example of this phenomenon
a case in point in the use of buddhist meditation in a psychiatric setting in kandy sri lanka de silva samarasinghe 
mikulas have comment on the favorable reception accord to the idea and technique of behavior modification in another buddhist country thailand
a far possible application of buddhist psychology for therapeutic purpose lie in the area of prophylaxis
theoretically there be much scope for this both with buddhist client group and with others
several buddhist technique appear to have a potential role to play in the prevention of certain kind of psychological disorder
for example train in meditation lead to great ability to tolerance of the numerous inevitable stress in modern life
one may in other word achieve a degree of immunity against the psychological effect of stress and frustration stress inoculation training of meichenbaum 
the facility and skill in selfmonitoring one can acquire with the aid of mindfulness meditation could provide a valuable mean of selfcontrol
the role of selfmonitoring in the selfregulation of behavior be welldocumented kazdin 
the overall selfdevelopment that buddhism encourage and recommend also have something to offer for prophylactic purpose
for example if one train oneself not to develop intense attachment to material thing and to those around one one be less likely to be vulnerable to psychological distress and disorder arise from their loss including abnormal and debilitating grief reaction
this be not to suggest that the total renunciation of all worldly comfort and attachment should be the goal of every person
indeed very few person in today s world will want to renounce all material thing and devote themselves to the attainment of personal perfection
would remain lay person with normal household duty and daytoday activity and pursuit and that only a relatively small number would renounce lay life completely hence the prominence give in buddhism to lay ethics gombrich saddhatissa 
on the other hand some of the meditation exercise and other personal development endeavor find in buddhism can potentially enable a person to develop a outlook on life and pattern of response which in turn will help cope with the problem of living by enable great calmness and assurance and with reduced vulnerability to common psychological disorder
this kind of primary prevention be certainly worth explore
buddhism and modern western psychology
finally a few comment may be make on the relationship between modern western psychology on the one hand and buddhist psychology on the other
the relationship between the scientific psychology of the west and indigenous system of psychology can take many form range from totally independent existence to complete integration katz 
buddhist psychology be so only in the narrow sense in that it develop prior to and outside the context of modern western science
it offer clearly testable hypothesis and therefore can be bring within the realm of scientific inquiry
far as note above the overall stance of buddhism be a eminently empiricist one and the process of evaluate the notion and practice of its psychology be something that will be consistent with this stance
such testing will not be alien to the spirit of buddhism which encourage enquiry and discourage dogmatic acceptance of theory and claim jayatilleke 
thus buddhist psychology can potentially make a contribution to modern scientific psychology without compromise its basic stance or that of the latter
what be the chance of the successful integration of the two in the author s view total integration between two independently developed system of psychology each quite sophisticated do not seem to be either feasible or desirable
modern scientific psychology will continue to evolve and grow and in the process it source for evaluation and where the evaluation have lead to positive result incorporation
buddhist psychology will continue to be one of the indigenous psychology that will provide many such testable concept and technique and thus make a contribution towards the far expansion and development of modern psychology
beyond such interaction and influence it be not plausible to assume that the two system in their entirety will be or can be integrate
on the other hand it be possible to envisage that a limited integration between certain aspect of buddhist psychology and certain parallel area of modern psychology may fruitfully be affect
mikulas for example have argue for a integrated new system of behavior and behavior change of which both buddhism and behavior modification be subset
within the broad limit of psychology it be indeed possible that such school or area of modern psychology which be able to derive much from or have much in common with buddhist psychology may develop and fiuorish with such close interaction
there be a good deal of buddhism and other idea of personal development and enduring personal change
on this limited scale close overlap and synthesis seem possible
in the broad context buddhist psychology be likely to keep interact with modern psychology rather than achieve integration with it
in this interaction it will continue to make a contribution to both theory and practice in different area and in varying degree of significance
this contribution be likely to be particularly significant in the area of psychological therapy
this study describe the development of the depression proneness rating scale dprs a brief selfadministered measure of the tendency to experience frequent longlasting and severe depression and three investigation into the scale s reliability validity and factor structure
study use university student
find a stability coefficient of for the dprs over a testretest interval of nine week
far time t dprs score predict time t symptom of depression even after adjust for time symptom xxr change 
study use university student find the dprs to be a better predictor of past depressive episode xxr to than be the beck depression inventory xxr 
study use university student find that all item of the dprs load or great on a single factor for both male and female
overall result provide substantial evidence for the dprs as a valid depression proneness refer to the tendency to experience relatively frequent longlasting and severe depression
researcher interested in uncover the determinant of depression proneness have typically use one of three correlational design correlate the hypothesized determinant with current severity of depression all measure obtain in a single setting correlate the hypothesized determinant measure at time with a measure of depression obtain on some later occasion or correlate the hypothesized determinant with the subject past history of depression
a example of the first approach be a study conduct by seligman abramson semmel von baeyer 
as predict by the learnedhelplessness model depressed student make more internal stable and global attribution for bad outcome than do nondepressed student suggest that attributional style may be contribute to depression proneness
of course a major shortcoming of this type of design be that one can not rule out the equally plausible proposition that attributional style be a consequence rather than a cause of depression coyne gotlib of a individual s current affective state with his or her tendency to become depressed
although it be reasonable to expect that depression proneness would correlate with a individual s current affective state this relationship be far from perfect
not everyone who be depression prone will be depressed during the assessment period and not everyone who be depressed will be equally depression prone
klerman for example find that only of those diagnose as neurotic depressive ever experience another depressive episode during a fouryear followup
a example of the second approach be a study by metalsky halberstadt and abramson 
these author find that measure of attributional style take before a important exam time do not predict depressive mood in college student who have just receive a unsatisfactory grade on their midterm exam time but do predict depressive mood in these student two day later time 
a major advantage of this approach over the first be that by adjust for the effect of a significant correlation between the hypothesized determinant of depression proneness attributional style at time and depression at time xxn can be consider consistent with the proposition that attributional style predispose to depression and inconsistent with the proposition that attributional style be merely a consequence of depression
however other problem remain
in use the subject s affective state at time xxn as a indicant of depression proneness the researcher be in effect make a inference about the subject s tendency to become depressed base on a single observation and as epstein have demonstrate inference regarding behavioral tendency that be base on single observation be apt to be high in measurement error and low in temporal reliability or replicability
the metalsky et al
 result provide a excellent illustration of this point
if mood have be assess at time t but not time t the attributional style hypothesis would have be fully support
conversely if mood have be assess at t but not t a example of the third approach be a study by silverman silverman and eardly 
these investigator assess dysfunctional attitude in patient with a history of depression when they be symptomatic and again when they be in remission
the logic behind this design be that if dysfunctional attitude exhibit by the symptomatic depressive be still present when the symptom of depression have remit then these attitude qualify as possible determinant of depressive vulnerability rather than as correlate or consequence of the depressive episode itself
however certain aspect of this approach can be problematic
as lewinsohn zeiss and duncan have note study of patient population be potentially bias by factor relate to helpseeking behavior and treatment
most depressed individual do not seek or receive treatment roberts vernon weissman myers thompson and those who be treat be likely to be suffer from more severe form of the disorder davies blashki 
there be also the possible confounding of psychotropic medication that be typically prescribe for the remitted patient in these investigation simons garfield murphy 
another problem appear to be obtain reliable diagnosis of depression
some study corer wittenborn silverman silverman eardley report select their subject according to the research diagnostic criteria rdc or the diagnostic and statistical manual dsmii dsmiii but do not provide information about the training or interrater reliability of the interviewer make the diagnosis
yet another problem with this approach involve dichotomize individual as depression prone or not depression prone on the basis of whether they have ever receive a psychiatric diagnosis of depression
it would seem more appropriate to consider depression proneness to be a continuous variable and to develop more sensitive and stable measure of this variable
lastly many researcher who want to investigate vulnerability factor or risk factor in depression can not use this approach because they simply do not have access to sufficiently large number of formerly depressed patient
many if researcher have access to a psychometrically sound and economical measure of depression proneness
to this end zemore have develop a measure of depression proneness that do not rely on current severity of symptom or past diagnosis of depression
instead respondent be ask to indicate the extent to which they experience a variety of depressotypic symptom over the past two year
assume that each subject s report be base on multiple observation of his or her affective reaction to a variety of situation over the past two year these selfreport should provide more direct more sensitive and more reliable measure of depression proneness than those use in past investigation
additional advantage of this approach over some of those previously discuss be the ability to treat depression proneness as a continuous variable the ability to assess large number of individual quickly and economically the ability to assess a variety of nonpatient population and when use in conjunction with measure of current affective state the ability to statistically control partial out the influence of and other situational or personal variable of interest
the depression proneness rating scale dprs be develop by zemore and zemore bretell to assess a individual s tendency to become depressed the dprs have three question compare to most people you know how often do you get depressed compare to most people you know how long do your depression last compare to most people you know how deeply depressed do you become
each question be accompany by a point scale anchor at one end by the descriptor much less often much short or much less deeply and at the other end by the descriptor much more often much long or much more deeply
the midpoint of the scale be describe as about the same
the dprs list ten of the most commonly assess symptom of depression and ask the respondent to rate how frequently compare to others he or she have experience these symptom over the past two year
at one end by much less often and at the other by much more often
the midpoint be describe as about the same
